title: Review/Theater; A Surrealist's Eye Among the Ruins
description: The Talking Band has a long history of treating topical subjects in imaginatively oblique ways. And "The Blue Sky Is a Curse," a trilogy of surreal music-theater pieces whose title was inspired by a Magritte painting, is typical of the whimsical approach taken by the venerable experimental ensemble.

title: Deadly Injustice
description: The Supreme Court's latest mangling of death penalty issues is part of its campaign to speed up and multiply executions in the United States. That may be the will of the people in some states, but the Court's unprincipled reasoning in three cases last week would make a hangman blush.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PRINCE ANDREW stopped by WALTER ANNENBERG 's place in Rancho Mirage, Calif., for a few days.

title: Game May Be Blowout, but the Show Must Go On
description: If you want expert soothsaying, don't ask NBC's Super Bowl team. With the Dallas Cowboys' 52-17 destruction of the Buffalo Bills as crucial hindsight, let us recall the NBC crew's predictions:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Somewhere out there is the perfect Charlie Goldberg. He's a boy who's 13 years old, give or take a year or two, with a sharp sense of humor and a savvy New York demeanor laced with sensitivity. MEG SIMON , a casting director, is scouring the city for him to take over the role as one of the two sons in "Conversations With My Father," the drama about a Jewish bartender on the Lower East Side struggling for assimilation and success.

title: Pianist Cancels at Carnegie
description: The pianist Andrei Gavrilov has canceled his appearance at Carnegie Hall with the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra on Thursday at 8 P.M. because of a death in his family. Barry Douglas will be the soloist, playing the scheduled program: Tchaikovsky's First Piano Concerto and Beethoven's "Eroica" Symphony. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: A One-Two Punch Knocks Out the Bills
description: After Troy Aikman threw two touchdown passes to Michael Irvin today, he passed him his Most Valuable Player trophy.

title: Robert Pekarsky, 70, Dental Lawsuit Expert
description: Dr. Robert L. Pekarsky, a dentist and expert on dental litigation, died on Thursday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan, his family said. He was 70 years old and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: There are more cultural conservatives than cultural liberals, and their ability to mobilize should not be underestimated. You've got 300,000 to 400,000 churches out there, and there's nothing like that on the left. PROF. JOHN GREEN -- of the University of Akron. [ A14:4. ]

title: Dance in Review
description: New York City Ballet 'Two's Company' and 'Reunions' New York State Theater

title: Israel Holding 3 U.S. Arabs It Links to Militant Group
description: In the continuing crisis over the 400 Palestinians deported to Lebanon, the Israeli Government today debated actions to stave off sanctions threatened by the Security Council, and announced the arrest of three Arab-Americans it suspects of involvement in the group that was the main target of the expulsions.

title: Sports of The Times; Turnover Prophets Of Doom and Boom
description: WITHOUT a crystal ball or tarot cards, the Super Bowl XXVII coaches defined the difference in last night's game two days before that difference developed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Lebow Completes Race
description: FRED LEBOW, president of the New York Road Runners Club, continued his comeback from brain cancer yesterday, competing in the New York Road Runners Club's 5-kilometer run in Central Park. Lebow, who also ran in the New York City Marathon in November and the 5K Midnight Run on New Year's Eve, was timed in 29 minutes 14 seconds for the 3.1-mile event.

title: North Korea Rebuffs Nuclear Inspectors, Reviving U.S. Nervousness
description: In a move that has increased concern that North Korea is secretly continuing an effort to develop nuclear weapons, North Korea has rebuffed a request by the International Atomic Energy Agency to visit two sites that Western intelligence agencies say are linked to the program.

title: Alexandra of Yugoslavia Is Dead; Queen Without a Throne Was 71
description: Queen Alexandra of Yugoslavia, the widow of Peter II, whose reign as the last King of Yugoslavia was ended in 1941 by invading German troops, died Saturday at her home outside London. She was 71.

title: Kotite View: Smith Threw a Block Party
description: Along with 120 million other Americans, Rich Kotite watched the Dallas Cowboys' systematic, opportunistic trouncing of the Buffalo Bills in Super Bowl XXVII last night.

title: Abroad at Home; Not a Rose Garden
description: After the election, Republicans charged that the press was biased against George Bush. A conservative think tank produced a solemn report to the same effect.

title: Clarence L. Holte, 85, Collector Of Materials on Blacks' Heritage
description: Clarence LeRoy Holte, who assembled what was thought to be the largest private collection of books on black history and culture, died on Friday in Oakland, Calif. Mr. Holte was 85 and lived in Oakland.

title: Investors Now Expect Inflation to Remain Low
description: Inflation is down. That is documented in Government statistics. But what was not so sure until last week's bond rally is that investors and traders -- long known for their skepticism -- are actually beginning to believe that inflation will stay low for some time.

title: American Express: Try, Try Again
description: For the second time in a week, the American Express board meets today to choose a chairman. The leading candidate, Richard M. Furlaud, is poised to join the growing ranks of chairmen who are not also chief executives -- the better to oversee their companies' activities.

title: Lett, Carried Away, Fumbles His Moment of Glory
description: The game was over, and Leon Lett had his prize in sight, so he reached out confidently and this time he made sure. The Dallas Cowboys' defensive lineman grasped the Super Bowl trophy with two hands and said, "I won't drop this one."

title: When Good Will Is Not Enough; Desegregation Project at Heart of Hartford School Suit
description: Twenty-six years ago, hundreds of black children from Hartford stepped onto buses to go to schools in five nearby towns. They were pioneers, the first to take part in Project Concern, one of the nation's earliest voluntary desegregation programs between a city and its suburbs.

title: U.S. Cable Unspools Its Wires Across the Globe
description: MTV is planning to expand its music video empire to Latin America in October, at which point the only continent where the American cable channel is not seen will be Antarctica.

title: Trail of Killer Is Growing Colder In Chicago Suburb Where 7 Died
description: Three weeks after seven people were found shot to death in two coolers at a fast-food restaurant, the police in this Chicago suburb have made no arrests and named no suspects. And as time passes, it is less likely that they will, some criminologists and law-enforcement officials say.

title: Gentle Voice, Roses, a Smile: West Side Misses Shy Victim
description: In all the tales of sudden death in New York, there are always the salient facts: the strange, sad circumstances of the final encounter, the grim details of weapons and wounds, the history of a life tragically cut short. There are such facts about the life and death of Aurea Bonnie Vargas.

title: Question Box
description: All-Stars in N.H.L.

title: XXVII Marks the Spot: Dallas Is Back on Top
description: The Dallas Cowboys turned a close game into a rout so quickly, so decisively, so painfully for the Buffalo Bills in Super Bowl XXVII today that all the Bills could do was sing a familiar refrain: Wait till next year.

title: Not Exactly a Dream Come True
description: It was not the kind of Super Bowl experience that Bills quarterback Jim Kelly expected. He thought he would be standing in the winner's locker room. Perhaps even accepting the Most Valuable Player award.

title: Equality Is Replacing Quality in Today's Big East
description: For all the talk about the poor performance outside the conference by the members of the Big East, competition within it has never been more ferocious. Some call it parity. Others say that everyone has dropped to the same level of mediocrity.

title: Croatia's Chief Vows 'Liberation' Of More Land in Serbian Enclave
description: President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia today completed a quick tour of territory wrested from Serbians over the last week, and he used the occasion to promise the "liberation" of more land deep inside the Serbian enclave in this country.

title: Greenspan the Politician
description: Alan Greenspan, the habitually cautious chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, appeared to have read the election returns when he gave a surprisingly strong endorsement last week to President Clinton's plans to stimulate the economy.

title: TV Awards Go To 4 Agencies
description: Four agencies won Best of Show Grand Awards as the New York Festivals presented its 35th annual international television advertising awards on Friday in New York.

title: Review/Rock; Pop Metal's Weight: In the Eye of the Beholder
description: "Satisfied vanity revealed becomes fatuity. This is the rather impertinent name which the hypocrites of modesty -- that is to say everybody -- have invented, because they are afraid of genuine feelings." So wrote Jules Barbey D'Aurevilly in "Dandyism," published in 1897. Mr. D'Aurevilly meant to defend men of fashion against public scorn; but his words apply, almost a century later, to the much-maligned world of pop metal.

title: Doctor of the Dying Treads With Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Maybe It's the 4th Time That's a Charm
description: Frank Reich, the Bills' backup quarterback, could already see Buffalo Coach Marv Levy spinning his way around the team's third Super Bowl loss.

title: New York's Poor Trying Alternative to Medicaid
description: On an icy winter morning at the Livingston Income Support Center in Brooklyn, a handful of men and women sat in a back corner of the office listening quietly as city workers explained a new requirement for those seeking public assistance.

title: Local Loan Funds Also Help the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Talk of Sundance; The Winners and Notable Losers at Sundance
description: Mainstream was once a derisive word at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: A River Runs Through Courier's Victory in Australia
description: Jim Courier was running for the river, running toward a repeat of last year's victory swim with his coach and high-energy soulmate, Brad Stine.

title: In Somalia, Now It's the U.N.'s Turn
description: In just two months, American forces have nearly completed their assigned mission of providing desperate Somalis with emergency humanitarian relief. The tasks ahead are best handled by the United Nations, not the United States alone. Yet U.N. authorities have shown extreme reluctance to take charge.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, followed on Thursday by an auction of one-year bills.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: Review/Television; Reuther, The Big 3 And Days Of Sit-Ins
description: The gritty pictures from the 1930's, the union tunes and the reminiscences of United Automobile Workers old-timers bring back the organizing battles of what became America's biggest industrial union. But the hero of tonight's hourlong documentary, "Sit Down and Fight: Walter Reuther and the Rise of the Auto Worker's Union," remains a distant figure.

title: Two Surveys Show Split On Clinton's Performance
description: Two new polls indicate that Americans are deeply divided over President Clinton's job performance so far, and are almost evenly split over the first major issue his Administration has tackled, the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces.

title: Governors Ask U.S. to Set Standards on Health Care
description: In a sweeping new policy statement, the National Governors' Association said today that the Federal Government should set nationwide standards for health insurance and should limit the tax deductibility of health insurance for both employers and employees.

title: Money Fund Assets Down
description: The total assets of the nation's 609 retail money market mutual funds decreased by $3.62 billion, to $383.20 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute has reported.

title: Perfection in a Hot Dog Is Found in a Drive-In
description: PETER Gonda and Ford Macieski have been eating hot dogs together for 45 years, and they figure just about all of them have been eaten at Rawley's, a drive-in right out of a Norman Rockwell painting.

title: Art Bauman, 53, Choreographer; Began Dance Theater Workshop
description: Art Bauman, a dancer and choreographer who helped to found the Dance Theater Workshop, died on Wednesday at Tisch Hospital in Manhattan. He was 53 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Staten Island Packs One-Two Punch
description: IF AT FIRST you don't secede try, try again.

title: Equity Issues This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected during the week beginning today:

title: Doomed in Dome: Pirates Fall to Orangemen
description: If upset is still a definitive word in the Big East, where everything goes this season, then Syracuse indeed upset Seton Hall today, 76-67, before a roaring crowd of 28,033 in the Carrier Dome.

title: Fitness Clubs Vie for Market Share
description: When Marc Tascher looked out the window of one of his New York Sports Clubs the other day, the fine skyline view was not what captured his attention. Mr. Tascher, the chairman of New York City's largest chain of health clubs, pointed to a sleek skyscraper a block away and began to criticize what occupies its basement.

title: Man Arrested in Abduction Of Boy Who Is Found Safe
description: Authorities in Monmouth County, N.J., are holding a man in the abduction Friday afternoon of a 10-year-old Keyport boy who was left hogtied in the woods less than a mile from his home.

title: Dance in Review
description: New York City Ballet 'Afternoon of a Faun' New York State Theater

title: Two Floors Burned At Midtown Tower
description: A fast-moving fire damaged three floors of a virtually deserted 29-story office tower at 280 Park Avenue, at 48th Street, about 11 P.M. last night, bringing about 40 pieces of equipment to the midtown scene.

title: Dance in Review
description: Little Angels Children's Folk Ballet Carnegie Hall

title: Bulls' Paxson to Miss A Month After Surgery
description: Chicago Bulls starting point guard JOHN PAXSON will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee Thursday, which is expected to keep him out of action for at least a month.

title: Chiat/Day and Riney In New York Shifts
description: Chiat/Day will replace Dick Sittig, who has served as creative director of the New York office for almost two years. Mr. Sittig, 34, will return to the agency's Venice, Calif., headquarters in May as a senior vice president and associate creative director.

title: Choice Is Notre Dame
description: Quarterback RON POWLUS of Berwick, Pa., a virtually unanimous choice as the national high school football player of the year, ended speculation by announcing that he will attend Notre Dame. The 6-foot-4-inch, 210-pound Powlus, who holds most of Pennsylvania's career passing records with more than 7,500 yards, chose Notre Dame over the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Review/Pop; 60's New Orleans Sound Updated by 90's Energy
description: In the mid-1970's the Meters, who were on the road opening for the Rolling Stones, would come back to their hometown, New Orleans, and put on extraordinary and prophetic shows, merging hard rock, funk and New Orleans parade rhythms. Their albums, on Warner Brothers, didn't even hint at the ferocity of the music or its sense of expansion. It was so intense that minutes seemed like hours, hours seemed like days, and by the end of now-legendary shows everybody, musicians and audience alike, would wander exhausted out into the early-morning darkness.

title: Low Australia Inflation
description: Australia has achieved the lowest inflation rate in the developed world, according to figures released last week. Australia's consumer price index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in the final quarter of 1992, for an annual inflation rate of three-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Petrovic's Perpetual Motion Has Heads Spinning
description: We now turn your attention from the mass hysteria known as the Super Bowl to one of the National Basketball Association's most amazing players: Nets guard Drazen Petrovic.

title: Rebbe, but Not the Messiah, As Lubavitchers Compromise
description: An event billed as the Grand Rabbi of Lubavitch's coronation as the King Messiah turned into a frenzy of singing and dancing last night in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, as thousands of ecstatic followers pleaded with the Rebbe to reveal himself in all his messianic glory.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The parents of the jazz trumpeter ARTURO SANDOVAL fled Cuba and arrived safely in Florida after their first escape boat sank.

title: Rangers Are on the Expressway to Desperation
description: When the season began with the optimism of October, Ranger fans wondered whether their team would not only be the best in the Patrick Division, but also the best in the Wales Conference, the best in the National Hockey League and maybe even the best team in the world.

title: Rifle Gunfire Wounds a 2-Year-Old Girl on a Street in the Bronx
description: Janil Urbino, 2 years old, was safe in her father's arms when the stray bullet hit her in the right side.

title: Runner's Baby Ill
description: The Cuban track star ANA QUIROT was recovering well from severe burns, but her prematurely delivered daughter developed severe neurological problems over the weekend, the news agency Prensa Latina said.

title: Fund-Raising Efforts Reveal Mayoral Candidates' Strategies
description: The angry sound bites of the New York City mayoral election are months away, but for more than a year a quiet campaign has been busily afoot: the race for millions of dollars to make it all possible. The candidates' cash says much about them and their strategies for winning.

title: Somali Police Back on Duty, With U.S. Aid
description: Throughout the two years that his country was collapsing into anarchy, Hussein Hassan Awale stood guard at the central police station here. While looters stripped everything they could from the neighboring buildings, Mr. Awale lived here, preserving the station's courtyard and terraces from ruin.

title: Iran Could Gain Ex-Soviet Land; Tajiks Arrest Activist
description: To the Editor:

title: A Media King With Much to Prove
description: For someone who has just lost more than $640 million, Jean-Luc Lagardere looks singularly sprightly. The eyes of the ebullient chairman of Matra-Hachette still twinkle, and he remains a man with a ready smile.

title: Elinor Stecker, Mano Orel
description: Elinor Horwitz Stecker, a senior editor of Popular Photography magazine in New York, was married yesterday to Emmanuel Orel, a photographer in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. Rabbi H. Leonard Poller performed the ceremony at Courtland Gardens, a senior citizens' residence in Stamford, Conn., where her mother is a resident.

title: Behind Japan's Economic Crisis
description: The Japanese economic crisis, reflected in a 60 percent decline of the stock market over two and a half years and by declining growth, should not be comforting to foreign competitors. Japan's manufacturers will be concentrating afresh on the world market to keep themselves going. They have no choice.

title: Ron Kostelnik, Tackle For Packers, Dies at 53
description: Ron Kostelnik, a former Green Bay Packers defensive tackle, died Friday night as he suffered a heart attack and lost control of his car on Interstate 75 in Kentucky, authorities here said. He was 53.

title: Springfield Calling
description: After BILL ELLIOTT of Mid-America Nazarene made college basketball history with his 432d career 3-pointer, his biggest worry was keeping his sneakers. The Basketball Hall of Fame in Springfield, Mass., wants them, along with the uniform he was wearing and the game ball from Mid-America's 76-74 loss to Baker on Saturday night in Olathe, Kan.

title: With All the Fun That Comes Before, Why Let the Game Begin?
description: Whether it's the Inauguration Ball or football, the Hollywood crowd is omnipresent. The Dallas Cowboys, fresh off their bus a week ago, were being handed room keys and minibar keys when actor Gene Hackman begged quarterback Troy Aikman to peer his way. "Wish I had paper for an autograph," Hackman was heard to say.

title: Review/Theater; Getting to Know a Joan Who Is Saintly, Shavian And Just a Bit Unlikable
description: Saint Joan

title: INSIDE
description: Koreans Block Nuclear Visit

title: Cowboys' Defense Pours On Pressure
description: The Dallas Cowboys' no-name defense took no prisoners today.

title: Review/Theater; A Room With a View of a Family
description: "The Boiler Room," by Rueben Gonzalez, opens with the wife of a building superintendent praying to the boiler of the title. Indeed, in the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater's production, the cranky heating plant so dominates Edward Gianfrancesco's ingenious set and the whole theater that it seems natural to find a supplicant kneeling before it.

title: An Oil Import Fee Makes Good Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Surprising Governor Keeps State Guessing
description: In 1988, when Gov. William Donald Schaefer was in his second year on the job, a member of the Maryland House of Delegates took the floor one day to offer a brief prayer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10 FLIGHT OF CAPITAL FROM RUSSIA

title:
SUPER BOWL XXVII: ON THE SIDELINE;
Watching From Wings, Reeves Feels for Bills
description: Dan Reeves believes it's O.K. for a man to cry in public -- even at Super Bowl games.

title: Congressional Brief; Amid Calls for 'Change,' Senate Stays the Course
description: When the rest of Washington hums a mantra of "change," count on the United States Senate to stand fast against the kind of loose thinking abroad in the land that suggests the venerable Congressional way of doing business is, well, not quite adequate to the nation's needs.

title: Results Plus
description: N.H.L. A Capital Club Record The Washington Capitals extended their unbeaten streak to a club-record 13 games yesterday with a 2-2 tie against Pittsburgh. Washington is 9-0-4 at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., since Nov. 20, outscoring the opposition by 63-43. The unbeaten string surpasses the previous high set in 1982, and marks the first time Washington has gone two straight months without a home loss. The second-place Capitals haven't beaten a team with a winning record since New Year's Day, and still trail Pittsburgh by 17 points in the Patrick Division. (AP)

title: Byrd Says I'll Walk By Myself
description: Jets defensive end Dennis Byrd, partly paralyzed after breaking his neck during a game Nov. 29, said today that he is going to try to walk by himself, without the aid of a walker, crutches or a therapist, in the next 10 days.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the scheduled release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Ireland Devalues Its Pound
description: Ireland this weekend gave up its fierce battle to maintain the strength of its currency, handing another big victory to speculators and leaving Europe's battered monetary system facing another test of its ability to survive.

title: Gay Issue Mobilizes Conservatives Against Clinton
description: Emboldened by the furor over President Clinton's proposal to allow homosexuals in the military, conservative and evangelical Christian groups are furiously organizing, raising money and looking ahead to the battles to come against the first Democratic President in 12 years.

title: Pasadena Turns Into Playground For the Cowboys
description: In the end, the burdens were more than the Buffalo Bills could bear.

title: Market Place; Hospitality Franchise is a hot stock in a tepid lodging industry.
description: IN the issue's first day of trading in December, the six million common shares of Hospitality Franchise Systems rose $2.75 from the initial public offering price of $16. And the company, the worldwide franchiser of Days Inn and Howard Johnson and the franchiser of Ramada in the United States, shows no signs of cooling off.

title: Sony and Time Warner Put $20 Million Into Cable Radio
description: The music publishing divisions of Sony and Time Warner, as well as Time Warner Cable, have invested a total of about $20 million in Digital Cable Radio of Hatboro, Pa., a fledgling radio service transmitted through local cable television systems.

title: Suspects in Fatal Robbery Linked to Others at Banks
description: The four men who took part in an Upper West Side bank robbery on Friday that ended with the death of a robber and his hostage are suspected in the holdup of the same bank in November, the police said yesterday.

title: A Tradition of Giving to the Neediest
description: Elsa W. Koestler began in the 1920's. Hope Cobb started in the 1930's. Babette S. Goldman sent her first check in the 40's, and Robert S. Sandler first mailed his in the 50's.

title: Iraq Ordered to Name Its Weapons Suppliers
description: The head of the United Nations nuclear inspection team here said today that Baghdad must turn over a complete list of foreign suppliers for its nuclear program before the Security Council would lift or ease sanctions on Iraq.

title: For Buffalo's Fans, a Third Winter of Discontent
description: The city that gets no respect just slipped another notch.

title: Shultz Memoirs Say Bush Knew Of the Arms-for-Hostages Affair
description: In a new book, former Secretary of State George P. Shultz disputes assertions by George Bush that Mr. Bush had only vague knowledge of the arms-for-hostages arrangement in the mid-1980's.

title: Stalled Tobacco Suit Is Revived by Ruling
description: After winning a five-year battle to remove a Federal judge from sitting on their cases, cigarette companies defending against smokers' lawsuits found scant reason last week to cheer a ruling by the judge's successor.

title: Dance in Review
description: Lance Gries St. Mark's Church

title: Dublin Upbraids Its Partners in Currency System
description: The Irish Government criticized its larger, richer European Community partners today for not helping it avoid the 10 percent currency devaluation announced Saturday night in Brussels.

title: Japanese Stocks Gain
description: Stocks rose today, as buying by public pension and insurance funds offset profit-taking that had been restraining the market. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 stocks was up 109.86 points, or 0.65 percent, to 17,133.64. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 39.63 points, or 0.23 percent.

title: Effort to Save a Company
description: A group of former employees at Supercomputer Systems Inc. said on Saturday that they were trying to raise $20 million to $30 million to save the company.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY AN EXPERIMENT IN HEALTH CARE

title: Review/Pop; Shaking Off the Vestiges Of Rock's Family Dialect
description: Rock is supposed to resist musical and cultural entrenchment; the only rule rock musicians are bound to follow is the one that says, blast all rules to shreds. But traditions build themselves, inevitably, through formal repetition and paternal influence. Today's bands bear traces of the Stones, Led Zeppelin or the Clash, because those groups created the family language. To escape their parents, today's rockers have to run a very long way from home. Or they can redecorate the old haunts in colors meant to disturb and dislocate their esthetic elders.

title: Revlon Expected to Replace No. 2 Executive
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics giant that is the cornerstone of the billionaire investor Ronald O. Perelman's financial domain, is expected to announce today that Michael M. Hammond, its second in command, will step aside.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; Where literary lightning hits, book houses often hope for a second strike.
description: THE WAY THINGS OUGHT TO BE" by Rush Limbaugh, the conservative and popular radio and television talk-show host, has astonished the publishing world by breaking records for sales of hard-cover nonfiction at the two largest bookstore chains.

title: 1 Messier Out, 1 Messier Up
description: The Rangers don't know if Mark Messier's injured wrist will be recovered enough for him to play against the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum tonight. But they are sure to dress the best available Messier because they called up Joby Messier, a distant cousin of Mark Messier, from their Binghamton farm club yesterday.

title: Bridge
description: A freakish hand with a seven-card suit and a four-card suit often presents a bidding problem. Conventional wisdom suggests that one should select the seven-card suit as trump and spurn the possibility of playing in the four-card suit. The reasoning, in general sound, is that losing control is unlikely playing in the seven-card suit but likely in the four-card suit.

title: Dance in Review
description: Nina Winthrop and Dancers Theater of the Riverside Church Morningside Heights

title: Clemens to Be Honored
description: The former Texas Longhorns pitcher ROGER CLEMENS will become the first baseball alumnus to have his jersey number retired by the school. Clemens, who wore No. 21 for Texas in 1982 and 1983, is a three-time American League Cy Young Award winner with the Boston Red Sox. (AP)

title: Dokes Goes Out Early, But Not to Buy Bagels
description: At 1 o'clock yesterday morning, Michael Dokes stepped out the front door of his midtown hotel, jogged up to 96th Street, then turned down Fifth Avenue and ran alone through the heart of Manhattan. The streets were quiet, the air was cold and no one seemed to notice the dark figure moving along the city's sidewalks.

title: Ads Down, Los Angeles Times Again Cuts Staff
description: Under pressure to cut costs amid a severe advertising slump, The Los Angeles Times is carrying out a voluntary buyout program, its second in 18 months. The program will trim the staff by 9 percent, but also strip The Times, the nation's largest metropolitan daily newspaper, of some of its most respected reporters.

title: Dance in Review
description: Errol Grimes Merce Cunningham Studio

title: Iran Could Gain Ex-Soviet Land
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; The Great Reshuffle
description: They're rioting in Africa, as the old song goes; throughout that continent, warring tribes are ripping apart the once-secure borders of nationhood.

title: Tokyo Journal; Shedding Teens (and Jeans), They're Now of Age
description: To celebrate Coming-of-Age Day, one of Japan's most colorful annual rituals, Chie Karube and her friends knew that to observe ancient tradition a few modern techniques would help. So first they extracted the equivalent of several thousand dollars from their parents to buy brilliant kimonos befitting 20-year-olds about to declare their legal, if not their financial, independence.

title: Review/Music; The Past As Enemy And Totem
description: Any composer begins by choosing a past, a series of masterworks to be overturned or imitated or studied. But Luciano Berio has chosen a peculiar relationship to tradition, as could be heard on Friday night, when Dennis Russell Davies led the Brooklyn Philharmonic Orchestra at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in an impressively played concert devoted to Mr. Berio's music. The concert, which was repeated on Saturday night, suggested how much Mr. Berio's avant-garde stance, during more than three decades of composition, has involved wrestling with the past, both in rejecting it and in absorbing it.

title: Iran's Leader Challenges U.S. And Talks of Re-election Bid
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani confirmed today that he was ready to run for a second term in June and warned the Clinton Administration in unusually dismissive terms that it was up to Washington to improve relations with his country.

title: The C.I.A.: Time for an Overhaul
description: In R. James Woolsey, the Central Intelligence Agency will have a Director who did not rise through its ranks. As a consumer, not a producer, of intelligence assessments, he knows their flaws. He also has an outsider's skepticism of covert operations. May he act on those sound instincts to reshape an agency mired in history's amber.

title: Books of The Times; Middle-Class Rage: Like in History, Only Different
description: Boiling Point Republicans, Democrats and the Decline of Middle-Class Prosperity By Kevin Phillips Illustrated. 307 pages. Random House. $23.

title: Doubts Arise On Finances Of Prospect In Post Sale
description: To his fans, Steven Hoffenberg is a successful entrepreneur willing to use his muscle and money to rescue the faltering New York Post. To his critics, he is a combative loner who pushes the rules of business to the limits.

title: Patents
description: TINKERING with the intricacies of musical acoustics, William R. Epping obtained a patent last week for the first blues harmonica that can play complete chromatic scales -- the equivalent of several octaves of both white and black keys on a piano.

title: Truman's Legacy to Clinton
description: Isn't it paradoxical that on the day President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore attended the funeral service for Thurgood Marshall, Mr. Clinton found himself in the situation Harry S. Truman occupied in 1948 in the months leading up to his executive order integrating the military?

title: Disclosures on Analyst's Stockholdings
description: A Raymond James & Associates analyst who liquidated his holdings in a stock while telling investors to buy owned far more shares than the 27,500 previously disclosed.

title: Turning a new page, Playboy takes up the fight against AIDS.
description: THEY say that only a President like Richard M. Nixon, known for his staunch anti-Communism, could have pursued rapprochement with Communist China. Perhaps, then, only a men's magazine like Playboy, known for its strong heterosexual orientation, could become so intimately involved in the fight against AIDS.

title: Japan Bank Is Expected To Cut Rate
description: With Government officials acknowledging that the steepness of the current recession has taken them by surprise, the Bank of Japan is reportedly about to cut the official discount rate to its lowest level since 1989.

title: Free Tuition To Be Sought In Bias Suits
description: It was known, in some headlines last fall, as "the black list," a roster of all black male students at the State University of New York's College at Oneonta, that was supplied to the authorities investigating an attack on an elderly woman who had described her assailant as black.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Jordan Rallies Bulls

title: No Headline
description: "Judge Wachtler has dedicated virtually all of his professional life to doing justice and enhancing the administration of the judicial system. He will now put his trust in that system to exonerate him." -- CHARLES STILLMAN, Sol Wachtler's lawyer. [ B4:1. ]

title: Rich Bond -- Right, but Late
description: Richard Bond did not go gently into retirement. His swan song as chairman of the Republican National Committee criticized his party's rightward drift in general and its opposition to abortion in particular. His words, while true, would have carried a lot more credibility had he not waited until he was going out the door to utter them.

title: William Carter Awards Account
description: The William Carter Company, a maker of infant and children's clothing, said yesterday that it had selected Tucker Wayne/Luckie & Company in Atlanta to handle its account. The decision followed a review that involved seven other agencies, including Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson in Boston, which was Carter's agency before the clothing company changed ownershop. Frederick J. Rowan 2d, president and chief executive at Carter in Morrow, Ga., said the company planned to spend $4 million on advertising this year, compared with $1 million last year.

title: King Comes Out From His Limbo
description: Twelve days after being released by the Washington Bullets, Bernard King remains a scoring forward in search of a team. A league source said today that King has sent a telex to every team in the National Basketball Association, with the obvious exception of the Bullets, volunteering his services.

title: Corrections
description: Thomas More's map of Utopia, which illustrated the Jan. 25 Editorial Notebook "After 1492: A Utopian Encounter," was most recently exhibited at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum and not, as stated, at the Pierpont Morgan Library, which owns the map.

title: ISRAEL TO RETURN 100 PALESTINIANS IT HAD DEPORTED
description: Yielding to international pressure and convinced that its relations with the Clinton Administration are at stake, Israel agreed Monday night to send home immediately about 100 of the Palestinians it had deported to Lebanon and to cut the exile period for the remaining 300 in half, to a year.

title: Delta Queen Steamboat (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Pro forma as if the 4.1 million common shares issued in March 1992 had been issued on April 1, 1991 and including interest savings from retirement of debt which resulted from the offering.c-Net loss

title: Man in the News; Theologian as Educator: George Erik Rupp
description: George Rupp has always seemed to be a man in a hurry. When he was a teen-ager, he collaborated with three others to build houses in New Jersey. The four of them could frame a house in two weeks.

title: Market Place; Some say 'not in my backyard' while others see opportunity
description: IF Hollywood remade "The Graduate" today, the advice whispered into the ear of the young man starting out his career might not be "plastics" but "nuclear waste."

title: Books of The Times; A Year in an Inspired Black Church in Brooklyn
description: Upon This Rock The Miracles of a Black Church By Samuel Freedman HarperCollins. 373 pages. $22.50.

title: Rackets Trial for Gambino Brothers Opens
description: Two brothers, John and Joseph Gambino, were portrayed by the prosecution at the opening of their racketeering trial yesterday as the main distributors of heroin smuggled into the United States by the Sicilian Mafia.

title: Deepest Wrecks Now Visible to Undersea Cameras
description: THE inky depths of the oceans are fast becoming transparent to all kinds of professional eyes, opening a new world of discovery as wrecks ancient and modern come to light for the first time.

title: Advertising
description: FOR all the blather about the Super Bowl being football -- and advertising -- at their finest, one might have looked to the baseball philosopher Yogi Berra to best characterize the commercials broadcast during Super Bowl XXVII: it was deja vu all over again, again.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOSEPH A. CALIFANO JR., the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, gave up a lucrative private law practice in Manhattan last year to serve as president and chairman of the Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, a new nonprofit organization that he hopes will offer the nation's first comprehensive examination of the huge and tragic costs of addiction among young people.

title: Review/Pop; New Guises for Old Sex Roles In a Quadruple Bill of Hip-Hop
description: Midway through Bobby Brown's set on Sunday night at Madison Square Garden, a bed ascended on an elevator. Mr. Brown was on it, face down and fully clothed, atop a woman in a leotard whose high heels waved in the air; then they rolled over so the woman could writhe astride the singer. It was only one of the bump-and-grinds in a quadruple-bill concert devoted to come-ons and boasts of prowess. The aptly titled "Humpin' Around the World" tour includes Mr. Brown, the Jamaican dancehall rapper Shabba Ranks, the three-woman pop hip-hop group T.L.C. and the singer Mary J. Blige.

title: Arrow Automotive Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 60,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 400,000, or 14 cents a share, in the 6 months, and the 6 months also included credit for termination of supplemental benefit arrangements for $ 1,104,000, or 40 cents a share.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: Acknowledging that it faces monumental expenses during the next 20 years for retiree health-care benefits, the General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it was taking a $20.8 billion after-tax charge against 1992 earnings. The accounting adjustment means that G.M. will post a net loss of about $23.5 billion for 1992, far exceeding the American corporate record loss of $4.97 billion that I.B.M. set just last week.

title: ALLIED-SIGNAL AND CHRYSLER WIN AIR FORCE CONTRACT
description: Allied-Signal Inc. and the Chrysler Corporation said they had won a contract worth up to $300 million over seven years to supply modern cockpit instruments for two of the Air Force's older cargo planes. Under an initial 18-month contract, the Air Force will spend $44 million to put modern autopilots and instruments in more than 800 of its C-130's and C-141's.

title: Aikman's Star Vehicle in Fast Lane
description: Troy Aikman, urban Cowboy, is about to be marketed like soda pop. He is 26, has blond hair, sky-blue eyes and lizard-skin boots for every day of the week. He knows Garth Brooks's phone number, is reading Al Gore's book and can type 80 words a minute.

title: Review/Music; A High-Energy Pianist Who Teaches as He Plays
description: One can rhapsodize about the fluidity of Richard Goode's technique or the combination of overt emotional drama and overarching, deeply reasoned philosophy that he brings to the music he performs. The bottom line, though, is that it is virtually impossible to walk away from one of Mr. Goode's recitals without the sense of having gained some new insight, subtle or otherwise, into the works he played or about pianism itself.

title: E.P.A. Plans to Seek Loosening of a Law On Food Pesticides
description: Faced with a court order to ban many important farm chemicals, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that she would ask Congress to relax a law prohibiting trace amounts of cancer-causing chemicals in food.

title: PRESIDENT ALLOWS STATES FLEXIBILITY ON MEDICAID FUNDS
description: President Clinton today ordered the Federal Government to make it easier for states to use Medicaid funds to introduce new health-care programs for the poor. His goal is to add much greater flexibility to a health-care system often constrained by Federal regulations.

title: Wannstedt Going, His Defense Staying
description: The four-year association of Dave Wannstedt and the Dallas Cowboys ended today, but the legacy and the aggressive defense that helped lift the Cowboys to a Super Bowl victory will live on.

title: Cadence Design Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and included charges of $ 51.6 million related to Cadence Design's merger with Valid Logic Systems Inc. in both the quarter and year.Year-ago results are restated in recognition of the effects of SOP 91-1 which deals with Software Revenue recognition for post-contract support services.

title: Governors Praise Ex-Colleague in the White House
description: President Clinton spent 12 years building good will with the nation's governors, and today they went to work to pay him back.

title: The Toughest of Ties, With Nothing but Winners
description: If the National Hockey League wants to start expanding its audience, it could use tonight's game, a 4-4 tie between the Islanders and the Rangers, as a selling point.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Isabella Lippi Violinist 92d Street Y

title: Even the Commercials Looked Familiar
description: When it came to the commercials shown during Super Bowl XXVII, originality was as scarce as applause during Michael Jackson's bombastic halftime show. Too many of the expensive spots were derivative, rehashing creative approaches from other commercials or borrowing too ardently from pop-culture sources like music videos. Here are some of the most notable deja vu spots. Budweiser beers, Bud Bowl V D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Bud Bowls I, II, III, IV, Influences: Bud Bowls I, II, III and IV, previous Budweiser spots, "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" Crystal Pepsi BBDO Worldwide Influences: "Right Now," Van Halen music video Master Lock Cramer-Krasselt Influences: "Cops" and other "reality" programs Nike Wieden & Kennedy Influences: Nike's 1992 Super Bowl spot, Warner Brothers cartoons Pepsi-Cola BBDO Worldwide Influences: Burger King campaign and Energizer Bunny campaigns, previous Pepsi spots, TV Guide spots mocking TV programs

title: Video Games Can Serve to Diagnose Epilepsy
description: To the Editor:

title: Labor Agreement Will Haunt New York City
description: To the Editor

title: The President and America's Children
description: With a dramatic proposal that champions America's youngest, most vulnerable citizens, the Clinton Administration would re-establish values lost during 12 years in which "getting the Government off people's backs" really meant cutting social services till it hurt.

title: Brush Wellman reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary restructuring charge of $ 30,751,000 in both the quarter and year, and the year also included a charge of $ 16,471,000 for adoption of SFAS 106, ''Employers Accounting for Benefits Other than Pensions.''

title: Knicks' Slumping Smith Hits Double Figures in Frustration
description: One of Charles Smith's unlaced Reebok Pumps was nearly out the door and into the bitter wind this afternoon when his presence was requested for a press grilling inside the Knicks' practice gym. Though it was much warmer indoors, Smith did manage to keep his cool.

title: Neal Steinman, 50, Public Finance Expert
description: Neal Steinman, a lawyer and expert in public finance, died on Thursday in a Philadelphia hospital. He was 50 and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Rice University President Picked To Succeed Sovern at Columbia
description: Reaching far outside their Morningside Heights campus for someone they hope will guide Columbia University securely into the 21st century, the university's trustees yesterday named George E. Rupp, an ordained Presbyterian minister who is president of Rice University in Houston, the 18th president of Columbia.

title: Rare Rose Not So Singular as Once Thought
description: IN what botanists hail as a surprise discovery, a member of the rose family long thought to be a single rare species has been found to have a living relative.

title: Dallas Journal; Big Victory In Football Encourages Wider Hope
description: The venerable, fedora-topped Tom Landry was revered as the coach of America's Team, as the Dallas Cowboys were called in the 1970's. But what about Jimmy Johnson, his helmet-haired, ice-water-in-the-veins successor?

title: Teen-Ager Shot to Death At a School
description: One teen-ager was shot to death and another wounded by a third youth after an argument on the grounds of Amityville High School this afternoon, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Touring Windows, Inside and Out
description: FOR getting a technician's-eye view of a Windows-based computer, Winsleuth Gold is indispensable. This utility, now in its third incarnation, analyzes, diagnoses and teaches about the machine in unrelenting detail.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart on Sunday about homicide arrests in the United States, by suspects' age group, reversed two labels. The highest levels of arrest were for suspects 18 to 24 years old; the next highest were for those 14 to 17.

title: Avoid Arbitrator, Hold On to Salary
description: Mike Schooler and Walt Weiss avoided salary arbitration hearings and escaped pay cuts yesterday, but Schooler had to settle for the same salary he made last year.

title: Delmarva Power & Light Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 12,730,000, or 25 cents a share, from change in accounting for unbilled revenues.Fiscal 1992 income from continuing operations of $ 98,526,000, or $ 1.69 a share, included a gain of 21 cents a share from the settlement of the Peach Bottom lawsuit with Philadelphia Electric Co.

title: Julia Davis Adams, 92, West Virginia Writer
description: Julia Davis Adams, a writer, died Saturday at Jefferson Memorial Hospital in Ranson, W. Va. She lived in Charles Town, W. Va., and was 92.

title: 2 Partners Join Owner Of Lutece
description: Andre Soltner, the renowned chef and owner of one of the country's most esteemed French restaurants, Lutece, has taken the first tentative step toward retirement by bringing two partners into his family business.

title: BEI Electronics Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Fire Damages Park Avenue Office Building
description: Park Avenue Office Is Damaged by Fire

title: Anadarko Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
METROPOLITAN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Fordham

title: Altron Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
COMPANY NEWS
description: BOC HEALTH CARE INC., Murray Hill, N.J., has bought the rights in North America and Europe to Brevibloc, a beta blocker, for $72.5 million from the Du Pont Merck Pharmaceutical Co. FLIGHTSAFETY INTERNATIONAL INC., New York, has completed the acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s visual simulator business in St. Charles, Mo. Terms were not disclosed.

title:
Political Tides, Haitian Waves;
An Exodus Was Risky
description: Bill Clinton was right to reverse his position on Haitian migrants. A mass exodus would have solved none of Haiti's problems and might have proved disastrous. Candidate Clinton condemned the Bush Administration for a "cruel policy of returning Haitian refugees to a brutal dictatorship without an asylum hearing," and promised to give them "temporary asylum until we restored the elected Government." The Haitians construed this promise to mean Bill Clinton would admit them all. In making it, he evidently underestimated Haiti's economic and political desperation and the mass migrations it has produced for decades.

title: Police Pull Abandoned Infant From a Trash Bin
description: Two police officers found a nearly naked baby boy, badly beaten, not breathing and abandoned at the bottom of a trash bin near Newark's Penn Station last night -- the coldest of the winter -- and brought him to a nearby hospital, where officials said he had a good chance of surviving.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on "The New Neediest," published last Nov. 29, could be read to convey an erroneous impression that The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is a major supporter of SafeSpace, a haven for homeless youths on West 46th Street in Manhattan. The fund provides no money directly to SafeSpace. Rather, it provides support to the Community Service Society of New York, which in turn has supported 3 of the 65 volunteers who work with the teen-agers at SafeSpace.

title: Bracknell Corp. reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: The company said its share earnings, ''restated to normalize tax,'' were 48 cents a share versus 42 cents a share.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: J. Thompson Ruger, Firearms Executive, 48
description: J. Thompson Ruger, an executive of Sturm, Ruger & Company, a manufacturer of firearms, died on Sunday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 48 and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: For Clark in the 800, An Unspeakable Rival
description: Joetta Clark, the five-time and defending champion in the 800 meters at the Millrose Games, will not say the name. In her speeches, even in her private conversations, her deeply resented rival, Maria Mutola of Mozambique, is simply "that individual" or "that person."

title: Soak the Rich, Not the Elderly
description: The Clinton Administration has hit the ground with a couple of pardonable stumbles, but in considering a freeze on cost-of-living adjustments for Social Security recipients it appears headed for a serious fall.

title: Ex-Im Bank Chief Picked
description: President Clinton today nominated Kenneth D. Brody, an investment banker and limited partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company, to become the chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States.

title: Q&A
description: L-Sugars, D-Sugars

title: C.I.A. Error Still Bloats Our Military Budget; Costs vs. Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Environmental Elements reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain from disposal of discontinued operations of $ 148,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 520,000, or 7 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $ 149,000, or 2 cents a share, and $ 586,000, or 8 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Computer Products (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 465,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 674,000, or 3 cents a share, in the year.c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 5,226,000 and $ 5,495,000 in the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary tax credit of $ 47,000 in the quarter and $ 91,000 in the year.Fiscal 1991 loss from continuing operations of $ 4,234,000 included a restructuring charge of $ 6.3 million.

title: Cominco Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a provision of $ 50,000,000 before tax for lead smelter modification in both the quarter and year, and a loss of $ 4.1 million in the quarter and a gain of $ 73.6 million in the year, both before tax from the sale of investments and ''other.''c-Included gains of $ 2.6 million and $ 15.4 million, in the quarter and year, respectively, before tax from the sale of investments and other.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Treasury Prices Shrug Off Report
description: Treasury prices were little changed yesterday, holding up well in the face of another report showing that the economy may be moving spritely into the new year.

title: Judge Delays Move to 'Uncluster' White Pupils at Richmond School
description: After being ordered by the Richmond schools superintendent to redistribute white pupils among predominantly black classrooms starting today, the principal of Bellevue Model Elementary School received a court order this afternoon to halt the reassignments until a hearing on Wednesday.

title: Central Maine Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Avemco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said included in the latest quarter it had after-tax realized investment gains of $ 101,000, compared with $ 717,000, or 6 cents a share, of after-tax realized investment gains in the year-ago quarter. For the latest year there were after-tax realized investment gains of $ 1.8 million, compared with $ 4.5 million, or 39 cents a share, in after-tax realized investment gains in 1991.

title: H. H. Beverage, 99, Research Scientist And Radio Engineer
description: Harold Henry Beverage, a radio engineer and RCA scientist whose research advanced communications technology, died on Wednesday at the John T. Mather Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 99 and lived in Stony Brook.

title: Boole & Babbage Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONAGRA ACQUIRES NATIONAL FOODS
description: Conagra Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired National Foods Inc., the New York-based maker of Hebrew National kosher franks and other kosher foods, and its affiliate, the Hanau Meat Company, for an undisclosed amount of stock. Conagra said the transaction would be accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: On My Mind; Needed: U.S. Goal In Bosnia
description: The United Nations Security Council will be meeting in New York to talk about Bosnia. It should be meeting in Sarajevo.

title: General Datacom Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hope Left Behind in Somalia By Disillusioned U.S. Marines
description: If there was an unspoken vision shared by the American military men and women who began arriving here in December, it was probably this: nursing a starving Somali child back to health under a grateful mother's gaze. But as nearly 500 United States marines climbed aboard their flight out today after a month dodging snipers and stones, hope had given way to disillusion.

title: Observer; Sarsa-Pa-What?
description: Washington is tough. Washington reporters who infest the weekend TV gab shows kept saying it. "A tough town." You could sense their pride in that toughness. That tough town was their town, they had flourished in it, which showed they were tough too: a tough crowd who had risen to the top in a tough town.

title: TV Notes; 2 Mormon Stations Drop 'Picket Fences'
description: Two CBS affiliates have told the network they will no longer broadcast the Friday-night drama "Picket Fences" because of objections to the show's content.

title: American Express Defends Past and Looks to Future
description: The new era at American Express got off to a halting start yesterday, with the new chairman more intent on defending his earlier recommendation to keep James D. Robinson 3d as chairman than on explaining his ideas for turning the company around.

title: White House Memo; President's Early Troubles Rooted in Party's Old Strains
description: When Bill Clinton was a candidate, his electoral promise was that he could straddle the gulf between populism and elitism, between the concerns of the middle classes that provide the Democratic Party's electoral muscle and those of the more liberal academic theorists who provide its ideology.

title: Croatian Is Unjustly Called Anti-Semitic
description: To the Editor:

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
West Point-Pepperell Names New President
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc. today named a new president and chief operating officer, who said his goal was to stabilize the textile company, which had been buffeted by a hostile takeover attempt.

title: Executive Changes
description: DOMINO'S PIZZA INC., Ann Arbor, Mich., named Lawrence Gordon chief operating officer.

title: Lindros Gets Set
description: ERIC LINDROS will practice full-scale with the Philadelphia Flyers today, the first time he will have done so since he reinjured his left knee. Lindros skated Sunday and yesterday at the team's rink in Voorhees, N.J. But he will miss tomorrow night's game against the Rangers at Madison Square Garden, Coach BILL DINEEN said.

title: Police Officer Suspended
description: A New York City police officer was suspended from duty Sunday night because he was unavailable for questioning about a complaint that he had raped a former girlfriend, the police said. The officer, Dwight A. Nicholas, is alleged by the woman to have raped her at gunpoint Saturday night while he was off-duty, said Suzanne Trazoff, a police spokeswoman. Mr. Nicholas, who is assigned to the 32d Precinct in Harlem, is being sought for questioning, and was suspended when detectives from the department's Internal Affairs Bureau could not locate him Sunday for questioning, the police said.

title: Shortages in Moscow? Not of Science Papers
description: MOSCOW may be experiencing shortages of consumer goods and other items, but it is producing more scientific papers than any other city in the world, according to the Institute for Scientific Information.

title: Imcera Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,300,000 and $ 1,500,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and both included litigation and benefit-related costs for previously discontinued operations and costs of disposal of the balance of Imcera's investment in IMC Fertilizer Group.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 200,000 and $ 2,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and both included litigation and benefit-related costs for previously discontinued operations and costs of disposal of the balance of Imcera's investment in IMC Fertilizer.Sales for the year-ago quarter and 6 months reflected combination into joint venture of the Fries & Fries unit of Mallinckrodt Specialty Chemicals and Hercules Inc. flavors businesses. Results subsequent to the formation of the venture were recorded on a pretax equity basis. Related income taxes were included in Imcera's consolidated income tax provision.Latest 6 months' income from continuing operations of $ 56,700,000, or 73 cents a share, included an after-tax charge of $ 3.4 million from executive resignations at Pitman-Moore.Year-ago 6 months' income from continuing operations of $ 53,400,000, or 68 cents a share, included after-tax gain of $ 4.4 million, or 5 cents a share, from sale of an investment.

title: Bundesbank Chief Holds The Line on Rate Policy
description: The head of Germany's central bank defended the institution's tight-money policies here tonight, and he seemed to indicate that the Bundesbank was not ready to lower interest rates to ease the pressure on Europe's battered monetary system.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 ISRAEL BENDS ON DEPORTEES

title: By Design; The Long-Skirt Affair
description: Last fall, anyone with an ounce of fashion had to have a long skirt. But visitors in Paris last week for the spring couture shows were struck by the lack of long skirts both on and off the runways. No sightings were reported of chic young Parisians bustling along the boulevards wearing anything other than above-the-knee lengths. And two couturiers, Gianni Versace and Yves Saint Laurent, made a point of including mid-thigh styles in their respective collections. New York store executives checking out the cheap-chic section of the Paris ready-to-wear district found only the shortest skirts for sale.

title: Get Ready, Get Set, File!
description: TODAY is Groundhog Day, but it is also the unofficial start of income tax preparation season. The final versions of the major 1992 Federal income tax preparation programs have arrived in the stores. (If the groundhog emerges from his burrow today and sees the shadow of an Internal Revenue Service agent, winter will last until April 15.)

title: Dolphins' Humphrey Arrested for Drugs
description: Miami Dolphins running back BOBBY HUMPHREY was free on bond yesterday after being charged with possession of cocaine and aggravated assault. But after his arrest, police sought to re-arrest him for giving a false identity.

title: Bills' Levy Not Ready To Throw In Towel
description: It was a fitful night for Bills Coach Marv Levy.

title: Miscellany
description: * Lenore Cooney, formerly president and chief operating officer at Ogilvy, Adams & Rinehart, New York, and Beth Waters, formerly senior managing director and head of the health-care practice there, opened the Cooney/Waters Group, New York, specializing in public relations for health-care and pharmaceutical clients.

title: In a Surprise, Oldsmobile Retains Burnett
description: The Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would retain Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago as the agency for its estimated $140 million account

title: In a Memoir Criticizing Bush, Shultz's Timing Is Questioned
description: George P. Shultz's assertions in a forthcoming book that George Bush carefully sought to blur his role in the Reagan Administration's arm-for-hostages deals with Iran provide the most authoritative challenge yet to the former President's account that his knowledge of the arms-for-hostages deals was hazy and incomplete.

title: Chaus Hires Ex-President Of Esprit
description: Richard Baker, who left the post of president of Esprit de Corp Womenswear in November, yesterday was named president of Bernard Chaus Inc., the women's clothing manufacturer based in New York.

title: Fast and Posh, X-2000 Train Picks Up Fans
description: Ian Campbell boarded the train at Washington's Union Station after arguing a copyright case before the Federal Court of Appeals and pronounced his surroundings "very plush, very good for working and relaxing."

title: Sliding Value
description: Shares of Glaxo Holdings Plc, a British holding company for pharmaceutical manufacturers, are down xxx percent since the November presidential election. There investor worries that U.S. health reforms by the new Clinton Administration will affect U.K. drug companies. Since Glaxo derives 40 percent of its sales from the U.S. market the concern took the stock to a new 52-week trading low of 19 yesterday.

title: Dell Computer Reports on S.E.C. Inquiry
description: The Dell Computer Corporation said today that foreign-exchange trading activities during the last 23 months would have produced a net gain of $1 million if the transactions had been listed each quarter at current market values.

title: 3 Top Editors and Columnist Leave Post for Daily News
description: At least three top editors and the columnist Mike McAlary left The New York Post yesterday to work for The Daily News amid growing anger toward the man who aspires to be The Post's next owner.

title: One Down, One to Go for A.P. Indy in Eclipses
description: A.P. Indy, the horse who was scratched from the Kentucky Derby on the morning of the race last May, carried his comeback to new peaks yesterday when he won the Eclipse Award as the best 3-year-old colt in North America. And he is considered an almost sure bet to crown his career Friday by winning the ultimate award as Horse of the Year.

title: HBO & Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 4,000 in the quarter and $ 544,000 in the year, and the year also included a pre-tax charge of $ 10,883,000.

title: Japanese Company Is Sued By I.B.M. Over Copyrights
description: I.B.M. filed a $150 million lawsuit today against the Kyocera Corporation, accusing the Japanese company of infringing copyrights on basic software used in personal computers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the budget for American intelligence organizations referred incorrectly to the military background of R. James Woolsey, President Clinton's nominee for Director of Central Intelligence. Mr. Woolsey, a former Army lieutenant, was Under Secretary of the Navy; he is not a retired admiral.

title: A & W Brands (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shares outstanding are pre-split figures. As reported, a 3-for-2 stock split will take effect Feb. 16 for shareholders of record Feb. 1. Post-split income for the fourth quarter 1992 would have been 33 cents a share compared with 32 cents for the year ago, and income for 1992 would have been $ 1.11 compared with $ 1.02 for 1991.A&W Brands said its fourth-quarter results included the costs of introducing the company's Tetley and Everlast brands.

title: Clinton Trade Policy: So Far, Little Is New
description: During last year's election campaign, Bush Administration trade officials fretted over what they saw as Bill Clinton's protectionist oratory, and in Mr. Clinton's first two weeks as President there have been a flurry of trade decisions, including the imposition of steep tariffs on steel imports.

title: Corrections
description: The $25 and Under column in Weekend on Jan. 22 referred incorrectly to the owners of the restaurant Lanza in the East Village. They are Anthony Macagnone and his sons, Anthony Jr. and William.

title: Medieval French Music
description: Les Entreprises Occitanes, a group dedicated to performing the music of southern France from medieval to modern times, will present a program called "Troubadours" on Feb. 28 at 8 P.M. and March 1 at 2 P.M. at the Town School, 540 East 76th Street in Manhattan. The program is a dramatic presentation of original 12th- and 13th-century French songs, translated and adapted by the ensemble's director, Susan Melvoin. The musical direction is by Suzy Schwartz. Admission is free, but donations are suggested. Information: (212) 222-0803.

title: Checkpoint Systems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Upjohn's Chief Getting Treatments for Cancer
description: The Upjohn Company said yesterday that Dr. Theodore Cooper, a physician and scientist who has headed the diversified health-care company since 1987, has been undergoing treatment for bone marrow cancer.

title: INSIDE
description: Strong Showing by Factories

title: Prosecutor Questioned in Glen Ridge Case
description: Defense lawyers in the Glen Ridge sex assault trial turned the second-highest official in the Essex County Prosecutor's office into their own witness today in an effort to impugn the testimony of a police detective in the case.

title: Cincinnati Survives An Ambush
description: Cincinnati 74, Miami of Ohio 68

title: Moving On With a Fond Look Back
description: THIS morning, I awaken to read my final column before moving on to a different career in a different place. As the noted philosopher Gonzo of the Muppets put it: "I want to go there. I just don't want to leave here."

title: C.I.A. Error Still Bloats Our Military Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon's Chief to Retire
description: Lawrence G. Rawl will retire this year as chairman and chief executive of the Exxon Corporation, the largest oil company in the United States, according to a proxy statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Rawl, who has guided the company since 1987, will reach Exxon's mandatory retirement age of 65 in May. Members of the nominating committee of Exxon's board could not be reached for comment on a possible successor. Mr. Rawl has worked at the company for 41 years.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Pamela Frankand Ignat Solzhenitsyn Violinist and Pianist The New School Pamela Frank, a violinist, and Ignat Solzhenitsyn, a pianist, played a fairly heady program on Sunday afternoon. In it, modernists of different stripes (Prokofiev and Webern) were surrounded by Romantics (Dvorak and Strauss). More striking than the program itself, though, was that Ms. Frank and Mr. Solzhenitsyn played it as collaborators rather than as soloist and accompanist.

title: Morgan Fund To Invest In Banks
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, combining its tradition of bailing out troubled banks with its desire to become an aggressive investment firm, said yesterday that it had raised $1 billion for a fund to invest in commercial banks worldwide.

title: Aur Resources reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Buffalo Should Do Itself a Favor and Copy Dallas
description: The view from the top is a mighty pretty sight for the Dallas Cowboys. For the Buffalo Bills, peering up from the bottom of the barrel, there is emptiness. There is darkness.

title: Grace H. Mack, 91, A Horticulturalist
description: Grace Hayward Mack, a horticulturalist known for her work in hybridizing chrysanthemums, died on Friday at her home in New Canaan, Conn. She was 91 years old.

title: Transactions
description: Football National Football League

title: Purchasing Managers Find Economy Is Gaining Ground
description: American manufacturers virtually roared into 1993, according to a report yesterday that was the first solid data on the economy's momentum so far this year.

title: What's Next? Try Bo the Bionic Man
description: From Birmingham, Ala., to Kansas City, to Chicago, it has always been different, this thing called the Bo Show. And now more than ever, the saga of Bo Jackson is more discomfiting and compelling.

title: Chess
description: Nigel Short has won the right to battle Gary Kasparov for the world title. By winning Game 12 on Thursday and making a draw in Game 13 on Saturday, the 28-year-old English grandmaster defeated the 41-year-old Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman in their final match for world championship candidates in San Lorenzo de El Escorial, Spain.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Chamber Music Society

title: Review/Television; The Easing of America's War on Drugs
description: On land, on sea, in the air, the United States is losing the fight to keep cocaine out of the country. That is the message of "What Happened to the Drug War?," tonight's in-the-field expose of high-tech, high-priced, high-hyped weapons that seem to have flopped.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Yale Music Spectrum Merkin Concert Hall

title: Ameron reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included about 62 cents a share of additional income due to the net difference between a pretax gain from the sale of the company's corporate headquarters facility, and offset by a charge of writedowns and repositioning costs in the quarter, and year included a pretax gain of $ 15.1 million from the sale of the company's corporate headquarters facility and a charge of $ 14.5 million for asset writedowns and repositioning costs related to a restructuring program. The net result was a gain of about 10 cents a share.

title: Their Lives Consumed, Officers Await 2d Trial
description: Three little girls were playing tag in the living room, a small white dog was barking happily and Sgt. Stacey C. Koon, who goes on trial on Wednesday in the country's most celebrated police-brutality case, was rolling around on the rug, demonstrating the actions of the man who was beaten, Rodney G. King.

title: Colombian Bombings Called Retaliation Against Escobar
description: A group calling itself "Persecuted by Pablo Escobar" said today that it set off three bombs around Medellin on Sunday in retaliation for a car-bombing that killed 21 people in Bogota.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Media Business page of Business Day yesterday with an article about staff reductions at The Los Angeles Times carried incorrect dates in some copies for quarterly operating income of the newspaper group of the parent company, Times Mirror. A corrected chart appears today on page D20.

title: Income-Tax Showdown Is Looming for Weicker and Legislature
description: The Legislature's tax-writing committee today approved a plan to cut state income taxes by as much as several hundred dollars a year for the majority of Connecticut residents while making up the difference with a rate increase for the 10 percent of families with the highest incomes.

title: Opening Day for N.H.L.'s First Commissioner
description: The first week of the shortest month of the year offers professional hockey a rare share of the American sports spotlight. Football is finally finished, and the baseball players won't report for spring training for another couple of weeks. The sports news media poke their collective heads above ground, see Charles Barkley's shadow and realize there are six more weeks of college basketball until the Final Four.

title: Sect in India Guards Desert Wildlife
description: In one of the world's most successful and oldest conservation efforts, a tough desert-dwelling Hindu sect has protected wildlife and vegetation from hunters and loggers for hundreds of years along the Great Indian Desert.

title: PRUDENTIAL IS CURBING POLICIES IN FLORIDA
description: The Prudential Property and Casualty Insurance Company will cease writing new homeowner policies in Florida for at least a year and a half as part of an effort to reduce its number of Florida customers by a third.

title: Overnight TV Rating Higher
description: NBC's telecast of Super Bowl XXVII produced a 43.9 Nielsen rating with a 65 share in preliminary results from 28 overnight markets, an 8.6 percent increase over the 40.4 rating in 25 markets for last year's game on CBS. One rating point in the overnights equals 462,634 television households. A share is the percentage of televisions in use.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The inaugural extravaganzas of two weeks ago would appear to be a hard act to follow in Washington. But 25 years as a resident theater is a long run in any town, and the city's political, corporate and social luminaries plan to turn out tonight at the Washington Hilton to honor FRANKIE HEWITT, the founding producer and director of Ford's Theater.

title: A.F.C. Teams, Try Not to Fret: It's Just the N.F.C.'s Time to Reign
description: Is it just one of those things, a sort of statistical anomaly in which for nine straight years a National Footbal Conference team has won the Super Bowl?

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the benefits listing of Styles of The Times on Sunday about a concert to be held on Friday at Carnegie Hall to benefit the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia misstated the area code for tickets by telephone. The number is (215) 893-5279.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Proof that STEPHEN SONDHEIM and JULIE ANDREWS are living Broadway legends was clearly evident early yesterday when about 700 of their fans braved wind-chills below zero. They began lining up shortly after midnight at the City Center Theater to purchase 1,500 tickets for Mr. Sondheim's new musical revue, "Putting It Together."

title: Vision Care for Children Offered by Neediest Cases
description: Luis Gonzalez is 5 years old, so he is particularly concerned these days with dump trucks and fire engines. When his mother took him to an optometrist in Harlem the other day, Luis jumped at the chance to race his toys through the office. He did not quite grasp how important the appointment was to his future.

title: Dr. Diana B. Clark, 56, Educator And Authority on Dyslexia, Dies
description: Diana Brewster Clark, an educator and an authority on dyslexia, died at her home in Manhattan on Sunday. She was 56.

title: Suspension Is Expected For Schott
description: The major league executive council is scheduled to meet in Chicago tomorrow to complete its deliberation on Marge Schott and take action that is virtually certain to result in baseball's next court case.

title: ChipSoft Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Port-au-Prince Journal; In Hiding in Haiti, Dissident Despairs of U.S. Help
description: More than four months after his imprisonment and repeated beatings by soldiers in Dame-Marie, a tiny town at the end of Haiti's southern peninsula, Ferleau says his ears still run sometimes with the cloudy liquid that began oozing from them once the bleeding stopped.

title: In a Nod to U.S., China Plans to Free 2 Dissidents
description: The Government said today that it was releasing two prominent political prisoners before the completion of their sentences. The move was apparently a gesture to Washington and a signal that Beijing may be testing the waters for a broader amnesty.

title: Hillary Clinton's New Home: Broccoli's In, Smoking's Out
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton says she and President Clinton hope to open the White House to all Americans. But they won't let them smoke.

title: Seeking More Work From City Workers
