title: Mentally Ill Man Who Abused Drugs Is Freed
description: For the second time in three days, a judge in New York City yesterday ordered a mentally ill homeless man with a history of substance abuse and repeated arrests freed from a mental hospital.

title: Earl J. McGrath, Education Chief Under 2 Presidents, Dies at 90
description: Earl James McGrath, a Commissioner of Education under two Presidents, died on Jan. 14 in Tucson, Ariz. He was 90.

title: CHRONICLE
description: They were often a formidable team in the international political arena, so despite the fact that they're now both out of office, there's no reason to expect that RONALD REAGAN and MARGARET THATCHER will stop attending one another's parties.

title: Cray Computer Seeks Investors as Losses Rise
description: Struggling with losses and looking for investors, the legendary supercomputer designer Seymour Cray is beginning to lift the veil of secrecy that has surrounded his efforts to build the world's fastest computer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: IMPERIAL CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES P.L.C., said it was negotiating to sell its powder coatings unit in Europe and North America, which generates about $100 million in annual income, to the Ferro Corporation of Cleveland. MOBIL CORP., Fairfax, Va., announced that capital and exploration expenditures in 1993 would probably be unchanged from the 1992 level of $4.4 billion. PROCTER & GAMBLE CO., has bought about 40 acres in Warsaw for a plant to make Pampers diapers for distribution throughout Central and Eastern Europe. The company said it would invest $50 million to $60 million to acquire the site, develop it and install manufacturing lines. UNITED AIR LINES, Chicago, said it would offer 10 percent discounts on excursion fares to people 62 and older and one traveling companion.

title: National Study Finds Insurance Industry Bias
description: A nonprofit community development group says that it has found evidence in a national study that homeowners in inner-city neighborhoods are severely underinsured and that it is harder for poor members of minorities to buy insurance than it is for poor whites.

title: Ingalls, Quinn Loses Big Account
description: Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson in Boston announced the loss of a large account yesterday and high-level management changes.

title: Lincoln Telecomm (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Criticism Of N.A.S.D.
description: By failing to vigorously monitor the sales practices of penny stockbrokers, the National Association of Securities Dealers has allowed "unscrupulous broker-dealers, who use fraudulent and abusive practices in dealing with the public, to go unchecked," the General Accounting Office said in a report released yesterday.

title: ILC Technology (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Germans' Apprentice System Supports Economic Vitality
description: When Michel Sorgatz finished school last year, he did not have to read classified ads to find a job in his chosen field. Instead he entered an apprentice program at one of Germany's largest companies that will teach him a profession and virtually guarantee him a job.

title: Valenzuela Redux
description: FERNANDO VALENZUELA was happy with his first outing in more than two weeks yesterday as he helped pitch the Mazatlan (Mexico) Deer to victory in their first game of the Caribbean Baseball Series in Mazatlan.

title: Marian W. Freedman, Civic Leader, 86
description: Marian W. Freedman, a civic leader in central New Jersey, died on Tuesday at the Applewood Estates retirement community in Freehold Township. A resident of Freehold, she was 86.

title: Banyan Systems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Judge's Hiring of Illegal Alien in 80's Did Not Violate Immigration Law
description: Judge Kimba M. Wood was right when she said tonight that she violated no law in hiring an illegal immigrant to work as her baby sitter in March 1986.

title: Corrections
description: The "On Stage, and Off" column in Weekend on Jan. 29 misidentified a producer of the play "Jeffrey" at the WPA Theater in Manhattan. He is Richard Frankel.

title: Union Prepares For Long Strike At Coal Mines
description: Along the mountainous roads that wind through southern West Virginia's coal fields, miners in camouflage strike gear built shacks of weathered wood panels at a half-dozen mine entrances here today in grim anticipation of a long strike against the nation's largest coal producer.

title: One Mean Substitute
description: HOWIE LONG of the Los Angeles Raiders was added to the American Football Conference Pro Bowl team for Sunday's game in Honolulu, replacing BRUCE SMITH of the Buffalo Bills at defensive end.

title: Now, a Coach. Next, a Running Game.
description: The Jets, under a mandate by General Manager Dick Steinberg to revive the ground game and lessen the pressure on quarterback Browning Nagle, hired Johnny Roland yesterday as the running backs coach.

title: For Stock Newsletters, Crash Is Finally History
description: SOME investment newsletter writers got a big break this week when, just by the passage of time, their abysmal 1987 stock market crash performances were erased from their important five-year track records.

title: Letterman Says on Air: No Decision on Moving
description: In an early segment of his television show last night, David Letterman denied a newspaper report that he planned to move the show to Los Angeles from New York City in the summer.

title: Review/Dance; The Diverse Jazz Idiom, With Unifying Elements
description: No wonder jazz dance is diverse. It has been influenced by tap, ballroom dancing, vaudeville, modern dance, musical comedy and the riches of black culture and history. The sheer variety of this dance form was celebrated on Sunday afternoon in "Jazz Music in Motion" at the Evolving Arts Theater at Dance Space Inc.

title: JUDGE WITHDRAWS FROM CLINTON LIST FOR JUSTICE POST
description: Judge Kimba M. Wood withdrew today from consideration for Attorney General after the White House learned she had employed an illegal immigrant as a baby sitter before it became illegal to do so.

title: Q & A
description: Kinds of Coins

title: 200 Somali Youths Stone American Troops
description: More than 200 youths hurled stones at United States troops and burned tires at the Mogadishu port today after a rumor spread that marines had shot and killed six Somalis. Military spokesmen said there had been no gunfire from American forces.

title: Israel Lists Arabs Who May, but Don't, Return
description: Israel today released a list of 101 deported Palestinians in southern Lebanon who it says may return immediately to Israeli-occupied territories as part of an agreement that it reached this week with the Clinton Administration.

title: Pro-Democracy? Start With Haiti.
description: Bill Clinton, as a candidate, promised a foreign policy based on support for America's democratic values. He also denounced as cruel George Bush's Executive Order, probably illegal, that commanded the Coast Guard to intercept boatloads of Haitian refugees in international waters and ship them home without a hearing on their claims to refuge.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PIERRE BERGE, president of the Paris Opera and the chief business associate of Yves Saint Laurent, was removed Thursday from his 20-year post as president of the ready-to-wear division of the Chambre Syndicale, the quasi-official body governing the fashion industry in France.

title: Mobutu Spurns West and Ousts Premier
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire today rejected Western demands that he give up power and said he was dismissing his main political rival, Etienne Tshisekedi, as Prime Minister.

title: Hans Jacobson, 88, A Trader in Bonds Of Shaky Railroads
description: Hans Jacobson, a Wall Street specialist who traded the bonds of bankrupt railroads, died on Thursday in Cambridge, England. He lived in Basking Ridge, N.J., and was 88.

title: A ROLLER COASTER RIDE FOR EAGLE-PICHER SHARES
description: The price of Eagle-Picher Industries's shares plunged 31.3 percent yesterday -- the single worst drop on the New York Stock Exchange for the day -- on concerns about Chapter 11 reorganization and settlement of asbestos litigation. The stock closed at $2.75, down $1.25, as nearly 1.3 million shares were traded. Earlier in the day, shares had reached $5.50, a 52-week high.

title: Engelhard Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 89,509,000, which reflects one-time charge for accounting changes related to employee retirement benefits and income taxes.Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Sept. 30, 1992.

title: FHP International Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge
description: The North American College Bridge Contest, played in November, was won by Sam Ehrlichman of Flushing, Queens, and Dave Seligman of Falls Church, Va. They represented Swarthmore College and headed a field of 180 pairs on 24 campuses. The winners were two of 10 players to receive $500 scholarships toward college tuition, awarded by the American Contract Bridge League's Educational Foundation.

title: Kenneth H. Lundmark, Lawyer, 76
description: Kenneth H. Lundmark, the retired chief lawyer of Conrail, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Nashua, N.H., at the age of 76. He was a resident of Stamford, Conn.

title: Cremation Ashes in 16 Urns Found in Lot
description: It was a bizarre discovery even to hardened investigators accustomed to grisly sights: 16 urns containing the ashes of dead people dating back to 1958 scattered among weeds, broken bottles, car parts and old furniture in a vacant lot.

title: INSIDE
description: Zairian Refuses to Yield

title: Medco Containment Service (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 5,813,000, or 2 cents a share, after tax from subsidiary stock issuances and pretax charge of $ 7,041,000 in connection with the merger with American Biodyne Inc. in both the quarter and 6 months.c-Included pretax gain of $ 8,503,000, or 4 cents a share, after tax from subsidiary stock issuance in the quarter and $ 14,098,000, or 6 cents a share, after from subsidiary stock issuance in the 6 months.Year-ago 6 months results are restated to reflect purchase of American Biodyne Inc. on Dec. 18, 1992, which has been accounted for on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: Jack in the Box's Worst Nightmare
description: Since the outbreak of food-poisoning from hamburger sold at Jack in the Box outlets here in mid-January left two children dead, the stock of the chain's parent company, Foodmaker Inc., has dropped more than 30 percent. The 60 Jack in the Box restaurants in the state have been barraged by anonymous telephone callers accusing them of being baby killers. Customers are scarce. And local newspapers have carried advertisements by lawyers offering to represent poisoning victims.

title: Displaced New Yorkers Remember the Neediest
description: They are exiles, former New Yorkers who are trying to adapt to locales where the pace is maddeningly slow or the civic life seems to revolve around strip malls or the bagels come frozen (the horror!). They often long for a taste of their rough-and-tumble homeland, so they eagerly buy New York newspapers and phone friends who live there.

title: 3 Reputed Gotti Associates Charged With Murder
description: In another blow against the crime family headed by the imprisoned John Gotti, three men identified by prosecutors as a captain and two soldiers in the family were charged yesterday with participating in one of the murders Mr. Gotti was convicted of.

title: Ametek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Amax Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 37,600,000 for legislated coal retiree health benefits and a charge of $ 99,000,000 from cumulative effect of accounting changes related to post-retirement benefits and income taxes.c-Net income

title: F.B.I. Director Overrules Decision To Put Off Disciplining of Agents
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, today abruptly overruled a decision by senior aides to delay action against agents accused of violating bureau rules that the Director was found to have broken.

title: F.T.C. Takes No Action On Microsoft
description: After meeting behind closed doors all morning, the Federal Trade Commission refrained today from taking disciplinary action against the Microsoft Corporation, which had been accused of unfair competition in the market for personal computer software, where it dominates.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: "Absolut Concerto" Avery Fisher Hall

title: Second Baboon-Liver Recipient Dies of Infection
description: The world's second recipient of a baboon liver died last night without having regained consciousness since the experimental transplant operation was performed Jan. 10 at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Clinton and Mulroney Fault Balkan Peace Plan
description: President Clinton and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada today both criticized a plan to end the crisis in the Balkans negotiated by international mediators. Mr. Mulroney suggested that both Russia and the United States should assume more active roles in working out a diplomatic solution.

title: Review/Opera; A Comic-Book 'Magic Flute' From Peter Hall
description: If "Die Zauberflote" has "the metabolism of a child," as the director Sir Peter Hall has said, how active should that metabolism be? How much fantasy and whimsy and invention can Mozart's opera take? There are limits, as Mr. Hall's new production at the Los Angeles Music Center Opera proves.

title: Mattel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 5 million charge related to Lionel Leisure receivables in the quarter.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 5,236,000.Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1992.Year-ago results are restated for the merger with International Games Inc.

title: Not Enough for Domestic Partners
description: In moving to grant them some of the benefits enjoyed by married couples, Mayor David Dinkins makes a welcome gesture of recognition and respect to the non-marital relationships that constitute "family" for millions of New Yorkers. Yet he continues to dodge the most urgent issue facing non-traditional families -- health care benefits.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's policy discussions with leaders of both parties referred incorrectly to Senator Bob Dole in some editions. He leads the Senate minority, not the majority.

title: Russians Have Few Illusions About Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Beliefs
description: Joyce Davis, the foreign desk editor at National Public Radio, says the subject of women and Islam is one that has long puzzled her. A former reporter at The New Orleans Times-Picayune, she has lived in Athens, traveled frequently in the Middle East and written about the Palestinian Liberation Organization.

title: CPC International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an environmental charge from discontinued chemical operations of $ 46,800,000 in both the quarter and year, and a charge of $ 3,300,000 which reflects impact of accounting change for other postemployment benefits in the quarter and the year included a charge of $ 160,000,000. During the fourth quarter, CPC changed its accounting principles for postretirement benefits (other than pensions), postemployment benefits, and income taxes. The charge resulting from these changes of $ 160 million will be recognized retroactively to the first quarter of 1992. The changes also resulted in a 1992 charge of $ 7.8 million which will be retroactively reflected in each quarter.The company said the above environmental charge was an addition to the charge of $ 31.5 million in the third quarter of 1991.

title: Expert Links Mandatory Desegregation to 'White Flight'
description: Large numbers of whites have removed their children from public schools wherever mandatory integration plans have been imposed, an expert testified today in the state's defense against a suit challenging the racial and economic segregation in Hartford's schools.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Gov. MARIO M. CUOMO had the ball and was driving toward the basket Wednesday evening in a tournament at the State Police Academy when, he said, "I felt a little pop, like a little balloon exploding."

title: Game, Set, Match
description: PHILIPPE CHATRIER, who steered tennis through boycott and hot pants controversies and then back into the Olympics, steps down today after having served for 24 years as president of the French Tennis Federation.

title: Hortense Freezer Kobrin, Volunteer, 87
description: Hortense Freezer Kobrin, who was a leader in charitable causes, died on Thursday while on vacation in Miami Beach. She was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Albany G.O.P. Grappling With Gay Rights
description: The State Senate's decision on what action to take on a gay-rights bill is shaping up as a particularly difficult test for the Republican majority -- one that could define the direction of party politics in New York through the 1994 elections.

title: Some Regions Fear the Price As Pollution Rights Are Sold
description: When Congress passed the Clean Air Act of 1990, it created something never before seen in the annals of capitalism: a free market in pollution.

title: Chemex Pharmaceuticals (NSC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 2 million gain for final milestone payment from Block Drug Inc. for Food & Drug Administration's approval of Chemex's drug Actinex in the quarter and a $ 6 million gain from milestone payments in the year.c-Net loss

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Faldo Shares Lead Nick Faldo and Colin Montgomerie of Scotland were tied for the lead at 135 after two rounds of the Johnnie Walker Classic yesterday in Singapore. Montgomerie grabbed a share of the lead by shooting a three-under-par 67 in the second round of the P.G.A. European event, while Faldo had a 68. One stroke behind were Ernie Els of South Africa and Choi Sang Hoi of South Korea. Els had a 65 and Choi shot 67. (AP)

title: Tuition Reimbursement A Confusing Situation
description: PEOPLE who have been attending school at their employers' expense should take a careful look at the 1992 W-2 income tax statement just arriving in the mail. Some of them could get a rude shock when they find out how the tuition was handled for tax purposes.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Gloria Cheng Pianist Weill Recital Hall

title: U.S. Officially Pleased at Foreign Rate Cuts
description: American officials welcomed this week's interest rate cuts by Germany's and Japan's central banks, but they were reluctant to say in public what many express privately -- that the two nations should do more to stimulate their languishing economies.

title: Public Hospital Chief Picked To Lead Public Health Agency
description: Dr. James J. Mongan, director of the Truman Medical Center in Kansas City, Mo., will be named Assistant Secretary for health in the Clinton Administration, in charge of the Public Health Service, Administration officials say.

title: G. L. Monahan, 59, A General Who Led 'Star Wars' Program
description: George L. Monahan Jr., a former head of the "Star Wars" missile-defense program and a vice president of the Loral Corporation, died Thursday in San Jose, Calif., during a business trip. He was 59 and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: Marriott Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Included pretax transaction costs of $ 21 million, or 13 cents a share, associated with the plan to divide Marriott into two separate companies in both the quarter and year.Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Howe Makes His First Appearance of 1993
description: The cameras were rolling and Steve Howe was clowning for them. While a crew from "60 Minutes" was taping the relief pitcher at the Yankee Fan Festival yesterday, he was waving anxious fans over to his booth, joking with children and scribbling his autograph and No. 57 on baseball cards, pennants and caps for three hours at the Javits Center.

title: Case of Double Jeopardy; Clinton's 2d Setback Over Attorney General Is Calling His Political Savvy Into Question
description: Casey Stengel asked it about the 1962 New York Mets -- "Can't anybody here play this game?" -- and politicians in the capital, including many Democrats, are starting to ask it about the Clinton Administration in the wake of a second, painfully public, politically devastating failure to find an acceptable candidate for Attorney General.

title: Why Teachers Must Maintain Seniority Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Chemed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax gains of $ 1,899,000, or 19 cents a share, from the sales of investments.c-Included after-tax gains of $ 1,522,000, or 16 cents a share, from sales of marketable securities in the quarter and $ 2,452,000, or 25 cents a share, in the year, both from the sales of investments.The company also said the contribution to the Chemed Foundation in 1991 reduced income from continuing operations for the year ended Dec. 31, 1991 by $ 624,000, or 6 cents a share after tax.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Adidas Hires Former Nike Executive
description: Adidas A.G., the German maker of sportswear and athletic footwear, which is struggling with sagging fortunes in North America, said today that it had formed a new United States subsidiary headed by a former marketing executive of Nike Inc.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: The Vogler Quartet 92d Street Y

title: They Appreciate Herbal Remedies Outside U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: 58 New York Choices for Tax-Free Income
description: No doubt President Clinton's talk of raising taxes is weighing heavily on people's minds as April 15 draws near. Here is some good news for New Yorkers -- state residents can earn triple tax-free income from 58 New York tax-free bond funds that already hold $16.1 billion. Only Californians own more.

title: British Test 19-Year Ban On 'Clockwork Orange'
description: Two decades ago the director Stanley Kubrick and Warner Brothers abruptly withdrew Mr. Kubrick's "Clockwork Orange" from theaters across Britain, an unusual act of self-censorship amid public protests that the movie had stirred a wave of violence.

title: Kennedy Library Acts Properly on Archives
description: To the Editor:

title: A Film Maker in the Avant-Garde for 40 Years
description: Stan Brakhage is a living argument for the proposition that the avant-garde is good for your health. In the last four decades, most of them spent in near-poverty, he has made more than 250 films, ranging in length from nine seconds to more than four hours. Yet at 60, the grand old man of the American avant-garde cinema is smooth of face and unfurrowed of brow.

title: Sports of The Times; Bobbing Amid Thugs And Bullies
description: IN a span of 48 hours this weekend, Madison Square Garden will have played host to two major sporting events. Last night, the Chemical Bank Millrose Games were held, and tonight Riddick Bowe will make his first heavyweight championship defense, against Michael Dokes.

title: BRINKER'S FORMER CHAIRMAN ON WAY TO RECOVERY
description: The health of Norman E. Brinker, former chairman of Brinker International Inc., has improved so much in recent days that one of his physicians said yesterday that Mr. Brinker might eventually be able to return to his job as head of the restaurant company.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: Brenco Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Water Works reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
British Air Shakes Up Management
description: Working to restore an image tarnished by a campaign to undermine its main competitor, British Airways announced several management changes today, including the resignation of its chairman and its public affairs director, who reportedly took part in the unethical practices.

title: The Envelope, Please: A.P. Indy Nears Sweep
description: A.P. Indy, who was voted North America's best 3-year-old colt earlier this week, stood at the brink of racing's ultimate honor tonight as the overwhelming favorite to be named Horse of the Year.

title: Woman, 70, Is Hit By Cab and Killed
description: A 70-year-old woman died yesterday after she was struck by a yellow cab as she tried to cross the Avenue of the Americas at Bleecker Street in the West Village, the police said.

title: Piggott Rained Out
description: Heavy rain delayed the return of the British jockey LESTER PIGGOTT to racing yesterday in a series of races in Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

title: Cincinnati Financial (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hans Jonas, Influential Philosopher, Is Dead at 89
description: Hans Jonas, who fled Nazi Germany and became an influential philosopher, died yesterday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Observer; Laundry And Debt
description: I am trying to worry about the deficit but make no headway. Driving shirts to the laundry, I am worrying about the American laundry situation when a radio yakmeister insinuates himself into my ear.

title: Fisk Not Through Yet
description: CARLTON FISK, 45, signed last night to play his 22d major league season, the Chicago White Sox said. Terms of the catcher's one-year contract were not available. Injuries limited him to 188 times at bat last season, and he batted .229 with 3 homers and 21 runs batted in. He ranks second behind BOB BOONE in career games behind the plate. (AP)

title: Despite a Few Bad Putts, Ogle Leads by a Stroke
description: Brett Ogle, despite four-putting for a triple bogey on his next-to-last hole, took the lead today after two rounds of the A.T.&T. Pebble Beach National Pro-Am.

title: Baker to Write of Years as Diplomat for Putnam's
description: James A. Baker 3d has agreed to write the memoirs of his years as Secretary of State for G.P. Putnam's Sons in a deal that could earn Mr. Baker more than a million dollars if the book is successful.

title: Balkan Mediators Ask U.S. Assent For NATO Planes to Keep Peace
description: The international mediators trying to solve the Balkan crisis want the United States to support the use of NATO war planes to enforce provisions of their peace plan for ending the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, arguing that this would reassure Muslims and deter Serbs from further aggression.

title: Tyson's 'Dear Riddick' Letter
description: Mike Tyson, the imprisoned former heavyweight champion who is from the same Brooklyn neighborhood as Riddick Bowe, sent Bowe a message yesterday, and it wasn't to wish him good luck.

title: Cooper Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 6,200,000 in the quarter and $ 590,000,000 in the year.c-Net income

title: Corrections
description: A roll-call listing of the votes by Senators from the New York area on the family leave bill misstated the vote of Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut in some editions yesterday. He voted for it.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERIHOST PROPERTIES INC., Des Plaines, Ill., said its Amerihost Management Inc. unit had contracted to manage the Beach Resort in Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Courts Grow Wary on Science Testimony
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Jumps To Gain 4% For Week
description: Global manufacturing stocks dominated the market again yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its second straight record high.

title: U.S. Jobless Rate Falls As Labor Force Shrinks
description: The labor market showed further spotty improvement in January as the nation's unemployment rate eased two-tenths of a point, to 7.1 percent, and businesses expanded payrolls by 106,000, the Labor Department said today.

title:
STRATEGIES;
Smaller Withholding in 1992 Means Skimpier Tax Refunds in Store
description: MOST employees barely noticed the extra few dollars that began showing up in their weekly paychecks last March after President Bush ordered a cut in withholding taxes to prod a sluggish economy. But tax experts predict many are in for a rude awakening in coming weeks as they figure their 1992 taxes. Not only will tax refunds be skimpier than last year's average of about $1,000, but in some cases taxpayers will owe Uncle Sam.

title: Real Help for the Everglades
description: In her hearings for confirmation as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol Browner spoke of the need for a "new era of communication" between environmentalists and business. As one of her first moves, she has a rare opportunity to work to the benefit of the environment and the economy, resolving a dispute with which she is keenly familiar.

title: Fisher-Price Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: b-Data has been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split distributed June 1, 1992.The company said for comparative purposes, the results for the three months ended Dec. 29, 1991 have been restated to reflect the change in accounting policy for advertising and merchandising, which was implemented on July 1, 1991.The company also said application of this change in accounting policy to calendar year 1991 resulted in the three months ended Dec. 29, 1991 advertising and merchandising costs decreasing by $ 4.5 million and the resultant net income increasing by $ 2.3 million. This change does not affect results for the calendar year.For the first 6 months of the 12 months ended Dec. 29, 1991, Fisher-Price operated as a unit of Quaker Oats Co., therefore, the reported results are not necessarily indicative of the financial performance of Fisher-Price as a stand-alone entity. As Fisher-Price was not a separate publicly-held company during this period, net income per common and common equivalent share and weighted average common and common equivalent shares outstanding are not applicable.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Philadelphia Orchestra Carnegie Hall

title: Maytag Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time after-tax charge of $ 307,000,000 related to the adoption of two new accounting rules and the corporation also took a $ 95 million reorganization charge.c-Net income

title: Harm From Alaska Spill Goes On, Scientists Say
description: The environmental devastation caused by the Exxon Valdez oil spill four years ago persists along parts of Alaska's coast today, scientists say.

title: The Top Soldier Is Torn Between 2 Loyalties
description: In his waning months as America's senior soldier, Gen. Colin L. Powell is struggling to balance loyalties to a new Commander in Chief whose ideas clash with his, and to a tightly knit military culture he feels bound to protect.

title: They Appreciate Herbal Remedies Outside U.S.; Acupuncture's Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Shock Radio to G.O.P.: Imus Likes Florio
description: Don Imus, the radio talk-show host who has been called "irreverent" so often it seems part of his name, is insinuating himself into the New Jersey race for governor, to the delight of Gov. Jim Florio and the chagrin of his opponents.

title: American Air May Retire Planes and Hubs
description: American Airlines is considering a retreat from its strategy of having major operations in all parts of the nation and may cut the number of its hubs and retire several planes, top executives of the airline said yesterday.

title: Automotive Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Net income and shares outstanding are given on a pro-forma basis to reflect the initial public offering in the second quarter of 1992.

title: Fed Adopted Neutral Stance At December Policy Meeting
description: The Federal Reserve said in a report today that its chief policy-making committee abandoned its slight tilt toward lower interest rates in December and adopted a neutral policy, a move that will probably disappoint politicians who want further rate cuts.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: FEARS OVER FREE-MARKET POLLUTION

title: Shlomo Mintz Recital
description: The violinist Shlomo Mintz is to give his only New York recital of the season tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. Mr. Mintz, accompanied by Itamar Golan, will perform Bartok's Rhapsody No. 2, Shostakovich's Op. 134 Sonata, and Schumann's rarely played Sonata No. 2 in D minor. Tickets are $25. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: Raspy but Democratic, Kazoos Corner Market; A Company in Eden, N.Y., Hums Along
description: It is said that a kazoo is to music what a full body cast is to ballet.

title: All-Stars Skate Around Rumors
description: On the banks of the icy St. Lawrence, the hockey world has come together this weekend, and rumors are flying like snow flurries on Ste. Catherine Street.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 INVESTING IN APPRENTICES

title: Bird Confronts the 24-Hour Clock
description: When the cheering stopped, and his final starring night had ended, Larry Bird returned to the reality of retirement.

title: Joseph L. Mankiewicz, Literate Skeptic of the Cinema, Dies at 83
description: Joseph L. Mankiewicz, a writer, director and producer who was one of Hollywood's most literate and intelligent film makers, died yesterday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 83 and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: A Touch of the Irish, a Dash of the Algerian
description: There had been a stirring rendition of the Irish national anthem, and then Eamonn Coghlan, a 40-year-old runner from Dublin with ageless springs for legs, had set a new standard in the masters indoor mile.

title: Review/Dance; How Being Still Is an Art, And Being Fidgety Isn't
description: If a choreographer demands it, standing still is as much a part of dancing as jumping and whirling. Darci Kistler and Nilas Martins jumped and whirled charmingly enough in George Balanchine's "Duo Concertant," which the New York City Ballet offered last Saturday night at the New York State Theater. But they had trouble standing still.

title: JOBLESS RATE HITS A 25-YEAR RECORD IN NEW YORK CITY
description: The unemployment rate for New York City soared to 13.4 percent in January from 11 percent in December, hitting the highest level in the 25 years that the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics has tracked the city labor market, the bureau reported yesterday.

title: Nets Are Close To Signing Bernard King
description: The Nets are on the verge of signing Bernard King to a contract for the remainder of the season, his lawyer, Bob Woolf, said last night.

title: Blair Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a record book deal for Allan R. Folsom, a first-time novelist, misidentified the publisher of the previous record holder, Sally Beauman's book "Destiny." It was published by Bantam, not Doubleday.

title: Cisco Systems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
description: The company said share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split which was effective March 6.

title: Dokes May Not Be Ready, but He Is Well Rested
description: Michael Dokes said he needed some rest, so he spent most of yesterday afternoon lying in bed, watching game shows on television.

title: Philip J. Levens, Broadcasting Executive, 74
description: Philip J. Levens, a retired vice president of the American Broadcasting Companies, died on Tuesday at Massapequa (L.I.) General Hospital. A Massapequa resident, he was 74.

title: Knicks Stop Miami Cold At the End
description: The Knicks won the hard way tonight, which made the victory both gratifying and impressive.

title: Century Telephone Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles of $ 15,668,000 in both the quarter and year.

title: Pyongyang Balks on Nuclear Visits
description: North Korea has rebuffed a request to allow international inspectors to visit two sites suspected of contributing to its nuclear arms program. The International Atomic Energy Agency is right to insist on the inspections and Pyongyang would be wise to invite the inspectors. By dispelling doubts about its nuclear intentions, the North can open the way to wider political and economic ties.

title: All Sides Get Message: Haiti Is a Top U.S. Priority
description: In an acknowledgement that it will have to take more action on Haiti, the Clinton Administration sent a variety of signals today on the crisis there.

title: Senate Panel Says C.I.A. Fumbled Iraq Loan Case
description: The nation's intelligence agencies badly mishandled their roles in the prosecution of a bank that secretly financed Iraq's arms buildup, a Senate report issued today said.

title: Big Weeks
description: Euphoria reigned in the only two weeks that the Dow Jones industrial average gained more points than it did this week. In the last full week of 1991, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates so decisively that a strong recovery seemed imminent. And in January 1991, allied troops swept into Iraq.

title: S.I. Official Gives Support To Fernandez
description: In a significant shift as the Board of Education prepared to vote on the fate of Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, he received support from an unexpected quarter yesterday when the Staten Island Borough President praised his leadership.

title: Nicklaus and Watson Gain Open Exemptions
description: The former champions JACK NICKLAUS and TOM WATSON were among the 13 players granted special exemption for this year's United States Open by the United States Golf Association yesterday. The tournament is scheduled for June 17-20 at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J.

title: American Barrick Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Malpractice Suit Fund Serves New York Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Cache Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
The Community College Route to a Lower-Cost Bachelor's Degree
description: When Adrian Tubero, of Albertson, L.I., graduated from high school, she knew she wanted a college education, but she was uncertain about the specifics. Her major, her career plans, even her choice of school were undecided. Her high school record wasn't bad - she had a B average - but it was unlikely to merit a substantial scholarship.

title: G.M. Verdict Intensifies Debate on Jury Awards
description: The mammoth judgment handed down by a Georgia jury on Thursday against the General Motors Corporation has already renewed calls to curb runaway verdicts by placing caps on punitive damage awards.

title: Hanga Roa Journal; As World Crowds In, an Island Shields Its Culture
description: The topography is like the political climate in this speck of land with its Polynesian people isolated in the South Pacific.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: How Somalia Was Left in the Cold
description: The cold war is over and so are its intrigues, now buried in the diplomatic archives, forgotten except by those who suffer its legacy, as they do in Somalia. The tragedy in Somalia is well-known, but not the diplomatic tale of misperception, naivete and duplicity that brought it about.

title: A Jew, a Woman and Still a Scientist
description: AS befits a scientist, Salome Waelsch has cultivated meticulous habits. Each morning she rises at exactly 5:55 in her Morningside Heights apartment, makes breakfast, reads the paper and walks to meet colleagues who drive her to her laboratory at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. At 8:30 she begins checking to see which of her mutant mice gave birth overnight.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Judge Upholds the Right Of Artist to Use Billboard
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Amtrak must permit an artist to display a montage criticizing the owners of the Coors Brewing Company on a giant billboard in Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

title: Advantage, Ball Club
description: JERRY BROWNE and the Oakland Athletics went into salary arbitration with the largest spread among the 100 players and their clubs on the arbitration list. WILLIAM GOULD, the arbitrator, was asked yesterday to rule on a difference of $1,325,000.

title: Clinton Ponders, Then Drops Plan to Cut Science Projects
description: Eager to find more ways to cut the Federal budget, the Clinton Administration today considered scrapping two of the nation's premier science projects, the space station and the superconducting super collider, but decided to keep them for now after encountering intense opposition.

title: Former Tenant Advisory Chief Admits Misusing $32,000
description: The former top tenant adviser to the New York City Housing Authority pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday to embezzling $32,000 in a case that law-enforcement officials said the authority's former chairwoman, Laura D. Blackburne, tried to keep quiet.

title: German Doctors and Their Secrets
description: How could a doctor with a Nazi past rise to prominence, let alone be elected president of the world's largest medical society? Since the scandal of Dr. Hans-Joachim Sewering broke, a disturbing chain of events suggests the medical profession has not adequately dealt with its past.

title: Judge Kaye for Chief Judge
description: For the vacant post of Chief Judge of New York's highest court, the state's nominating commission has offered Gov. Mario Cuomo seven names. With all respect to the six men on the list, they are no match for Judge Judith Kaye, the slate's only woman.

title: No Headline
description: I have fulfilled every legal requirement with respect to the employment of our babysitter. Nevertheless, and after further consultations, I have concluded that in the current political environment, proceeding further with the possibility of my nomination would be inappropriate. -- KIMBA WOOD, withdrawing as a prospect for Attorney General. [ 8:5. ]

title: Trenton to Vote on Bill Easing Semiautomatic Ban
description: Faced with uncertain prospects of overriding Gov. Jim Florio's veto of a bill last year that would have ended a ban on all but two semiautomatic weapons, the New Jersey Senate is expected to vote Tuesday on an alternative that would allow some 200,000 current owners to keep their guns.

title: Despite New Rate Limits, Health Insurers Stay Put
description: Although there were dire predictions last year that commercial insurance companies would cancel health coverage for thousands of small businesses and individuals if New York State changed its rules governing rates, the outlook now seems far less grim.

title: General Signal reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 58,200,000 from disposition of businesses and restructuring charge and a charge of $ 92,400,000 from adoption of FASB 109.c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 9,800,000.Latest year's income from continuing operations of $ 67,391,000, or $ 3.45 a share, is after adoption of FASB 102 and 106, which caused a charge of $ 8 million.

title: Central La. Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
After Nearly 4 Years, Rushdie Has Hope
description: As he approaches the fourth anniversary of the edict that drove him into a life of nomadic secrecy and lethal hide-and-seek, Salman Rushdie is beginning to see a ray of hope.

title: When a Home Also Shelters a Business
description: Steven Dworman, a 38-year-old West Los Angeles consultant and publisher of the Infomercial Marketing Report, started his business from his home in 1986. It is still being run there, even though half of his house is now being used as an office.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an obituary of the book editor Albert Russel Erskine Jr. was published in error. It showed Donald S. Klopfer, co-founder of Random House, who died in 1986.

title: King Again Puts Himself Among the Heavyweights
description: Just as the surging tide of prefight hype seemed to be reaching full froth for tonight's heavyweight championship bout between Riddick Bowe and Michael Dokes at Madison Square Garden, along comes the undertow.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in some copies yesterday on the front page of The Metro Section, with a cross reference to a sports article, was published in error. It showed Pascual Perez (in a dark jacket), formerly of the Yankees, not his brother, Melido, who signed a new contract with the team.

title: Cutting the Costs of Going to College
description: Two years of community college saved about $29,000 for Adrian Tubero in her quest for a bachelor's degree. How They Do It, Page 34.

title: California Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 4,991,000 recognition of deferring financing and related repayment costs associated with the refinancing of the company's Coso geothermal project for both the quarter and year.

title: Amgen Shares Fall as Income Data Are Released
description: Shares in Amgen Inc., the biotechnology company, plummeted today after the company released earnings and two analysts lowered their recommendations on the stock.

title: Andrea Marcovicci, Daniel Reichert
description: THE torch singer Andrea Marcovicci, whose four-month engagement in the Oak Room at the Algonquin Hotel ended last weekend, describes herself as a "feminist hopeless romantic."

title: Bowe Keeps Title in Just 2:19 of First Round
description: By the time Riddick Bowe had stopped throwing lefts and rights last night, Michael Dokes was barely standing. The ropes kept him upright, but he was going down. It was only a matter of when.

title: The Hippo and the Belle of Amherst
description: LET THE DOG DRIVE

title: Plan for New Road Perils Raceway Flea Market
description: THE future of the Roosevelt Raceway Flea Market in Westbury, which merchants say has become a major tourist attraction that yields $2.7 million in annual sales taxes, has been thrown into doubt with planning for a road through the heart of the market.

title: Polgar Starts Strongly Against Spassky
description: JUDIT POLGAR of Hungary, at 16 the world's youngest grandmaster, won two of the first four games against Boris Spassky of France, a former world champion, to lead in their exhibition match in Budapest. After winning the fourth game on Thursday, Polgar was ahead, 2 1/2-1 1/2.

title: Man Shoots Dog, Runs Mad
description: RECITAL OF THE DOG

title: Christianity Is Booming In China Despite Rifts
description: The Rev. Wang Yijun is a Communist's headache, the kind of fellow who can spend 25 years behind bars and still remain bowed in prayer, presumably asking for the forgiveness of his jailers.

title: Video Production as Cottage Industry
description: "COME on in, but be careful on the steps," the video producer called, as a visitor began navigating the steep flight of stairs to the basement of the house in Waldwick -- site of his audio-visual recording studio.

title: Dried Cherry Valentine Dishes, in Servings for Two
description: NEXT Sunday, Valentine's Day, offers an excuse to devise dishes and menus with foods that are heart-shaped, pink or red, sweet, prepared for two people and endowed with supposed aphrodisiac properties. Some of those goals can be achieved by using dried cherries, an ingredient that is a fairly recent addition to the pantry.

title: WINKING AT BIMBOS?
description: To claim that Gennifer Flowers and others are "direct descendants" of the likes of Madame de Pompadour is really stretching it. Pompadour was one of the most accomplished women of the age, one who advised the King on all sorts of matters, including patronage of the arts, industries like porcelain making and even, as we now know, matters of state.

title: Armani Disarmed
description: WHO is Gio?

title: Emily Bruce, Gib Chapman
description: Mrs. Murphy H. Baxter and George S. Bruce 3d, both of Houston, have announced the engagement of their daughter Emily Kay Bruce to Gilbert W. Chapman 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chapman Jr. of Mill Neck, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: Speeding Into a Hard New World
description: In May 1989, Junior Johnson visited the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, and the longtime Nascar team owner was asked to name the Indy-car drivers he considered capable of challenging stock-car racing's best drivers.

title: Meredith Hyde, James Treadwell
description: Mr. and Mrs. David R. Hyde of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meredith Ellen Hyde, to James Treadwell, a son of Dr. Thomas Treadwell of London and Tatiana Barker of DeCourcy Island, British Columbia. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Car Import Duty Can Only Hurt U.S. Economy
description: To the Editor:

title:
UP AND COMING: Dennis Haysbert;
He Got The PArt, At Last
description: Dennis Haysbert Knew he wanted the part as soon as he read the script. After supporting roles in two male-bonding pictures -- "Major League" and "Navy Seals" -- the 36-year-old actor was hungry for a more emotional vehicle. That turned out to be "Love Field," which reopens on Friday after a week's run in December to qualify for Academy Award consideration.

title: Looking for an Attorney General: The Hurdles; Few Women Have Resumes That Fit Job at Justice Dept.
description: The mishaps that have befallen the Clinton Administration in its protracted search for an Attorney General have arisen in part from the scarcity of Democratic women with enough experience of the right kind to qualify them for the job.

title: JAN. 31-FEB. 6: 7,000 Stop Work; Coal Miners Strike; The Issue Is Union Mines
description: The strike that broke out in the coal fields last week began with all the signs of another of the industry's drawn-out brawls. Negotiations on a new contract collapsed before the United Mine Workers and the 12 corporate members of the Bituminous Coal Operators' Association could even agree on who should come to the table.

title: Sherry Bricker, Andrew Miller
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman R. Bricker of Bellmore, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sherry Beth Bricker, to Andrew Laurence Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Paul Miller of New Vernon, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title: He Wires Snakes to Save Golf Course
description: EARLY last year, Robert Zappalorti, president and founder of Herpetological Associates Inc., surgically implanted radio transmitters in six of the 13 northern pine snakes he had discovered on a tract of land in Jackson Township. From May to December, he and his staff tracked the wired six, portable receivers in hand, and eventually found three nesting burrows and four dens.

title: Sound Bytes; She Puts Up the Money for the Software Dreams
description: ANN WINBLAD, daughter of a high school football coach in rural Minnesota, recalls that her first toy was a stopwatch. It apparently set her up for a career marked by rapid achievement and precise timing. She became a computer programmer. In 1976, she started a software company, Open Systems, then sold it several years later "for a pile of money." She moved to California; worked as a consultant for Microsoft, Apple and I.B.M.; wrote a book on object-oriented programming, and co-founded Hummer Winblad Venture Partners in Emeryville, Calif.

title: Where's the Lit. in Lit. Crit.?
description: DOUBLE AGENT The Critic and Society. By Morris Dickstein. 220 pp. New York: Oxford University Press.

title: The Best Congress Our Money Can Buy
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME
description: How long can Jon A. Jackson remain the best-kept secret of hard-boiled crime fiction connoisseurs? With HIT ON THE HOUSE (Atlantic Monthly, $20) just out, and earlier career adventures of Sgt. Fang Mulheisen about to be reissued, the gravelly voice of this dark, droll chronicler of the Detroit underworld is bound to make itself heard.

title: Mormon Tradition and Zeal Inspire Growth in Northeast
description: The Andersons and the Jacksons, two families with 16 children between them, sat near each other at the Mormon congregation here for seven years. But one day last fall, their meeting house was split in two and they now belong to different congregations under the same roof.

title: The Olympus Dispute's Broad Reach
description: BEYOND the jars of finger paint lining the windowsill, a chair is pushed back from a table where a newspaper is still open, as if someone has left the classroom at the Long Island Developmental Center in Melville for just a moment. Even the lights are on.

title: Hull Asks for a Raise: $20-30 Million Will Do
description: He has more than a year to go on his four-year $7 million contract with the St. Louis Blues, but BRETT HULL has opened a drive for a new five-year pact that would put him in the double million-dollar digits and perhaps in another city. According to The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, the star right wing is asking for a deal that would pay him from $20 million to $30 million.

title: Better Days Muffle Clinton's Call for Sacrifice
description: To economists, it makes no sense whatsoever. But in a perverse way, the rather good economic news these days may make it harder politically for President Clinton to ask Americans to tighten their belts for the sake of future prosperity.

title: How Do You Say, 'Vegetable'?
description: THE first night my sister stayed with her Japanese host family on her junior year abroad, they took her to a restaurant on the outskirts of Kyoto. Her Japanese was rudimentary and the family spoke no English, but everyone sat sociably around the low, polished wooden table drinking sake and smiling at each other. When the waitress arrived to take their orders, however, my sister became flustered. She was a vegetarian then, and while she had practiced how to say that she ate only fish, vegetables and fruit, she also wanted to be polite.

title: Baird, Wood, Outrage
description: Many angry women across the country contended that Judge Kimba M. Wood was being treated unfairly because of the President's political calculations. "Kimba Wood got caught in the wave created by the Zoe Baird situation," one woman said.

title: Making Tennis History at Rumson
description: ON a fall day in 1875, United States Customs officials in New York must have scratched their heads in puzzlement when they unpacked a large crate containing a jumble of netting, sticks and iron bars that had just arrived on a ship from England.

title: Celebrating Fashion
description: Council of Fashion Designers of America Awards, New York State Theater, Feb. 1.

title: Rent Control: A 'Misnomer'
description: This is in response to a recentarticle, "Battle Lines Drawn for Major Struggle Over Rent Control."

title: JAN. 31-FEB. 6: Tabloid City; News Raids Post! Post Is Shocked! And So On!
description: "It's War!" So thundered The New York Post last week in outrage over the body-snatching of its top editorial team by The Daily News, its archrival in the New York City tabloid punch-out. When the Post's editor and headline whiz, Lou Colasuonno, along with its managing editor and metropolitan editor and the columnist Mike McAlary bolted for The News, the Post's new buyer, Steven Hoffenberg, branded the new owner of The News, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, "a vulture" bent on "gunning down" the competition.

title: Mr. Civil Rights
description: DREAM MAKERS, DREAM BREAKERS

title: Surprise Snow Causes Scores of Accidents
description: A surprise storm that only an auto-body shop owner could love dropped up to three inches of snow on parts of the New York metropolitan region yesterday morning, causing scores of fender-benders and, in one case, a 14-car chain-reaction collision.

title: Through Medium and Process, 13 Artists Make Their Marks
description: FROM its curving gables to its leaded window panes, the John Slade Ely House has the look of 17th-century Dutch architecture. It also has a slightly ecclesiastical air, although this is quickly dispelled by the sign outside that announces the exhibition within, "Connecticut Invitational: Curator's Choice." In fact the building, at 51 Trumbull Street, has been a center for art and artists since 1959, when Grace Taylor bestowed it for that purpose on the City of New Haven, naming it for her husband.

title: Handguns Aren't Sexy
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Auto Junkyard, Borne by Taxpayers
description: ACROSS the state, municipalities are struggling with a byproduct of the poor economy: the rusting hulks of abandoned automobiles that are littering the landscape.
