title: JUDGE CLEARS WAY FOR THE PURCHASE OF NEW YORK POST
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge removed the biggest hurdle keeping Steven Hoffenberg from becoming the owner of The New York Post in a court proceeding yesterday that was part high finance and part street theater.

title: No One Person Can Save New York City's Schools
description: Felix Rohatyn is right. Anyone who wants to be chancellor of the New York City public schools should be automatically disqualified. Not because of the deeply divided Board of Education; not because of anger over social issues; not because of racial and partisan politics; and not because of how poorly the city treats innovative outsiders. No sane individual should apply because an anachronistic structure makes the job impossible.

title: What's Shrill to Some Is Incentive to Others
description: Bring up the subject of screaming coaches and Terry Dehere, Jerry Walker and Bryan Caver will say they have heard an earful.

title: 'Kids Week' No Picnic for New York Parents
description: For Erica Legagneur, Kids Week, the winter vacation created by Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez for the one million New York City schoolchildren, was a wonderful adventure.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report in some editions of Business Day on Thursday, about a Federal grand jury investigation of the Dow Corning Company regarding its silicone gel-filled breast implants, referred incorrectly to an investigation last year. It was conducted at the company's request by an independent team of lawyers headed by a former United States Attorney General, Griffin B. Bell.

title: Lance Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Administration Favoring a Plan To Airdrop Supplies Into Bosnia; U. N. Official Is Overruled
description: In an extraordinary rebuff to a high-ranking associate, Secretary General Boutros-Ghali publicly overruled the official in charge of relief work in Bosnia today and ordered an immediate resumption of operations in the area.

title: Supply Side Goes by the Wayside
description: Call it Reaganomics in reverse.

title: Transamerica Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 75 million charge for the estimated loss on the ultimate disposition of the company's property and casualty operations in the quarter and year, and the year also included loss of $ 24.7 million from discontinued operations.c-Net lossd-Included a one-time charge of $ 130 million related to the company's commercial finance company in the quarter and year; income from discontinued operations of $ 16.9 million, or 22 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 39.7 million, or 52 cents a share, in the year, and the year also included a charge of $ 34.7 million from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for postemployment benefits other than pensions.The latest year included a gain of 6 cents a share in the latest year, and a loss of 3 cents a share in the prior year, on investment transactions.

title: 11-Year-Old Is Shot Near Brooklyn Store
description: An 11-year-old boy walking to a corner store with a friend was shot and critically wounded in Brooklyn yesterday, apparently the unintended victim of neighborhood gunfire, the police said.

title: Brady (W.H.) Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 3,334,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Quaker Chemical (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 5,675,000 from an accounting change.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-4 TROOPS, SOMALIS AND SHOOTINGS

title: Proposal for Sludge Plant In Brooklyn Is Withdrawn
description: After a torrent of local opposition and mounting political pressure, the Dinkins administration yesterday withdrew its proposal to build a large sludge-treatment plant along the waterfront of Sunset Park in Brooklyn.

title: Riser Foods Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 9
description: b-Included a pretax restructuring charge of $ 5 million resulting from the closing of seven retail locations in northeast Ohio.c-Net income

title: Tuboscope Vetco International Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Devils Keep Up the Pace With Sabres
description: The presence of two newcomers from the minor leagues seemed to invigorate the Devils tonight, increased their speed in moving the puck a notch or two and allowed them to keep up with the fast-skating Buffalo Sabres.

title: Clinton, in Hyde Park Visit, Urges A Renewal of Roosevelt's Legacy
description: President Clinton paid homage to the memory of Franklin D. Roosevelt today and then, walking arm in arm with the grandson of the 32d President, laid a red rose on the grave of the statesman to whom he would like to link his policies and his political fortunes.

title: Hyde Park Scrambles to Provide a Banner Day for President Clinton
description: What would a visit from the President of the United States be like without a banner welcoming him to town? To her horror, Kate Hinz-Shaffer almost found out.

title: Rematch Becoming A Battle Of Wallets
description: After a series of four-point, five-way conference calls that kept the trans-Atlantic cables humming for almost three hours yesterday, negotiators were said to be just $2 million away from a deal on a pay-per-view rematch in June between the heavyweight champion, Riddick Bowe, and his deposed predecessor, Evander Holyfield.

title: Varco International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that the 1992 results reflected a previously announced third-quarter charge of $ 4.9 million related to the closing of a manufacturing plant in Houston. The company also said that it recorded a $ 2-million, retroactive to the first quarter, for a change in its accounting methods for reporting future income taxes.Results for the latest quarter also reflected the full effect of the Shaffer division, which was acquired in July.

title: G.O.P. SEEKS ALLIES AMONG DEMOCRATS
description: Although they are virtually united in criticizing the Clinton economic plan as the same old Democratic tax-and-spend policies, Congressional Republicans concede that when it comes to fighting it they are outnumbered and outgunned.

title: Beliefs
description: If Roger Finke and Rodney Stark are right, the current understanding of American religious history ought to be turned upside down. If Martin E. Marty is right, Professors Finke and Stark might want to wash their mouths out with soap and water, then offer other scholars an apology.

title: The Clinton Budget: Some Strategies to Help Ease the Pain
description: The dust storm kicked up by President Clinton's economic plan this week is unlikely to settle soon, leaving few clear signals for people seeking ways to lessen the impact of the Administration's deficit-cutting program on their personal finances.

title: Honda Motor Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars and have been translated from yen at the rate of 124.70 yen equaled U.S. $ 1.00, the rate on the Tokyo foreign exchange market on Dec. 31, 1992.Share earnings represented American Share (AS), and 1 AS equaled 2 common shares.Revenue represented net sales and other operating revenue.

title: Oppenheimer Capital L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding represented units.

title: So Far, So Good, but Check Back Later
description: One by one, first Dwight Gooden, then Bret Saberhagen, then John Franco, they climbed atop the mound, each carrying his own misgivings. There were flashes of forced humor and routines of superstition and habit. Then, there was silence. Then, there were pitches.

title: Freed Man To Return To Custody
description: A mentally ill man released by a judge from a psychiatric center two weeks ago despite a history of substance abuse and arrests was ordered back into custody yesterday by an appellate court pending a full hearing on whether he is dangerous to himself or others.

title: How to Beef Up New York Police Foot Patrols
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Vienna Philharmonic Carnegie Hall

title: Review/Rock; Hyperactive Band of One For Techno
description: If techno music is going to make the leap from dance clubs to the pop charts, its starkly propulsive dance rhythms are going to need melodies, identifiable stars or both. Moby, a one-man band from New York City, could be the techno performer whose showmanship carries him to a wider audience without turning techno tracks into pop songs.

title: CONVERSE CHANGES NAME OF NEW BASKETBALL SHOES
description: Converse Inc., the North Reading, Mass., athletic shoe maker, has decided to change the name of its newest basketball shoe, the Run 'N' Gun, after receiving complaints from some community groups in the Boston area, which said the name could incite violence among young people. The president of Converse, Gilbert Ford, decided to switch the name of the $85 basketball sneaker to Run 'N' Slam. Mr. Ford said the original name is a common basketball term that refers to a fast-break style of play. Kevin Johnson, a guard with the Phoenix Suns and the new shoe's endorser, said he was surprised by the negative reaction and did not feel the original name encouraged violence. But he commended Converse for responding promptly.

title: Jones Medical Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Indiana Player Injured
description: Top-ranked Indiana, which has been limited to nine players for most of the season, suffered another blow when forward ALAN HENDERSON injured his right knee during practice yesterday in Bloomington, Ind.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the hijacking of a missionary plane from Haiti to Miami referred incompletely in some copies to the hijacker and incorrectly to the hostage. The hijacker was Haitian, and the hostage was American.

title: Immigrants Infected With AIDS
description: Should the United States allow immigrants infected with the virus that causes AIDS to enter the country for extended stays?

title: Insurance Point System Proves a Costly Puzzle for Motorists
description: ASK drivers whether they have motor vehicle points, and the chances are they'll know what you're talking about: if you accumulate 12 motor vehicle points, you lose your license.

title: On Sunday; Formula 1: Gentleman Tows Engines
description: JUST another day at Gambardella auto repair and tow service. It was 10 degrees when Pat Gambardella, age 61, unlocked the front door at 6:45, carrying coffee and a corn muffin. ("You want half? It's still warm. Feel it.") He turned on the space heaters and compressors for his two sons who get in at 7:30 and settled behind the counter of his cramped 5-foot-by-6-foot "office" for another 14-hour shift.

title: Bosworth Case to Jury
description: With as much as $7 million in insurance benefits riding on its decision, a Federal jury began deliberations in Seattle on Friday on whether BRIAN BOSWORTH's permanent disability was caused by the shoulder injury that ended his career as a linebacker with the Seahawks in 1989 or by arthritis. In his closing agrument, a lawyer for Lloyd's of London said that arthritis, not the injury, caused the disability and that Bosworth, accordingly, was due no proceeds from injury policies. (AP)

title: Lisa Nathanson, Jeffrey Rosen
description: Dr. and Mrs. Noel Nathanson of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Beth Nathanson to Jeffrey Edward Rosen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hal Rosen of Wheatley Heights, L.I. A fall 1994 wedding is planned.

title:
Focus: Scottsdale, Ariz.;
Learning to Live in, and With, the Desert
description: The message that Dick and Brenda Dijkman have for anyone thinking of building a house in the Sonoran Desert is, "First learn to protect the desert."

title: Jackson in Running to Lead N.A.A.C.P.
description: Benjamin L. Hooks made his last report yesterday as executive director to the annual meeting of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. But the subject that dominated the meeting was the news that the Rev. Jesse Jackson is one of a handful of finalists to replace him.

title: The Executive Computer; Behind Next's Sea Change, a Lesson About Market Niches
description: WHEN Next Inc. withdrew from the hardware business earlier this month, a message was delivered to all companies that would build a better mousetrap without first identifying its market niche. The second corporate child of Steven P. Jobs, who co-founded Apple Computer Inc., Next burned through $200 million of capital from Mr. Jobs, Canon Ltd. and Ross Perot before deciding it would really be better off as a software company.

title: THE REFORMATION OF A STREET PREACHER
description: As I read about Al Sharpton's new attitude, I heard over the radio that Thurgood Marshall had died ("Al Sharpton's New Attitude," by Catherine S. Manegold, Jan. 24).

title: Instill Discipline, Install the Military
description: Do any of these educators and the other "champions of the poor" really want to give these Hartford kids an education? ("Failings but No Solutions for Hartford Schools," Jan. 31)

title: Measuring Schools And Dollars
description: In "Comparing School Spending and Taxes" you reported on a recent study regarding per-pupil expenditures and assessed valuation (ability to pay) for each Nassau County school district.

title: World Class, in More Ways Than One
description: SUPPOSE you are an American designer and the job is to work up a new and semi-pricey Japanese car. Suppose further that you like the look of the old Jaguar sedans, and that you were always a bit taken with the lopped-off trailing edge of the Peugeot 504's trunk. Suppose, too, that you intended all along to steal Maserati's jewel-like clock and make it the centerpiece of your dashboard.

title: Lectures and Liaisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Have Plenty of Twists of Fate to Ponder
description: If major league club owners had immediately permitted a Florida group to buy the San Francisco Giants and move them to St. Petersburg; if Bill White, the National League president, had not extended an invitation for someone -- anyone -- in San Francisco to make an offer for the Giants; if Peter Magowan and his group hadn't charged out of the Bay Area gloom to rescue the damsel in distress, Candlestick Park would be a legendary memory, Barry Bonds would be in someone else's outfield and Dusty Baker wouldn't be the Giants' manager.

title: Malcolm, the Aardvark and Me
description: ONE of the most gratifying effects of Spike Lee's film "Malcolm X" is that its success has prompted the restoration of Malcolm's autobiography to the best-seller lists. The country is

title: Composting Odors Roil East Moriches Neighbors
description: HOMEOWNERS in East Moriches say they are tired of holding their noses. After more than a year of persistent odors emanating from a composting plant on Frowein Road, the residents are preparing a suit against the operator of the site, the Earthgro Composting Company.

title: Scarsdale Agent Finds Publisher and $2 Million for a 1st Novel
description: THE scene is a luxurious hotel room overlooking the Caribbean Sea. A man in a dripping wet bathing suit is talking on the phone while the rug he is standing on gets soaked. He has been on the phone with clients for most of the day, but this is the conversation that counts: He has just clinched a deal that makes book-publishing history.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Jan. 24 about Victoria Falls misstated the location of one national park in Africa and referred imprecisely to another. The Okavango Swamps are in Botswana, not Namibia; the Hwange Game Reserves are in Zimbabwe.

title: THE REFORMATION OF A STREET PREACHER
description: Early in the article, Sharpton is quoted as preaching: "There is nothing hip or slick about being ignorant. And there is nothing hip or slick about going around killing each other for no good reason." Such a casual reference to murder as being "unhip"! And does he mean that, if someone believes there is "a good reason," killing is O.K.?

title: 'Pearls': The Nightlife
description: Sexy and sassy. Shiny and sheer. Some are mad. Some even a little bad. But almost all cost less than $500.

title: U.S. Pushing to Get Bosnia Leader Back to Talks
description: Administration officials said today that a proposal for United States military planes to drop relief supplies in eastern Bosnia was designed in part to persuade the Bosnian Government to rejoin peace talks in New York.

title: Orlando Discounts
description: To The Editor: In "What's Doing in Orlando" (Jan. 3), I was sorry to see no mention of the Orlando Magicard discount card offered by the Orlando Convention and Visitors Bureau. The card provides discounts of 10 to 50 percent at tourist attractions, hotels, restaurants, stores and car rental outlets. The three main Disney parks are not included, but Typhoon Lagoon and Pleasure Island are. The free card is available at the visitor information center at Mercado Mediterranean Shopping Village, 8445 International Drive. GARY KAZIN Rockaway, N.J. John Rutherford, director of public relations for the Orlando/Orange County Convention & Visitors Bureau Inc., adds: The Magicard may also be obtained free by calling (800) 551-0181. It will be sent by mail. Allow 10 working days for arrival.

title: A Light Shines In Brooklyn
description: UPON THIS ROCK The Miracles of a Black Church. By Samuel G. Freedman. 373 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $22.50.

title: Technology; The A B C's Come to Life
description: Educational software is growing rapidly, thanks to new technology sophisticated enough to produce the animated images and realistic voices that can delight young children while teaching them.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ANOTHER COUNTRY By Karel Schoeman. Sinclair-Stevenson/Trafalgar Square, $24.95.

title: Grosjean Holds On in the Slalom
description: The wind started howling and the light turned flat five seconds before Matt Grosjean, of Steamboat Springs, Colo., the defending national Alpine slalom champion, leaped out of the starting gate for his second run this afternoon.

title: RECORD BRIEFS
description: Jimmy Giuffre 3: 'Flight, Bremen 1961' Hat Art 6071; CD only.

title: World Markets;   Eastern Europe's Promise Fades
description: WHEN the Berlin wall fell in 1989, the major countries of Eastern Europe were viewed as interesting prospects for fund managers watching emerging markets. But after the initial enthusiasm, the last three years have been disappointing.

title: Behind Bohemia's Plain Walls, Millions
description: NOTHING but the barbed wire bordering its roof and a scarcity of windows draws attention to the nondescript two-story building at 1610 Ocean Avenue in Bohemia where Revere Armored Inc. had its headquarters.

title: Putting It Together
description: Weeks before he took office, Bill Clinton realized that the economic plan that would define his young Presidency would do two things that any politician would abhor: break promises and raise taxes. In interviews, senior aides told how he and his advisers assembled the plan -- and the plan to sell it.

title: Catherine Caan, John Mayher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Glenn W. Caan of Milwaukee have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Kinsella Caan to John William Strieder Mayher, the son of Alison T. Strieder of Brookline, Mass., and Dr. John S. Mayher of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: Time to Set One's Sights On the Outhouse Shot
description: I have yet to master the art of shooting geese from an outhouse.

title: Nearly Everything in Somalia Is Now Up for Grabs
description: The hand-written plea on the hotel's bulletin board was emblematic of a people adrift. "We have 12 flag poles outside and no flags," it said. "We would be grateful for any flags, either organization, corporate or national."

title: For U.S., Aid To Terrorists Is Hard To Define
description: THE very idea that terrorist operations could be orchestrated from within the United States is alien to an American sensibility that regards terrorism as a thankfully foreign phenomenon.

title: FAREWELL, HUCK
description: I don't know if I was more saddened that a police sergeant whipped a 12-year-old with a belt or that the victim, now an adult, recalled the beating with so much admiration for the officer who administered it (About Men: "Farewell, Huck," by Lloyd Van Brunt, Jan. 24).

title: A Toast to Brotherhood
description: Glasses lifted Feb. 12 in Equitable Building atrium.

title: A la Carte
description: DINERS who want to squeeze every dollar for maximum value would not be prone to think about Poco Loco, a Mexican cafe in Roslyn.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: AMERICAN MOVIES

title: Mutual Funds; Pluses and Minuses of Muni Funds
description: SALES of tax-free municipal bond funds have exploded in the last few months, and fund companies say there's probably more to come as investors worry about President Clinton's proposal to raise the top income tax rate from 31 percent to 36 percent -- and 39.6 percent for the wealthiest.

title: Uncertainty Over Parade Has Merchants Worried
description: In the past, the St. Patrick's Day Parade has meant bulging cash registers at businesses like Tommy Makem's Irish Pavilion, a midtown restaurant and bar on East 57th Street. But this year, merchants dependent on the parade say uncertainty over the event is already casting a pall over their businesses.

title: Joanne Barbara, K. L. Friedman
description: Joanne Barbara, a lawyer, was married last evening to Kenneth L. Friedman, a consultant. Rabbi Jeffrey K. Salkin performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue of Nassau in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Clinton Classmate May Head I.N.S.
description: Bruce A. Morrison, the former Congressman from Connecticut and the Democratic Party's nominee for governor in 1990, is being prominently mentioned on the list of candidates to be the next director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, officials in Washington and Connecticut say.

title: Jeffrey Jacobson and Shari Kellner
description: Dr. and Mrs. Irwin L. Kellner of Port Washington, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Shari Lynn Kellner to Jeffrey Howard Jacobson, a son of Dr. Donald Jacobson and Susan Jacobson, both of Woodbury, L.I. An October wedding is planned.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Navratilova-Seles Final Monica Seles and Martina Navratilova reached the final of the Paris Women's Open with easy victories yesterday. The second-seeded Navratilova beat Jana Novotna of the Czech Republic, 6-1, 6-2, before the top-seeded Seles downed Conchita Martinez of Spain, 6-1, 6-1. Last week, Seles beat Navratilova in three sets at Chicago. Navratilova has lost only four times since losing in the second round of the United States Open in September. She has won two tournaments and lost in four finals, three to Seles. Against Novotna, Navratilova won for the seventh time in seven meetings. (AP)

title: THE SQUARE ROOT
description: I enjoy Molly O'Neill's offerings, and her treatment of the lowly turnip was no exception (Food: "The Square Root," Jan. 24). But her reference to the turnip as "a squat little bulb" is not what necessarily grows in my patch. My Swede turnips, or rutabagas, commonly grow to the size (and heft) of the mortar shells Ulysses Grant used to subdue Vicksburg. MIKE O'NEIL Vernon, Conn.

title: The Messy Science of Cetology
description: The whale swam ashore in Nags Head, on the Outer Banks of North Carolina, shortly before dusk, even as a group of beachcombers tried to scare her away by shouting and waving their arms. Just before she grounded, a dozen people ran into the water and flushed her back toward open ocean. But she turned shoreward again and beached herself solidly in front of a cluster of cottages.
