description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week begins with the regular weekly auction today of new three- and six-month bills. Two-year notes will be auctioned on Tuesday, followed by a five-year note auction on Wednesday.

title: Those Numbers, Again?
description: Oil industry officials said the proposed energy tax would bite far deeper than the Administration predicts. Page A14.

title: A Lot Stirring in Big East In a Race to Move Ahead
description: Foremost on the Big East agenda are Connecticut's surge, St. John's concern about Shawnelle Scott's tender ankle and Seton Hall's on-going effort to distance itself from the rest of the pack.

title: States Are Ready to Spend Extra Clinton Transit Aid
description: Officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are anticipating a windfall of more than $435 million in new transportation aid as part of President Clinton's economic stimulus package. They say that if the money is approved by Congress, it could create about 12,000 new jobs this year as local highways, bridges, and subway stations are rebuilt.

title: How to sell expensive jeans? Mix poetry and film noir with celebrity.
description: HERE is a recipe for one of the most ordered dishes at the Madison Avenue Cafe. On the menu, it goes by the name of Modish Campaign for Pricey Apparel. This time, it is being served up to Pepe Group P.L.C. for its Pepe Jeans: 1 small creative boutique agency 1 fresh celebrity spokesman or spokeswoman who hopes to become known as more than just a pretty face 1 large, high-profile photographer who has produced trend-setting ads for designers like Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren 3/4 pound beatnik counterculture elements like berets and poetry 1/2 cup self-consciously stylized realism 1 ton black-and-white film for that moody noir-ish tone so popular among fashion marketers.

title: Abroad at Home; The Two Clintons
description: One quality above all made President Clinton's economic speech a stunning success as he delivered it. That was the self-confidence he radiated. When he ad-libbed jabs at mocking Republicans, there was an inner security that brought Franklin Roosevelt to mind.

title: A Sweet Lou Primer On Marge and Loyalty
description: Lou Piniella's departure from the Cincinnati Reds occurred last October, but it began a year earlier.

title: Peace From Chaos -- A special report.; Mozambique's Outlook Brightens As Truce Holds and Drought Ends
description: On a continent of withered promise, where country after country has defeated recent dreams of creating civil order out of chronic chaos, Mozambique has unexpectedly emerged as a candidate for an African success story.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the special City Council election in District 4 on the East Side of Manhattan described The Daily News's editorial position incorrectly in some copies. The News has indeed printed an endorsement, for Paula Blasband.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Clinton's televised appearance with children at the White House described the preparation of the program incorrectly. The children were chosen by ABC News, and both ABC and the White House were aware of the general nature of the questions they would ask, but the questions were not rehearsed.

title: Owen Is Feeling Secure As a Yankee Newcomer
description: For some of the Yankees' middle infielders, life at this moment is a mystery. For Spike Owen, it is not.

title: Seeing Figures, 2 Sides Calculate Clinton's Math
description: Much of the Congressional battle about President Clinton's economic package could come down to a duel over algebra: the ratio of proposed tax increases to proposed spending cuts.

title: In Miami's Wali Jones, The N.B.A. Discovers It Has a Conscience
description: Anyone here with a young Horace Grant fan at home could be an instant hit by returning with a pair of red goggles that replicate the futuristic look of the Bulls' hard-working forward. As of yesterday afternoon, there were still plenty remaining for the non-negotiable price of $66.

title: Finding the Next Fernandez
description: New York City's Board of Education did not distinguish itself during the purge of Schools Chancellor Joseph Fernandez. Now it needs a new chancellor, and it could gain some measure of redemption by distancing itself from the selection process. That task should be assigned forthwith to an independent panel.

title: Israeli Electors Select the Two Chief Rabbis
description: After a campaign sullied by charges of mischief and wrongdoing, Israeli rabbinical elders and political leaders chose Chief Rabbis today for the Ashkenazic and Sephardic branches of Judaism.

title: Slipping Free From Entrapment's Tangled Web
description: WHEN Ginger Labensky, the 34-year-old daughter of a retired New York City police officer, first told her parents about Aaron Cohen, they were delighted: finally, a nice Jewish boy.

title: As Plants Close, Injury Claims Rise
description: On June 1, 1991, a jeans manufacturer named Big Yank shut an Oklahoma factory employing 225 workers. As the plant closed, the employees filed nearly 400 workers' compensation claims for injuries on the job, despite having filed only 6 in the previous year.

title: Bronx Isn't Dumping Ground for Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Get No Reward for Effort
description: Ron Smith is not a hypocrite.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Choices for German Readers
description: Germany's mainstream print media have been dominated by just two weeklies: Die Zeit, a liberal, intellectual newspaper, and Der Spiegel, a muckraking news magazine that is the nation's most influential publication. But within the last month, three new challengers have entered the field nationwide.

title: Books of The Times; Why Baseball Is Striking Out and How It Can Be Saved
description: Coming Apart at the Seams How Baseball Owners, Players and Television Executives Led Our National Pastime to the Brink of Disaster By Jack Sands and Peter Gammons Illustrated. 266 pages. MacMillan. $24.

title: Elizabeth Cadwell Dance, Volunteer Worker, 67
description: Elizabeth Cadwell Dance, who was prominent in volunteer work in the Detroit area, died Thursday at Bon Secours Hospital in Grosse Pointe, Mich. She was 67 and lived in Grosse Pointe.

title: 2d Phone Line In Airline Suit
description: Travelers seeking to take part in the proposed settlement of a class-action lawsuit, accusing nine domestic airlines of price fixing, so overloaded the toll-free line yesterday that the law firm for the plaintiffs added a second number: (800) 854-7264.

title: Designed for Diapering
description: To the Editor:

title: Poles Forge Private Bank System
description: More than three years after dismantling Communism, Poland is struggling to get a grip on that most basic of capitalist tools, the banking system.

title: Foster Wheeler reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an incremental cost of $ 1,870,000 from the adoption of FAS No. 106 in the quarter, and the year included an incremental cost of $ 7,207,000 from the adoption of FAS No. 106, and a charge of $ 91,259,000 from the adoption of FAS No. 106.c-Net income

title: U.S. School Program Criticized Anew
description: The Chapter 1 program, the Federal Government's main effort to improve basic academic skills of poor children, was called outdated yesterday by two new studies, the second and third reports in three months to criticize the program.

title: Bridge
description: Look at the East hand shown in the diagram, which is much worse than anything you will ever hold in real life. Would you have a chance to make a trick against a heart contract, assuming that nobody blunders?

title: Doskocil Cos. (NMS) reports earnings for Year to Jan 2
description: b-Included a pretax provision of $ 32 million for plant closing.Year-ago results are not comparable; company reorganized in the third quarter of 1991.The company emerged from bankruptcy effective Oct. 31, 1991.

title: Culbro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: b-Included $ 3.5 million pretax restructuring charge at the company's Eli Witt Co. business in anticipation of its merger with Certified Grocers of Florida Inc., which was completed on Friday, in both the quarter and year.c-Net incomed-Included pretax gains from lower LIFO inventories of $ 5.7 million in the quarter and $ 9.9 million in the year.

title: Harvey Kurtzman Is Dead at 68; Cartoonist Was Creator of Mad
description: Harvey Kurtzman, a cartoonist and a pop-culture historian who founded and created Mad magazine and was a guiding force in several other satirical magazines, died on Sunday at his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 68.

title: Q&A
description: Melting the Ice

title: Small Houses: Holding in the 80's, Or Back to the 70's
description: Fashion may be heading back to the 1970's, with long skirts, unstructured cardigans and bell-bottoms, but the jackets and short skirts of the 80's are not yet endangered species. That's one of the messages sent out by designers taking part in the fall edition of the Fashion Coterie.

title: Profits Don't Explain High Drug Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: CLINTON TO FIGHT FOREIGN SUBSIDIES
description: President Clinton today told an audience of aeronautics workers, many of them threatened with the loss of their jobs, that their livelihoods were imperiled because of unfair foreign competition, and that the Federal Government would help them.

title: Fuqua Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain after taxes and minority interest of $ 1 million, or 6 cents a share, for the cumulative effect of a change in the method of accounting for certain photofinishing advertisement costs.c-Net loss and included a provision after tax benefit and minority interest of $ 5 million primarily for costs associated with the consolidation or relocation of plant facilities at Qualex Inc.; and a provision after tax benefit of $ 5.9 million for costs expected in reducing the size of the company's corporate staff, relocating corporate offices and consolidating operating facilities at Hutch Sports USA Inc. in the quarter, and the year included a provision after tax benefit of $ 10.9 million, or 66 cents a share, for the Hutch Sports consolidation.

title: Filene's Basement Picks a New Agency
description: The Filene's Basement Corporation in Wellesley, Mass., said yesterday that it had named Deutsch/ Dworin Inc. in New York as its agency. The off-price retail chain had its account at AC&R Advertising in New York for two years before moving it in-house in December. The retailer's total ad spending last year was estimated at $15 million.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: WOMAN NOMINATED FOR TOP JUDICIAL POST

title: MARRIOTT'S BIG INVESTORS SAY REORGANIZATION IS NEAR
description: A group of large investors in the Marriott Corporation said yesterday that they were within days of reaching an agreement with the company on a corporate reorganization. The investor group, whose steering committee owns $500 million of Marriott bonds, includes two of the nation's biggest pension funds, the California Public Employees' Retirement System, known as Calpers, and the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association.

title: Can Winner Be a Loser? A Riddle For a Rebel
description: Onstage at the Beacon Theater on Friday night, Dave Pirner of Soul Asylum didn't look like an ordinary hero. His long shanks of ratted blond hair were twirling in an unruly halo around his face, and his ripped, faded jeans exposed his legs from knee to shin. He stomped around in tight, frustrated circles, flailing on an acoustic guitar, singing songs from Soul Asylum's current album "Grave Dancers Union" in a parched, unpolished voice.

title: Clinton Backs Funds For Science Projects
description: DESPITE the Clinton Administration's hopes to achieve sharp reductions in Government spending, prospects appear to have brightened for Federal financing of some branches of scientific research and for construction of the world's largest particle accelerator, the Superconducting Supercollider.

title: By Design; Pants at Parties
description: Anyone who has been on the party circuit this winter couldn't help but notice. The ball gown is dead. Short dresses are in short supply, and calf-length skirts are as rare as taxis in the rain. The evening fashion of choice? Pants.

title: Escalade Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Net loss

title: Advice to the Shopworn
description: COMPUTER enthusiasts are a generous lot, generous with their time and information, and eager, sometimes to a fault, to share their hard-won knowledge with others. A recent column here of excerpts from readers' letters brought an outpouring of advice.

title: Patterns
description: A Bendel's Shoe Coup

title: Bonar Inc. reports earnings for Year to Nov 28
description: b-Included pre-tax restructuring costs of $ 17,460,000.c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 3,546,000.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: ASHLAND OIL SETTLES CIVIL SUITS OVER AIR POLLUTION
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said yesterday that it had settled civil lawsuits with 709 of 740 plaintiffs who had accused the company's Catlettsburg, Ky., refinery of polluting the air. Ashland said it was barred from disclosing details of the settlement but it did not expect the agreement to undermine earnings.

title: Nasdaq Index Falls 1.7% But Dow Stocks Are Up
description: The stock market accelerated its screeching swerve away from Nasdaq stocks yesterday as investors piled into the Dow industrials and utilities.

title: IMMUNITY SOUGHT FOR BOSNIAN SERB
description: The international mediators seeking to resolve the Balkan crisis have asked the Clinton Administration to grant immunity from lawsuits in the United States to the Bosnian Serbian leader, Radovan Karadzic, to encourage him to return here for a new round of peace talks later this week.

title: Security Plan Aims Savings At Tenants
description: To encourage tenants to become more involved in curbing crime in their buildings, the New York City Housing Authority plans to let residents use money saved by safety improvements.

title: Delhi Is Nervously Bracing For Militant Hindu Protest
description: New Delhi is a city under siege as it braces for an enormous demonstration by Hindu fundamentalists to be held on Thursday.

title: HOME DEPOT (N)
description: Home Depot Inc., whose warehouse stores have become a mecca for self-appointed home repair experts, put in another record-breaking financial performance in the fourth quarter.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: G.M. DISCUSSING SALE OF LOTUS TO MANAGEMENT GROUP
description: The General Motors Corporation is negotiating to sell the unprofitable Lotus Cars Ltd., a British sports car maker, possibly to a management group. G.M. confirmed yesterday that it had been approached by several potential acquirers. Adrian Palmer, managing director of Lotus, heads one of the interested groups, the auto maker said. G.M. bought Lotus for about $32 million in 1986. Lotus had a loss of nearly $23 million in 1991 on sales of $62.2 million.

title: Robert Rafsky, 47, Media Coordinator For AIDS Protesters
description: Robert Rafsky, a public relations executive and advocate for people with AIDS, who confronted Bill Clinton during the presidential campaign, died Saturday at New York University Medical Center. He was 47 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: E.P.A. Plays a Dioxin Numbers Game in Newark Bay Dredging
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: CEM CORP., Charlotte, N.C., a maker of microwave-based testing instruments, named Richard N. Decker treasurer and chief financial officer. DORNA U.S.A., New York, a sports and entertainment marketing unit of Dorna Promocion del Deporte S.A., Madrid, appointed Harry L. Usher president and chief executive.

title: Clinton Asks U.N. Chief to Meet On Plan for Airdrop to Bosnians
description: Clearly intent on moving ahead with plans for an airdrop of relief supplies into Bosnia and Herzegovina, President Clinton invited the United Nations Secretary General today to meet with him on Tuesday in an effort to win his support for the initiative, Administration officials said.

title: Austin Makes Return
description: TRACY AUSTIN , at 30, will play tournament tennis for the first time in almost four years when she faces RENNAE STUBBS today in the first round of the Evert Cup at Indian Wells, Calif. Austin has no tournaments lined up after the Evert Cup. (AP)

title: Antarctic Hooved Animals Left Fossils
description: EVIDENCE has been found that hooved animals, today represented by such species as the horse, pig and antelope, once roamed the Antarctic landscape, now buried in ice.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the rise in municipal bond prices last week misstated the goal of President Clinton's plan to cut the deficit. It would reduce the deficit by a total of $325 billion over the next four years.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Vladimir Feltsman Pianist Avery Fisher Hall

title: Track and Field; Kenya's Open Spaces Provide Running Start
description: Middle-distance runners from Kenya, the naturals of track and field, must now battle the stereotyping that comes with such outrageous success.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No, it's not true that everyone in President Clinton's inner circle went to Yale. GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOS, the White House communications director, who will be honored this week by his alma mater, Columbia College, said he does not understand how that perception spread.

title: U.N. General Warns Against an Airdrop for Bosnia
description: Senior United Nations officials renewed their warnings today against a proposal by President Clinton that the United States augment the Bosnia relief operation by dropping supplies by parachute to some of the 1.6 million people here who are estimated to be at risk from starvation, disease and winter cold.

title: Dublin Journal; Ireland Tightens Its Belt, but Smiles on Academe
description: The ancient Celts were said to fear that the sky would fall on their heads, and many Irish today understand such anxiety, as their public institutions seem to be failing them in economic hard times.

title: Air Canada reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 52 million provision for staff reductions and retirement costs.c-Included a $ 36 million provision for staff reductions and retirement costs, and a $ 145 million income tax recovery.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Robinson, Lake Buys Sawyer/Miller
description: Two large public relations and corporate communications agencies based in New York and Washington said yesterday that as expected they would merge.

title: AIDE TO TSONGAS INDICTED IN FRAUD
description: The chief fund-raiser for former Senator Paul E. Tsongas's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination was indicted today on charges of defrauding the campaign of more than $1 million. The United States Attorney's office here termed it the largest case of campaign finance fraud in American history.

title: Ameritech Offers to End Monopoly
description: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

title: Bowe Visits Somalia
description: RIDDICK BOWE, the heavyweight champion of the other two sanctioning groups, got a first-hand look at the devastated capital of Mogadishu yesterday after arriving in Somalia on a charter flight paid for with $94,000 of his own money.

title: DIME SAVINGS BANK TO SHED NEW JERSEY OPERATIONS
description: The Dime Savings Bank of New York said yesterday that it would sell its New Jersey operations -- eight branches holding deposits of $365 million -- and eliminate 225 jobs. Dime previously agreed to sell eight New York State branches to concentrate on New York City.

title: Research On Smell Providing Major Hint
description: THINK spring. You're walking through a botanical garden amid a cascade of spirit-lifting scents: first lilac, then hyacinths and daffodils and finally the first roses. How is it, though, that as you pass through the garden the lilac odor, which seemed so intense initially, does not linger and become intermingled with the others? And why, when you smell gas upon entering a room, do you quickly lose your sensitivity to the noxious odor?

title: On My Mind; The Driver's License
description: One day when the United Nations was young, a British delegate delivered a warning: This place is going to choke to death with new members.

title: Chiat/Day Hires A Creative Associate
description: David Angelo, one of the creators of the popular "Hey, you never know" campaign for the New York State Lottery at DDB Needham New York, is leaving the agency, effective Monday, to join Chiat/Day in New York as an associate creative director, working with Ty Montague, also associate creative director, on accounts like Reebok International and MTV. Mr. Angelo, who is 31, is an art supervisor at DDB Needham. Both he and his Lottery account creative teammate, Paul Spencer, a copywriter, also did freelance work last year for the Clinton/Gore Presidential campaign.

title: Metropolitan College Report
description: With tournament time approaching, the following is a look at area conferences in the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Knicks Near Pace of '73 As the Second Half Begins
description: After compiling their best record at the All-Star Game break since they last won a league championship, the Knicks went back to practice today with a goal of improving in the season's homestretch.

title: Closer Scrutiny Urged for Providers of Day Care
description: City Councilwoman Una T. Clarke called on the state to revamp its system of inspecting and monitoring day-care centers yesterday, five days after a fire killed two children at an unlicensed center in Queens.

title: Officer Is Shot As 2 Suspects Are Pursued
description: A police officer was shot in the ankle early yesterday in a barrage of gunfire from a car he and his partner had stopped in upper Manhattan. After chasing the car into the Bronx and pursuing the suspects through the snow and into the Bronx River, officers arrested the two suspects in a vacant lot.

title: Texas Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 80 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.c-Net loss and reflected a charge of $ 1 billion from a provision for regulators' refusal to allow certain costs to be included in customers' utility rates.

title: Lewis Agrees to Defend His Title Against Tucker
description: World Boxing Council heavyweight champion LENNOX LEWIS signed a contract yesterday for a mandatory defense against TONY TUCKER , Lewis's promoter, DAN DUVA , said.

title: Court Fight Over Parade Continues
description: The longtime sponsor of the St. Patrick's Day Parade contended in court yesterday that New York City was threatening this year's march by insisting that a homosexual organization be allowed to participate.

title: Bally Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax charge of $ 1,419,000 in the quarter and $ 10,605,000 in the year, and the year also included an extraordinary gain on extinguishment of debt of $ 612,000, or 1 cent a share.c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 4,851,000, which reflected results of operations of Bally's Life Fitness Inc. and Scientific Games Inc. units, which were sold on July 2, 1991 and Oct. 1, 1991, respectively. The quarter also included loss of $ 4.2 million from the sale of these businesses, and an extraordinary gain due to extinguishment of debt of $ 664,000, or 2 cents a share.The 1991 year included income from discontinued operations of $ 23,300,000, or 69 cents a share, which reflected results of operations of the company's Life Fitness Inc. and Scientific Games units, which were sold on July 2, 1991 and Oct. 1, 1991, respectively. Also included a net gain on the sale of these businesses of $ 18 million, and the quarter also included an extraordinary gain of $ 56,053,000, or $ 1.65 a share.Latest quarter's loss from continuing operations of $ 16,120,000 included gain of $ 5.2 million from the November 1991 sale through a public offering of 3,000,000 Bally Gaming International common shares in the quarter, and the year's income from continuing operations of $ 557,000 included a gain of $ 6.7 million, which resulted from the July 1992 sale through a public offering of 4,547,600 Bally Gaming International shares in the year.Fiscal 1991 loss from continuing operations of $ 57,625,000 included gain of $ 5.2 million which resulted from the November 1991 sale through a public offering of 3,000,000 Bally Gaming International common shares.Results for the latest quarter and year-earlier period have been presented, after restatement of the 1991 period, to reflect the results of operations of Bally Gaming International Inc., on the equity method of accounting due to the July 1992 sale of an added 4,547,6000 Bally Gaming International common shares, which were held by the company.The company said revenues included gains on the purchase of public debt of the company and a subsidiary for sinking fund requirements of $ 4.5 million for 1992 and $ 14.7 million for 1991.Financial results for 1992 and 1991 have been presented to reflect the results of operations of Bally Gaming International on the equity method of accounting due to the July 1992 public offering.Results for the latest and year-ago periods also have been presented to reflect the results of operations of Bally's Grand Inc. on the equity method of accounting. Pursuant to the Amended Plan of Reorganization, the company believes it will lose control of this subsidiary, which is currently operating as a debtor-in-possession under the authority of the United States Bankruptcy Code and also believes its loss is limited to its investment in and advances to this subsidiary, which were written down to zero in 1990.

title: GOODYEAR RAISES OFFER FOR CANADIAN SHAREHOLDERS
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company offered yesterday to buy out Goodyear Canada Inc.'s minority shareholders for $65 (Canadian), or $51.48 (United States), about 35 percent more than the offer rejected by shareholders in June. Goodyear Tire of Akron, Ohio, owns 88.8 percent of Goodyear Canada. Goodyear Canada's shares rose $16 yesterday to close at $63 (Canadian) on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Goodyear Tire's stock rose 75 cents to close at $67.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Cyprien Katsaris, pianist Ewa Podles, mezzo-soprano Kenn Hicks, tenor Alice Tully Hall

title: NORDSTROM INC. (NMS)
description: The fourth-quarter results reported yesterday by Nordstrom Inc. were evidence that traditional retailers have taken their cue from discount chains and have learned to shepherd more of their sales to the bottom line through tight inventory controls. Nordstrom, based in Seattle, is a broad-line store chain known for a high level of customer service.

title: Jury Sworn In for Police Beating Case
description: A jury that includes two blacks and a young Hispanic man was chosen today to decide the Federal case of four white police officers accused of violating the civil rights of a black motorist, Rodney G. King, in a videotaped beating.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Philadelphia Electric Co. is offering $100 million of 7 3/4 percent first and refunding mortgage bonds due in 2023 at 98.852 to yield 7.85 percent through Goldman, Sachs & Co. with the issue callable in five years. It is also offering $250 million of 6 5/8 percent noncallable first and refunding mortgage bonds due 2003 at 98.794 to yield 6.793 percent through Lehman Brothers. Both the callable and noncallable bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's, and BBB+ by S.& P. and Duff & Phelps.

title: Harold Barlow Dead; Pop Composer Was 77
description: Harold Barlow, a songwriter and consultant on music plagiarism, died on Feb. 15 at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 77 and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: George Lovi, 53, Dies; Astronomy Instructor
description: George Lovi, a writer and instructor on astronomy who was widely known in that field, died on Thursday at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 53 and lived in Lakewood, N.J.

title: A new award for ad creativity, the Cresta, joins a long line of aspirants for the title of the next Clio.
description: WHAT, another award for creativity in advertising? Yes, but this new one has some old hands at the helm.

title: 1993 Finds Mets Aiming to Connect the Bat to the Ball
description: The final club average for 1992 was .235, the worst mark for the Mets in nearly a quarter of a century. Each member of the Mets took a piece of it with him -- a .209 or .223 -- a kind of radioactive artifact that couldn't be buried too deeply or fully extinguished from the psyche.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies yesterday about Hillary Clinton's appearance at an Eleanor Roosevelt celebration at Lincoln Center misidentified the man with her. He was Franklin D. Roosevelt 3d, not Herbert Zohn.

title: Parents Plead Guilty In Starvation Death
description: The adoptive parents of a Nassau County boy who starved to death last year while in their care, for which the state was paying $800 a month, pleaded guilty in Mineola, L.I., yesterday to charges stemming from the case.

title: Suffering in Silence Behind the Red Maple Forest
description: THE house stands behind a forest of red maples, like a hidden medieval castle.

title: A New Clue to the Splendor That Was Troy
description: THE rich businessman and gifted amateur archeologist Heinrich Schliemann believed implicitly Homer's epic of the Trojan War. It was as real to him as were Achilles and Hector, Paris and the beautiful Helen. So was Troy, site of the bitter siege, which the German archeologist set out more than 120 years ago to find on the Aegean coast of Turkey.

title: A Politician He's Not
description: DICK MacPHERSON , the former New England Patriots and Syracuse University football coach, will not run for mayor of Syracuse.

title: Douglas MD-11 Plans
description: The Douglas Aircraft Company may develop a version of the MD-11 with 64 more passenger seats in the lower forward fuselage section, Aviation Week and Space Technology said today. The unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation would offer the 362-passenger MD-11D in two takeoff weight classes. Douglas is discussing the MD-11D with airline customers, but does not expect to introduce either version until the commercial transport market improves. McDonnell Douglas stock closed yesterday unchanged at $51.375.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: TORCHMARK SEEKS TO ACQUIRE ALL OF UNITED INVESTORS
description: The Torchmark Corporation sent shares of the United Investors Management Company soaring yesterday, after it bid $201 million for the 16 percent of the company it does not own. Torchmark, a Birmingham, Ala., insurer and financial services company, said it had offered about $30.50 in new convertible debentures for each of United Investors' 6.58 million nonvoting shares outstanding.

title: Islanders Get Defenseman
description: The Islanders yesterday acquired minor league defenseman RICK HAYWARD from the Winnipeg Jets for future considerations. Hayward played in 47 games for Moncton of the American Hockey League this season. He had one goal, three assists and 233 minutes in penalties. He will report to the Islanders' Capital District team in the A.H.L. (AP)

title: Sports of The Times; Basketball, And Time, In Perspective
description: SUNDAY afternoon, Meadowlands Arena. Georgetown had lost again. This time to Seton Hall, by 10 points, the seventh loss in nine games for the once-mighty Hoyas.

title: INSIDE
description: Dollar at Low Against Yen

title: Market Place; Read-Rite is out front with a new technology for reading disk data.
description: SOME savvy investors have played the PC price wars by investing in the few chip and disk drive companies that supply the computer manufacturers. Now some investors are taking a look at a major supplier to the disk drive makers, the Read-Rite Corporation, which makes advanced heads that read data from high-performance hard disk drives.

title: The 'Oklahoma!' Gag
description: To the Editor:

title: Christopher Visits Beirut to Affirm Support and Push Peace Talks
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher flew by helicopter to Beirut today in a gesture intended to affirm the Clinton Administration's commitment to Lebanon's fragile sovereignty and to win support for a quick resumption of the Middle East peace talks.

title: That Cursing Coach? He's Just Old Yeller
description: It may seem like cruel and unusual punishment for a college basketball coach to scream and cuss and humiliate a player. And it may seem a perfectly appropriate action for an athletic director to dump a coach for such behavioral sins, as California's Bob Bockrath did two weeks ago to coach Lou Campanelli.

title: Cuomo Nominates Judith Kaye For Top New York Judicial Post
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today nominated Judge Judith S. Kaye, a centrist on the New York State Court of Appeals who has worked to expand individual rights under the State Constitution, to become the first woman to be Chief Judge of the court.

title: Dress Barn (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 23
Men's Movement Challenges Prison Machismo; Hardened New York State Inmates Find 'Oasis' in Sensitivity Sessions
description: The men's movement, with its talk of warriors and kings, magicians and lovers as role models, may seem to be an unlikely comfort for an incarcerated group of murderers and robbers, macho-trippers and loners.

title: Kenneth Gerald Peters, Liquor Executive, 78
description: Kenneth Gerald Peters, former chairman and president of Austin Nichols & Company, importers and distributors of wines and liquors, died on Saturday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 78 and lived in Manhasset.

title: Treasury Report On Clinton Plan Labels It as Fair
description: A Treasury Department document scheduled to be made public on Wednesday takes pains to assert that fairness was a major consideration behind many of President Clinton's proposed tax changes, including one to end deductions of country club dues as a business expense.

title: Jean Lecanuet Dies; French Senator, 72, Backed One Europe
description: Jean Adrien Francois Lecanuet, a prominent centrist politician who ran against President Charles de Gaulle in 1965 and forced him into a runoff, died early today at his home in Neuilly-sur-Seine, near Paris. He was 72.

title: You Can't Lock Up City Hall and Toss the Key; Heavy Lifting in Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Upheld at Retrial of Congressman
description: Rebuffing requests from the Justice Department and defense lawyers, a Federal district judge today refused to order the selection of a new jury in the trial of Representative Harold E. Ford on charges of bank fraud.

title: Mr. Clinton's Captious Critics
description: Over the weekend, the public got a look at the Republican response, such as it is. The G.O.P. legislators and their fellow-traveling commentators are worried -- yes, gravely worried -- about President Clinton's economic proposals.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary in some copies yesterday about Harvey Kurtzman, a cartoonist and historian of pop culture, misstated his role with Mad magazine. Mr. Kurtzman was the founder and creator of Mad. The obituary also referred incorrectly to his book "From Aargh! to Zap!" It is his most recent book. A corrected obituary appears today on page B7.

title: A Novel Microscope Probes the Ultra Small
description: A new generation of optical microscopes is emerging, capable of resolving images far beyond the conventional limits imposed by visible light.

title: 3-Part Financing Priced by Houston
description: The City of Houston and two utility districts priced a $219 million financing yesterday. The offering includes $176.9 million of general obligation public improvement refunding bonds that are tentatively priced to yield from 2.50 percent in 1994 to 4.35 percent in 1998, 5.5 percent in 2003, 5.55 percent in 2008, and 5.65 percent.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Jean-Efflam Bavouzet Pianist 92d Street Y

title: Dean Witter Stake Is Sold In Offering
description: In a widely anticipated public offering, Sears, Roebuck & Company sold 29.5 million shares of its Dean Witter brokerage firm subsidiary yesterday at $27 a share, or $796.5 million.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES CHANGES IN POLICY TO AID TECHNOLOGY
description: The Clinton Administration announced today a broad new technology initiative that enthusiastically embraces Government and industry cooperation to create new technologies and nurture innovative small companies.

title: Stars O'Neal and Johnson Had Time to Sit and Think
description: After Sunday's All-Star Game, Shaquille O'Neal's father, obviously sticking up for his son, blasted Pat Riley for limiting the playing time of the much hyped rookie.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Henry Rollins Irving Plaza

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Sara Zahn Eighty-Eight's 228 West 10th Street Greenwich Village Through March 31

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Jane Bunnett Sweet Basil

title: New Deal for Aguilera
description: RICK AGUILERA , who had 41 saves last season, agreed yesterday to the fourth richest contract ever given a relief pitcher, a two-year extension with the Minnesota Twins worth $7.81 million.

title: Government Mired in Muck
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is caught in a squeeze play between the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers. Two years and ten months is long enough for those Federal agencies to resolve their differences and let the Port Authority proceed with essential dredging.

title: Review/Music; Prized for Ideas, Pianist Shows Why
description: David Owen Norris, an English pianist who is a professor at the Royal Academy of Music in London, was named the first Irving S. Gilmore Artist in 1991, and last Tuesday evening he collected part of the prize, a New York recital debut at the Kathryn Bache Miller Theater. The prize is one of a growing number of important awards given for a musician's work over several years rather than in a competition performance.

title: New Job for NBC's Laugh Master: Fill the Late-Night Letterman Gap
description: For the better part of two decades, Lorne Michaels has been camped out along the borders of bad taste.

title: In '92, Largest Nassau Deficit
description: The Nassau County Comptroller's office closed the books today on the 1992 budget, revealing what everyone had expected: a $119.9 million deficit in the county's general fund.

title: Security at Nuclear Power Plants Is Inadequate
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Makers Told To Get Involved in Rules
description: The chairman of the House subcommittee on telecommunications warned today that the computer industry was in danger of losing out in the emerging but potentially enormous business of providing computer services to American homes and offices unless it became involved in the Federal standard-setting that will occur this year.

title: Politics' Tracy and Hepburn Signed by Publishing Rivals
description: In a highly unusual marriage of convenience and commerce, Random House and Simon & Schuster will jointly publish the joint campaign memoirs of James Carville, President Clinton's chief strategist, and Mary Matalin, a top political aide to President George Bush.

title: Search for Colorado Skiers Intensifies
description: Rescue teams using a helicopter, an airplane and snowmobiles scoured the treacherous back country here today for signs of five cross-country skiers last seen early Saturday in a region that has been swept by ferocious avalanches.

title: Confidence Index Up Again
description: Business confidence in the economy rose for the fourth consecutive month in February, the Cahners Business Confidence Index said today.

title: Pondering the Fate of Old Hardware
description: YOUR new 486 DX with the 120-megabyte hard drive may be running flawlessly but it still leaves a serious computing problem: what do you do with the old machine? It may be an antique at age 4, but it is not old enough to be charming desktop bric-a-brac, and its price was too high to turn it into municipal solid waste.

title: Angels' Rodgers Takes a Look (and a Seat) Back
description: When the California Angels rode a bus from Milwaukee to Chicago late last season, Buck Rodgers did not sit in the first seat, the one that traditionally is the manager's place on a team bus.

title: U.S. Believes Greek Ship Is Carrying Serbian Arms to Somalia
description: The United States believes that a shipment of Serbian arms is headed to Somalia and has begun a diplomatic effort to block it, Administration officials said today.

title: Vanbiesbrouck, No. 1 Again, Helps Rangers Become No. 3
description: It wasn't the toughest game John Vanbiesbrouck has played. Most likely, it was not even in the top 300. After all, these were the San Jose Sharks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARBARA LAZEAR ASCHER wrote a book called "Landscape Without Gravity: A Memoir of Grief," emanating from her feelings about the death of her brother, Robert Allen Lazear Jr., from AIDS in 1989 at age 31. But that effort, searing and poignant though it is, did not seem enough, and she said yesterday, "I tried to think over a long period of time how I could somehow use the book to do something bigger for the AIDS effort."

title: More Snow Than Usual? What Seems to Be So Isn't
description: Many weather watchers suspect that Sunday's storm was further proof that there has been more winter this winter than usual. But the National Weather Service said yesterday that there was actually less than wet the eye and that snowfall has been well below normal this winter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11 CLINTON SEEKS AID OF U.N. CHIEF

title: Suffolk Mother's Illness Imperils Son, Judge Rules
description: Since her son Aaron was born eight years ago, Ellen Storck says, she has lavished attention on him, nursing him through illnesses and virtually willing him to survive a life-threatening condition.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. 1,000 Points, but a Tie

title: East Village Doctor Convicted Of Performing Illegal Abortion
description: An East Village doctor was convicted yesterday of performing an illegal third-trimester abortion in which he severed the arm of a fetus. The doctor was the first person convicted of conducting an illegal abortion in New York State in more than a decade.

title: Black History Concert
description: Brother John Sellers, the folk and spiritual singer and a longtime associate of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is to perform with Carolyn Bird and the Inspirational Choir on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122d Street, Morningside Heights. The concert will celebrate Black History Month. Suggested admission: $10. Information: (212) 222-5900.

title: Lufkin Industries reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 24.3 million in restructuring charges, and a charge of $ 7,506,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting change for adoption of SFAS No. 106.c-Net income and included a loss of $ 2,102,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Editorial Notebook; Two Strong Judges
description: The deaths of two judicial giants, David Bazelon, 83, and Gerhard Gesell, 82, are stark reminders that the Supreme Court isn't the only seat of legal power. Former Chief Judge Bazelon was profoundly influential in four decades on the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington. Judge Gesell, on the District Court in the same courthouse, often had the last word in the cases he tried.

title: 31 Closings Set By Phar-Mor
description: Phar-Mor Inc. said it would ask a bankruptcy court for permission to close an additional 31 money-losing stores as part of the discount drugstore chain's effort to return to profitability.

title: Surrender? Boggs Says He's Just Begun to Hit
description: The statement was made with the sincerity and confidence of someone who knew without a doubt that his words were gospel, according to baseball record books.

title: Dorothy Van Doren, Author and Editor, 96
description: Dorothy Van Doren, author, editor and widow of the poet and critic Mark Van Doren, died on Sunday at the Sharon Hospital in Sharon, Conn., where she lived. She was 96.

title: 2 Accuse Unification Church of 'Coercion'
description: Four days before the state is to act on the University of Bridgeport's accreditation, two Russians held a news conference here today to say that they had been promised scholarships in exchange for taking Unification Church training.

title: Nobody Needs Nukes
description: In the wake of the first and second treaties on reducing strategic arms, many security experts say the world can afford a long pause in nuclear arms control. They are wrong.

title: At Murder Arraignment of Two 10-Year-Olds, British Crowd Erupts
description: Shouting abuse and wrestling with police officers, a crowd of angry protesters rushed police vans carrying two 10-year-old boys away from a Liverpool courthouse this morning, after their arraignment on charges of murder and kidnapping in the brutal killing of a 2-year-old.

title: Recalling Joe Caldwell, Circa 1974
description: Joe Caldwell lives in 1993, but he is stuck in 1974, when the former Atlanta Hawk's basketball career ended, not with an injury, a release, or a slam dunk, but with a suspension from the St. Louis Spirits of the American Basketball Association that he charges deprived him of more seasons, more salary, a better pension and a legacy.

title: Nets' Second Season Starting With a Bang
description: Long before the break for the All-Star Game, Coach Chuck Daly peeked at the Nets' schedule for the resumption of the season and winced.

title: National Service For Youth
description: In his Inaugural Address, President Clinton challenged young Americans to "a season of service" to help in "reconnecting our torn communities." A national service program is high among his priorities, enabling young people to provide service to their communities and help themselves pay for college as well.

title: Review/Fashion; Galanos's Latest: Call It Top Spin
description: For more than 40 years, James Galanos has listened to his own music, orchestrating his own scores. Never has his particular take on fashion, a marriage of technique and taste, seemed more topical or effective. Starting with a loosening-up of suit jackets, shown most often over tunics and wide-leg pants, progressing through dinner suits with cutouts at the yoke, and ending with the chiffon dresses that have been his hallmark through the years, his new collection represents top-quality dressmaking at its best.

title: Medical Test Pilots
description: If Hillary Rodham Clinton's task force seeking answers to our health care problems were commissioned instead to come forward with a new antibiotic or surgical procedure, it would carry out many pilot experiments before making sweeping recommendations. No biological scientist would commit large amounts of human or economic resources without favorable preliminary evidence.

title: Alvin Schonfeld, Securities Executive, 74
description: Alvin Schonfeld, a retired Wall Street executive, died yesterday at the Humana Hospital in Phoenix. He was 74 and lived in Phoenix.

title: Acquisition By Conagra
description: Conagra Inc. said today that it had acquired United Plastic Films Inc., a Cartersville, Ga., maker of the Brute and Fiesta brands of household and outdoor trash bags.

title: Congress Is Pressed to Join in Belt-Tightening
description: If members of Congress could finish all their business in one day, shut down their offices, dismiss their staffs and resign without pensions, they could save the nation's taxpayers $2 billion a year -- about the cost of one B-2 bomber.

title: PNC Merger Plan Canceled
description: The PNC Bank and Ohio Bancorp have canceled merger plans, three weeks after saying their agreement was being delayed for review.

title: Closest Pulsar
description: Using a radio telescope the size of a football field, scientists have identified a star emitting pulses of radiowaves 400 light-years from Earth as the closest pulsar ever found, according to a study published in the current issue of the journal Nature.

title: Woman in the News;  Cuomo's Choice to Head the Court of Appeals: A Judge's Judge
description: While Judge Judith S. Kaye exercises on her Nordic Track early each morning, she watches Court TV on cable television. When she travels to Switzerland each summer, she takes along a compendium of recent rulings by the United States Supreme Court as her vacation reading.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Decide if Anti-Bias Law Is Retroactive
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Civil Rights Act of 1991, which restored some legal remedies for employment discrimination and expanded others, applies retroactively to the thousands of cases that were pending when President George Bush reluctantly signed it into law.

title: Loud Noise May Offer a Way to Save Fish From Electric Plants
description: EXPERTS on antisubmarine warfare at a small company in Waterford, Conn., have long been obsessed with Soviet submarines because they design the sonar systems that enable the Navy's submarine and surface ships to detect and track those subs.

title: Serbian Arms Sale Suspected
description: Washington suspects that a Serbian arms shipment is headed to Somalia and has begun a diplomatic effort to block it, officials said. Page. A6

title: Insight; Tobacco Blues
description: The more the Administration talks about raising sin taxes to pay for improved health care, the more the tobacco stocks have fits. UST, the maker of Copenhagen and Skoal chewing tobacco, gets no protection from diversification, either. Instead of peddling cookies or cheeses, like some tobacco-based companies do, UST's other major products are premium wines.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: PRUDENTIAL INSURANCE COMPANY OF AMERICA, Newark, said it acquired the European real estate unit of global fund manager Invesco MIM P.L.C. for $:2 million, or $2.9 million. The London-based unit, MIM Property Services Ltd., manages about $900 million of real estate investments, mostly in Britain and on the Continent.

title: Two Arrests Embroil Fiat In Scandal
description: Two high-ranking Fiat S.p.A. executives were arrested today in a growing year-old scandal involving hundreds of Italian politicians and officeholders accused of trading public works contracts for bribes used to finance their political parties.

title: Effects Are Unclear In Limits On Medical Residents' Hours
description: Four years and nearly $1 billion after New York State adopted the nation's strictest limits on the hours worked by medical residents, it is unclear whether the changes have helped or hurt patient care, doctors and hospital administrators say.

title: Palestinian Set Peace-Talk Terms
description: Leaders of the Palestinian delegation to the Middle East peace talks said today that they would tell Secretary of State Warren Christopher that their continued participation in the negotiations depends on an Israeli commitment to stop deporting Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Making an Embryo: Biologists Find Keys to Body Plan
description: AS any ardent viewer of the "Star Trek" television series will attest, the great majority of alien creatures portrayed, no matter how theoretically distant their origins, look terribly familiar. They have bodies separated into two basic regions, head and trunk. They have eyes, ears, mouths and snouts, albeit of varying puttied-up shapes and dimensions. They have arms and legs in tidy symmetrical pairs.

title: Irish Deny Quid Pro Quo
description: Notre Dame, which successfully recruited star quarterback RON POWLUS of Berwick High School in Pennsylvania, offered an assistant coach's job to Powlus's high school coach, GEORGE CURRY .

title: Books of The Times; People With Bad Luck and Even Worse Behavior
description: Van Gogh's Room at Arles Three Novellas By Stanley Elkin 312 pages. Hyperion. $22.95.

title: U.S. Names New Coordinator For Aid to Ex-Soviet Lands
description: The State Department today announced the appointment of a career diplomat who is an expert on Russia as the new coordinator for American aid to the former Soviet republics.

title: You Can't Lock Up City Hall and Toss the Key
description: To the Editor:

title: Avondale Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 4 million writedown on assets in both the quarter and year.Avondale said that it made contributions to the Employee Stock Ownership Plan of $ 8.1 million for the full year 1992, $ 6 million for the fourth quarter of 1991 and $ 24 million for the full year 1991.

title: Europe Is Divided on Clinton's Plans
description: European governments are divided in their response to President Clinton's economic plan, gratified by his attempt to reduce the American budget deficit, but increasingly irked by his tough approach to trade issues.

title: Chess
description: John Fedorowicz, a Manhattan grandmaster, was fascinated by Boris Men of Cleveland, his Round 14 opponent in the United States championship, which ended Dec. 20 in Durango, Colo.

title: Senate Ordered to Detail Mailings to Constituents
description: In a ruling that opens a longstanding Legislative perquisite to greater public scrutiny, a New York State Supreme Court justice has ordered the State Senate to release detailed information about the taxpayer-financed literature it produced and mailed for one of its members.

title: Review/Ballet; A Surprise Premiere by Martins
description: The Reader's Digest approach to ballet programming receives a yearly nod when more than a dozen excerpts or short pieces fill up the closing night of the New York City Ballet's winter season.

title: Accounts
description: * The Holland Inc., Vancouver, Wash., to Borders, Perrin & Norrander, Portland, Ore., to handle its Burgerville U.S.A. fast-food restaurant chain account, previously divided among various agencies. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Baker and Mosbacher Are Hired by Enron
description: The Enron Corporation said today that it had hired former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and former Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher to help develop overseas projects.

title: ASPIN IN HOSPITAL FOR CARDIAC TESTS
description: Defense Secretary Les Aspin was hospitalized late Sunday for shortness of breath and is in intensive care, the Pentagon said today.

title: Dollar Drops Sharply to Record Low vs. Yen
description: The dollar continued its fall to record lows against the Japanese yen today as traders anticipated that the leading industrial nations would push for a stronger yen to help reduce Japan's soaring trade surplus with the United States and Europe.

title: Nation of Orphans: A special report; Uganda, Scarred by AIDS, Turns to Its Youth
description: Before Julius Keeya Kintu's father died of AIDS five years ago, he taught his son how to grow coffee, squash and cassava, whose root is Uganda's staple food. Together they patched up the family's brick-and-thatch hut.

title: 4 People Shot or Knifed During Violent Incidents Near Schools
description: Two people were shot and two suffered superficial knife wounds in separate incidents in and around three schools in Brooklyn and the Bronx yesterday, the police said.

title: Sir Dick White, 87, Ex-British Intelligence Chief
description: Sir Dick White, the former Director General of two British intelligence agencies, M.I.5 and M.I.6, has died at his home in the Sussex region of southern England, The Associated Press yesterday quoted his family as saying. He was 87.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: James Tocco Pianist Merkin Concert Hall

title: Airline Traffic Rises 6.1%
description: Traffic on the largest United States airlines rose 6.1 percent in January from the similar period of 1992, the Air Transport Association said today.

title: 4 Concerts Without Masur
description: Kurt Masur, the New York Philharmonic music director, has withdrawn from four Philharmonic concerts because of illness. James Levine, the Metropolitan Opera conductor, is to replace Mr. Masur at the Philharmonic Pension Fund Benefit concert at 8 tonight in Avery Fisher Hall. Jahja Ling, the resident conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, is to make his Philharmonic debut at the subscription concerts at 8 P.M. on Thursday and 11 A.M. on Friday in Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Ling is also to conduct the Philharmonic at 8 P.M. on Saturday in Tilles Center, on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, Brookville. Information: 875-5030.

title: Reputed Mobster Sent To Hospital by Judge
description: A Federal judge has ruled that a reputed mobster dying of AIDS should spend his final days in a hospital bed rather than in jail, despite his "proven dangerous propensities."

title: Track and Field; Hammer Thrower Reaps Benefits of Being Indoors
description: In 1987, Lance Deal, an outstanding hammer thrower outdoors, entered his first formal indoor competition in the 35-pound weight throw at the USA/Mobil track and field championships. He won with a throw of 74 feet 5 inches.

title: Arms Are Root Cause Of Somalia's Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The calendar of cultural events in the New Jersey Weekly on Sunday misstated the time and place of a free lecture, "The Russian Chess Tradition," at Fairleigh Dickinson University in Madison, N.J. It will be at noon tomorrow at the Hartman Lounge in the Mansion on the campus.

title: Oh, Canada: Men Finish 1-2-3 in Giant Slalom
description: A blizzard swept through today, but its ferocity was no match for the Canadian Alpine team. Canadian skiers won all three medals in the men's giant slalom event.

title: A New Job for Stein, Without a Race?
description: What's in a name? For the New York City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, it seems, everything.

title: Promising Moves in South Africa
description: South Africans neared a historic compromise last week that promises an orderly end to white minority rule. Both President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela's African National Congress have approved creating an interim government for five years.

title: No Headline
description: My father taught me how to plant and my mother, she taught me discipline. When I am older I want to be a doctor. I see so many people who are sick and they die before they even get to the hospital. -- JULIUS KEEYA KINTU, a 13-year-old Ugandan who is raising his family because both parents have died of AIDS. [ A1:3. ]

title: Share Price Of Synergen Plunges 68%
description: Shares of Synergen Inc. plunged 68 percent yesterday after the company's executives said they were disappointed by results of recent tests for Antril, Synergen's most promising new biotechnology drug. Antril is a treatment for sepsis, a deadly bacterial infection.

title: CalMat Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net non-recurring charges of $ 6,700,000 in the quarter and $ 21.8 million in the year. For the year, the charges included $ 6.7 million, related to the consolidation of certain construction materials operations; $ 6 million to adopt the new accounting standard for postretirement benefits other than pensions and a charge of $ 9 million to write down the book value of properties.c-Net incomeThe company said 1992 earnings also included gains from ongoing property sales of $ 272,000, or 1 cent a share, compared to $ 5,733,000, or 25 cents a share, in the same period of 1991.

title: Shut Library To Reopen For 3 Days Each Week
description: The library of the New-York Historical Society, which closed on Friday, will re-open three days a week, possibly as early as tomorrow, with an emergency grant of $66,000 arranged by state and local officials.

title: Trump Plaza to Sell Notes, In Bid to End Bank Scrutiny
description: Trump Plaza Funding Inc. filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $325 million in mortgage notes due in 2001. The move could help the developer Donald J. Trump to shed some personal debt and end bank supervision of his businesses.

title: Long-Bond Yield Hits 6.93% Low
description: President Clinton's economic program may be running into some obstacles in Congress and in the corporate world. But it is having no problems in the bond market, where long-term interest rates continue to fall.

title: Wherein a President Easily Outpolls Pooh
description: Say what you will about his economic plan, President Clinton is outperforming Winnie-the-Pooh.

title: Men's Movement Challenges Prison Machismo
description: The men's movement, with its talk of warriors and kings, magicians and lovers as role models, may seem to be an unlikely comfort for an incarcerated group of murderers and robbers, macho-trippers and loners.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Lorne Michaels, the executive producer of "Saturday Night Live," misstated the timing of a prime-time music special for which Mr. Michaels was also executive producer. It was shown on Sunday night, not Monday.

title: Dresser Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 8.1 million related to changes in the retiree medical benefit plan.c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 6,000,000, and a loss from for retiree medical benefits and deferred taxes of $ 393,800,000.

title: Rohr Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
No Additions to Hall
description: REGGIE JACKSON won't have to share his spotlight. The Hall of Fame veterans committee didn't elect any players yesterday at its meeting in Tampa, Fla., so Mr. October will have Cooperstown to himself on induction day.

title: Public & Private; Lost in Limbo
description: There is a political problem baking under the hot sun at Guantanamo Bay, a political problem ringed with razor wire, housed in wooden barracks, living amid rats and scorpions while soldiers watch from guard towers.

title: Liverpool Tries to Reconcile Murder and a Boy Next Door
description: Neighbors recall watching him roller-skate past the curving row of tumbledown two-story apartments where he lived with his mother and six brothers, a chubby-cheeked 10-year-old with close-cropped hair who, like so many other boys in the tough Walton neighborhood, seemed much older.

title: Announcement of Nominations by the President
description: President Clinton announced today that he had chosen the president of the Wilderness Society, George T. Frampton Jr., to be an Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

title: Tartabull Is Hoping To Play 162 Games
description: It is a new look for Danny Tartabull, to be sure, one that the New York Yankees could easily become quite comfortable with. The club's highly paid right fielder checked into camp today the picture of health.

title: Abbey Healthcare Group (NMS) reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 27,340,000.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: LAST year, I visited a trout hatchery in Idaho. Over the years I had tasted Idaho trout, which are widely marketed in this country, but I was never sure why they were so good. The operation was indeed impressive. The eggs are hatched in an incubator that is fed by a natural stream that flows from a pristine waterfall nearby. The baby fish are sent to various freshwater tanks until they reach a certain weight. They are caught with nets and immediately processed, some flash frozen, others boxed fresh in dry ice and shipped all over the country.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Manhattan School of Music Philharmonia Orchestra Manhattan School of Music

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt * Archer-Daniels-Midland Co., Decatur, Ill., a producer of grain and agricultural products, is offering $250 million of 7 1/8 percent notes due in 2013 at 99.736 to yield 7.15 percent through Salomon Brothers. The noncallable notes are rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by Standard & Poor's Corp. * P. H. Glatfelter Co., Spring Grove, Pa., a paper manufacturer, is offering $150 million of 5 5/8 percent notes due in 1998 at 99.764 to yield 5.93 percent through Bear, Stearns & Co. The noncallable notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's and A- by S.& P.

title: Clinton's Technology Plan Would Redirect Billions From Military Research
description: President Clinton's newly introduced plan to bolster industrial technology involves almost no increase in total government spending on research, but it would redirect billions of dollars from military programs to projects involving private industry.

title: Finding Ways to Deliver a Life-Saving Jolt
description: Ken Rusk remembers the first time the titanium box in his abdomen did what it was supposed to do -- deliver an electric shock to his heart. It felt like being kicked in the chest by a horse.

title: Time to Stop the Posturing Over Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Incentive Plan Seeks to Save G.M. Plant
description: In a long-shot effort to keep the huge car assembly plant here from closing, New York State officials are knitting together a multimillion-dollar package of inducements for the General Motors Corporation, including financing for the plant's retooling and the building of a companion parts-making plant an hour away.

title: Iraqi Artillery Is Said to Threaten U.N. Copters Looking for Missiles
description: In a new challenge to the United Nations, Iraqi forces aimed their guns at the helicopters of two inspectors on Monday, interrupting their search for Scud missiles, officials said today.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Stealth Industrial Policy It Makes Sense, If Done Cautiously
description: First there was the uncola. Then the non-bank. Now, courtesy of President Clinton, America has its first non-industrial policy.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: A.E.P. INDUSTRIES, Moonachie, N.J., a manufacturer of polyethylene film products, has acquired the assets and industrial products business of Rhodes Plastics Corp. of Linden, N.J., for an undisclosed amount of cash. NATURE FOOD CENTERS, New York, plans to acquire Nutrition World, the retail division of Sage Enterprises Inc. for $4.75 million.

description: Terror in the Night The Klan's Campaign Against the Jews By Jack Nelson Simon & Schuster. 287 pages. Publisher.

description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued ChemLawn operations of $ 264,357,000 and $ 274,693,000, in the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a loss of $ 24,560,000 from cumulative effect of change in accounting for post-retriement health-care benefits.

title: Europeans Scorn Charges By Clinton of Aid to Airbus
description: President Clinton's criticism that European governments subsidized the Airbus aircraft consortium at the expense of American jobs was greeted with scorn here today.

title: Bank Money Accounts
description: Annual effective yields, in percent, on money market accounts, three-month certificates of deposit and six-month C.D.'s expected at selected institutions on Wednesday, Feb. 24,1993. Some C.D. yields assume reinvestment after maturity. Yields are based on the method of compounding and the rate stated for the lowest minimum to open an account, but minimum vary. Higher yields may be offered for larger deposits. C.D. figures are for fixed rates only.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Lucinda Williams Town Hall

title: City Council Race Goes Down to Wire
description: Jane R. Crotty, a Democrat, and Andrew S. Eristoff, a Republican, were locked last night in a close race to represent an East Side district in the City Council, according to unofficial election returns.

title: Slaying of 3 Teen-Agers Sets Off Furor Over Spain's Justice System
description: The discovery in recent weeks of the bodies of three teen-age girls who had been raped, tortured and then shot has set off protests against lax criminal laws and lenient judges and has brought angry demands for a return of the death penalty in Spain.

title: New Season, Old Tension For Umpires and League
description: The chiefs of American League umpiring crews will meet in Tampa, Fla., Thursday, but their National League counterparts do not have a preseason meeting scheduled. The absence of a meeting for a fourth consecutive year is one of the issues at the heart of the umpires' growing discontent with the National League office.

title: FIRST FIDELITY TO BUY VILLAGE FINANCIAL
description: First Fidelity Bancorp, based in Lawrenceville, N.J., has agreed to acquire Village Financial Services Ltd. of Port Chester, N.Y., for $66 million in cash and stock. Village Financial's shares jumped $9, or 52.9 percent, to $26, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. First Fidelity will exchange $17.01 in cash, and $11.34 a share in new stock, for each share of Village Financial -- a total price of $28.35 a share, or 1.23 times book value. Village Financial Serviceshas branches in Westchester County, N.Y., and the Riverdale area of the Bronx.

title: Schott's Chance to Talk
description: JIM BOWDEN, general manager of the Cincinnati Reds, would like to have owner MARGE SCHOTT address the team's players before she begins her one-year suspension on Monday.

title: Nassau to Sue Over Financing Of State-Mandated Programs
description: The Nassau County Executive said today that he would sue New York State, charging that state mandates on counties, municipalities and school boards to provide services were unconstitutional.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No matter what else he accomplishes, PRESIDENT CLINTON, an avid jogger, has been a boon to running. Or so says someone who should know: FRED LEBOW, chairman of the New York Road Runners Club. In return, Mr. Lebow announced yesterday, the club would contribute $1,000 toward the construction of a running track at the White House.

title: PLAINTIFF AGAINST WESTINGHOUSE UNIT REPORTS BIG AWARD
description: Anuhco Inc. said yesterday that it and a subsidiary, American Freight System Inc., had been awarded $70 million in damages against the Westinghouse Credit Corporation. The company said the award, which is subject to appeal, had been entered in Jackson County Circuit Court in Kansas City, Mo. Anuhco's suit against Westinghouse Credit accused it of reneging on a 1988 commitment to provide financing. Westinghouse officials could not immediately be reached for comment.

title: Crime Against Tourists Prompts Florida Drive
description: News accounts abroad about recent incidents of violent crime against tourists in Florida prompted Gov. Lawton Chiles to form a task force today to fight not only the problem itself but also any perception that the state is experiencing a wave of terror.

title: Hoechst Celanese reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 141,000,000, which reflected adoption of SFAS No. 106.c-Net income

title: Perkin-Elmer Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Perkin-Elmer said that earnings for the year-ago quarter excluded a one-time gain of $ 3.3 million from the sale of a joint venture.

title: Cable System to Keep Connecticut Channels
description: In the face of a public outcry, the cable television system that serves southwestern Connecticut reversed itself today and said it would retain home-grown Connecticut stations that it had planned to drop. But it left future plans uncertain.

title: Woman Shot And Robbed On a Street in TriBeCa
description: A graphics designer was seriously wounded by a shot to the neck yesterday morning after she placed packages in the trunk of her Mercedes-Benz on a TriBeCa street, the police said. The gunmen then opened the trunk and calmly walked away with the packages.

title: Japanese Business Sees a High Cost in Rising Yen
description: The last time cries of "endaka!" -- the term for the surging strength of the Japanese yen -- reverberated here in the mid-1980's, Japan's economy was booming and the United States was searching for a quick way to reduce its vast trade deficit with Tokyo. The monetary solution helped a little, but only temporarily.

title: Giving More Than Once to Neediest Cases Fund
description: In recent weeks, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received scores of checks from contributors who were giving for a second time because they feared that the current campaign would fall short of its goal, forcing charities to turn away thousands of people.

title: MORGAN STANLEY GROUP (N)
description: Benefiting from the strong performance in its investment banking and currency trading operations, the Morgan Stanley Group, parent of one of Wall Street's leading brokerage firms, said yesterday that earnings in its fourth quarter ended Jan. 31 rose more than 7 percent from the comparable period a year earlier. For the full fiscal year, net earnings were also up more than 7 percent.

title: Plain & Simple; 2Dishes in 20 Minutes
description: HERE are two recipes that are so simple they can be prepared in less than 20 minutes. In fact, what takes the longest is cooking the pasta for this dish, wagon wheels with sun-dried tomato sauce. If you want to speed up the process, substitute fresh tubular pasta for the wagon wheels. For the side dish of lemony carrots, you can also save time by using already-peeled baby carrots.
