description: b-Net loss and included non-recurring items totaling $ 2,720,330 of net expense.

title: Rally Halts as Prices Fall Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, raising the yield on the 30-year bond to 6.88 percent, from 6.82 Tuesday.

title: Market Place; Insiders didn't take much of a gamble with Argosy Gaming.
description: IN any business, a regional monopoly can be a very profitable thing. At least until competition arrives.

title: French Skater Decides To Stay Within Lines
description: It was early on a gray European morning and the conversation quickly turned to the one subject guaranteed to transform Surya Bonaly into a chatterbox: the United States.

title: A New Kind of Housing That Brings People Together
description: CRUISING along Interstate 80, Charles Durrett smirked at all the Legolike condominiums that clutter the hillsides from Oakland to Sacramento. "Nothing but big fat roads leading to big fat houses," he said. "I saw a sign once for this one development that said, 'Live and Shop.' And it showed a happy couple with a mall in the background."

title: Enter the Once and Future King
description: George Steinbrenner is having fun again. He is in demand again and he is loving it, no matter how valiantly he tries to disguise it. There are still four days left before his two-and-a-half-year baseball suspension ends and he returns to power with the Yankees, but it seemed more like four minutes yesterday while a busy Steinbrenner hustled around his midtown hotel suite.

title: Rodriguez Helps Hunter Capture CUNY Title
description: Hunter College finished off its perfect season in the City University of New York Athletic Conference by dominating an undersized Medgar Evers squad, 104-73, last night for the Hawks' second consecutive title.

title: Heart Condition Will Force Aspin to Reduce Work, Pentagon Says
description: Defense Secretary Les Aspin will have to reduce his work schedule because of his heart condition and will perhaps need a pacemaker to deal with the ailment, a senior Pentagon official said today.

title: Events: Gardening Talks and Classes
description: Guides, Classes and More New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard , Bedford Park section of the Bronx; (718) 220-8777.

title: Christopher Leaving Mideast; No Date for Talks
description: Completing his first tour of the Middle East as Secretary of State, Warren Christopher is to leave the region on Thursday with no agreement on a date for resuming the peace talks.

title: Alka-Seltzer Plus To Foote, Cone
description: Miles Inc., Elkhart, Ind., has selected Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago to handle its Alka-Seltzer Plus cold remedy account, industry executives who insisted on anonymity said yesterday. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

description: The company said share amounts reflect the 30 percent stock dividend paid July 1992.

CHRONICLE
description: Just in case there's anyone left in California who hasn't gotten the message about physical fitness, there's a new messenger. Gov. PETE WILSON announced yesterday that he was appointing ARNOLD SCHWARZENEGGER as chairman of his new Governor's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. Other members of the council will include Sugar Ray Leonard, Tracy Austin, and Bruce Jenner.

title: Baldwin Piano & Organ (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Latest Austin Victory Puts Bite in Comeback
description: Tracy Austin's time warp continued today. Paired against an accomplished player -- No. 12-ranked Katerina Maleeva -- Austin moved her opponent like a pendulum, weathered a midmatch slump and won for the second time in two afternoons, 6-2, 2-6, 6-3.

title: DOOR MAY BE OPEN FOR ABORTION PILL TO BE SOLD IN U.S.
description: The president of the French company that makes the abortion pill RU486 told the Commissioner of Food and Drugs today that he believed the drug should be made available in the United States, the Commissioner said.

title: Piano Schools for Adults
description: To The Home Section:

title: Pottery And Such On Display
description: THE DAVIS & LANGDALE COMPANY usually deals in 18th-, 19th- and 20th-century American and English paintings and works on paper, but its owners, Cicely Langdale and Roy Davis, have also been interested in the British Arts and Crafts movement.

title: A Simmering Argument Despite Two Similar Pasts
description: John Rodriguez and Angel Jimenez shared common problems that could have bound them as friends. The two 15-year-olds were both in a special-education program for emotionally troubled students at Junior High School 25. Both came from families that have struggled to overcome financial troubles while trying to give their children an education. Both seemed to be searching for a place for themselves on the Lower East Side.

title: Court Considers Question of Aid To Deaf Student
description: With a sign-language interpreter translating the proceedings for the young man at the center of the case, the Supreme Court wrestled today with the constitutional implications of using government money to pay for such an interpreter in a parochial school.

title: Robert Tompkins Handville, Freelance Artist, 68
description: Robert Tompkins Handville, a freelance artist who designed postage stamps and covers for Sports Illustrated and other magazines, died on Monday at Barnstable County Hospital in Pocasset, Mass. He was 68 and lived in North Eastham, Mass.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WITH wallpapering, as with so many home decorating projects, obtaining professional results calls for knowing some refined procedures besides the basics. Virtually every room has at least one feature that can give a novice pause. Here are some hints for coping with common trouble spots.

title: Security Device Ruling Delayed
description: The board of the National Association of Record Merchandisers has postponed a decision on which type of theft-prevention technology its 850 members should use until it obtains the results of an additional study.

title: Microsoft Trademark Setback
description: In a case that echoes earlier fights over terms like "Light Beer" and "the Pill," the Federal Government has issued a preliminary decision denying the Microsoft Corporation a trademark for the word "Windows" on its hugely successful computer program by that name.

title: Longs Drug Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bonds Steps Onstage for Career's Second Act
description: Barry Bonds, dressed for his first workout as a member of the San Francisco Giants, walked into the team's Scottsdale Stadium dugout today and said, "It's cloudy."

title: DEERE PLANS TO EXPAND PRODUCTION THIS YEAR
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest producer of agricultural machinery, told shareholders yesterday at its annual meeting in Moline, Ill., that it would expand production this year for the first time since 1990. Hans W. Becherer, chairman and chief executive, said output would grow 5 percent this year, thanks to sharp reductions in inventories at dealers, renewed buying from American farmers and the appeal of new products. Growth would be even stronger, he said, but for declines in the European market, where debates about the level of farm price and production supports have made farmers cautious about investing in new machinery.

title: First, Islanders Pack Up Then Head Out Happy
description: Too much of a good thing isn't too good. In hockey, that includes home ice, where the Islanders have played five consecutive games and 11 of their last 14.

title: Missed Event Costs Jordan and Pippen
description: MICHAEL JORDAN and SCOTTIE PIPPEN of the Chicago Bulls were each fined $10,000 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for missing a news conference during the All-Star Weekend. The N.B.A. vice president of operations, ROD THORN, said in a statement that the fines were for "failing to appear at the media availability session" on the Friday before the All-Star game. The game was played on Sunday. It was not known why Pippen missed the news media session, but Jordan reportedly was playing golf.

title: Trial to Start Today in Los Angeles Beating Case
description: Last-minute legal hurdles were cleared and all the alternate jurors were seated today in the Federal trial of four Los Angeles police officers accused of violating the civil rights of a black motorist, Rodney G. King. That set the stage for opening statements on Thursday.

title: Books of The Times; Murders and Regrets in Southern California
description: The Cheshire Moon By Robert Ferrigno 285 pages. William Morrow & Company. $20.

title: Lifeline for Bosnia
description: President Clinton recognizes what some of America's allies prefer to deny -- that the people of Bosnia may starve long before peace can be negotiated. That's why he's about to throw the Bosnians a lifeline, dropping supplies by air to relieve the suffering.

title: A Defender of Redcoats Sets Out to Polish Their Image
description: IAIN HAIGHT-ASHTON loyally puts on a red-coated uniform of the British Colonial army when he participates in re-enactments of Revolutionary War battles, and he always knows what to expect from the spectators.

title: Russia's Big Sell-Off of Companies Gains Speed
description: The famous State Department Store on Red Square, best known by its Russian acronym, GUM, formally became private more than two years ago, when the trading company that leases the building was divided among the workers and the city.

title: Granite Construction (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rugs That Make The Room
description: EIGHT designers invited to put together vignettes at Darius, a newly opened antique rug emporium at 38 East 57th Street, are all members of Interior Design magazine's Hall of Fame. That is the common thread of a display at Darius tomorrow through to March 11.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13 HINDUS BARRED FROM PROTEST More than 45,000 Hindus across India have been arrested as they tried to travel toward New Delhi in response to a call from the main Hindu political party to join a demonstration against the Government. A1 CANADIAN LEADER TO RESIGN Brian Mulroney, Canada's 18th Prime Minister who solidified free trade with the United States but failed in efforts to reinforce unity between English and French-speaking Canadians, announced that he was retiring after eight-and-a-half years in office. A1

title: New Spring Training Drill: Schott Talk
description: Cincinnati Reds General Manager JIM BOWDEN met with the team to discuss players' concerns about owner MARGE SCHOTT and the use of racial slurs that got her suspended for a year.

title: Samuel Zuckerberg, Manufacturer, 82
description: Samuel Zuckerberg, a manufacturer in Manhattan's garment district who led fund-raising campaigns for Jewish charities, died on Tuesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park. He was 82.

title: Knicks Get a Call And Starks Delivers
description: A lot of calls went against the Knicks tonight, but the last call went their way. And as a result, New York pulled off one of its greatest escapes of the season, overcoming a 13-point deficit with six and a half minutes to play to stun the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Marina The Ballroom 253 West 28th Street Chelsea Through Tuesday

title: Buzz Buys L.A. Style
description: Buzz magazine, a monthly Los Angeles magazine, has acquired the assets of L.A. Style from the American Express Company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Integrated Health Services (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss for extinguishment of debt of $ 608,000 in the quarter and $ 2,524,000 in the year.The company said reported income in the 1991 quarter included a gain of 3 cents a share from use of a tax loss carryforward. Reported income in the 1991 year included a gain of 9 cents a share from use of a tax loss carryforward.

title: Litton Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago share earnings for both the quarter and year are restated to reflect 2-for-1 common stock split effective in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1992.

title: George Town Journal Their Prison Island: U.S. Policy Maroons Cubans
description: When Angel Garcia set out recently for Florida from the southern coast of Cuba in a stolen, overcrowded lobster boat, he figured that if he was picked up at sea it would be by the Cuban authorities, who would arrest him, or by the United States Coast Guard, which would rescue him.

title: Business Records reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax charge of $ 88,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary tax gain of $ 76,000, or 1 cent a share, in the year.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 416,000, or 9 cents a share, and $ 996,000, or 20 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Crotty Holds Small Lead In East Side Council Vote
description: With unofficial returns showing them separated by only 77 votes out of almost 15,000 cast in a special election, two candidates for a City Council seat on the East Side of Manhattan will have to wait more than a week to learn who won.

title: Swank Inc. (NSC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $ 1,775,000 gain from the sale of a division.

title: Home Alone at Justice?
description: Despite having no Attorney General, the Justice Department has handled one major controversy with distinction. Stuart Gerson, a Bush appointee sitting as Acting Attorney General, made a gutsy, fair call last week siding with Representative Harold Ford of Tennessee, who faces retrial for bank fraud, in his quest for a new jury.

title: Some of the Greatest Things Since Sliced Bread
description: IT's been an entire century since the first electric kitchen made its debut at the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago. On display in 1893 were an electric water heater, range, saucepan, coffee pot, tea kettle and chafing dish.

title: Employee Bonuses
description: Temperatures may be cold, but Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago warmed up its close to 600 employees by awarding each a bonus check for $100, after taxes. In a memo, Mitchell T. Engel, executive vice president and managing director at the Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, said the bonus was to congratulate the staff on what he called an outstanding performance last year for clients like Coors, Citibank and Kraft.

title: Chancellor Girds to Fight Bronx Board
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez moved yesterday to overrule a Bronx school board that refused to begin disciplinary proceedings against a principal accused of brutally humiliating an 8-year-old girl who said a custodian had raped her.

title: New York Unemployment Fund About to Run Out
description: The fund used to pay unemployment benefits in New York State will run out of money this week, and a Cuomo administration official today proposed a significant increase in business taxes to keep the system solvent.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: First-Aid Plant

title: Report Details School Superintendents' Salaries
description: A task force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that at least 26 public school superintendents received cash retirement packages of $100,000 to $230,000 in the last three years. The report on those payments, which are separate from the superintendents' pensions, is likely to fuel debate over school administrators' salaries.

title: For an Artist, Accomplishments Suddenly Made Her a Target
description: To her two attackers, Bonnie Bear, a graphics designer who was shot in the neck on Tuesday morning, must have looked like an easy mark, perhaps a wealthy out-of-towner loading the trunk of a silver Mercedes-Benz bearing Pennsylvania license plates.

title: Woman Is Slain at a Courthouse; Death Linked to 6 Bronx Killings
description: A woman accompanying her husband to the Bronx County Building for his court appearance yesterday was shot and killed by a man in a camouflage jacket and a bulletproof vest, the police said.

title: United Cities Gas (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Caldor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 2,812,000 from adoption of SFAS No. 109, ''Accounting for Income Taxes.''c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 3,557,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: Aerovox Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Year to Jan 2
description: b-Included charge of $ 228,000 from plant closing.c-Included charges of $ 2,000,000 from settlement of litigation and $ 262,000 from plant closing.

title: Japanese Cars Get British Accents
description: The Japanese auto makers, having entrenched themselves in the United States, are turning to what is perhaps the world's most hotly contested and most promising market: Europe.

title: Castle Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossYear-ago results are restated.Castle Energy said about $ 3 million of its net income for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1992 was earned by the company's 98 percent-owned refining subsidiary, Indian Refining Limited Partnership.

title: Pups Don't Bark; Birds Don't Chirp
description: HERE'S something for children of parents who feel beleaguered by pleas for more pets around the house: their very own pet store. Introduced by Kenner, the Littlest Pet Shop is a suitcase-like hinged plastic box equipped with shelves and compartments that can be filled with toy puppies, guppies and kitties, as well as a couple of chameleons.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included additional pretax reserve of $ 1,136,000 to cover higher than anticipated liability insurance costs in both the quarter and year.

title: Protectionism Doesn't Help Balance of Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: K-Swiss Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for prepayment penalty from early repayment of senior subordinated debt, net of $ 462,000 income tax benefit of $ 896,000, in both the quarter and year.

title: 60-Day Notice on Layoffs Undercut, G.A.O. Says
description: Few workers who lose their jobs because of plant closings or layoffs are given advance notice, despite a worker-protection law enacted in 1988, according to a study by the General Accounting Office.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CLEVELAND INDIANS -- Agreed to terms with Kenny Lofton, outfielder, on a four-year contract.

title: Review/Television; Just an Irish-American, Blowing Smoke
description: "Denis Leary: No Cure for Cancer" had an Off-Broadway run of several months last year. Now, trimmed slightly and directed by Ted Demme, it can be seen as a one-hour special on Showtime. Tonight's broadcast is at 9:30.

title: Try Time Stuffing: GetaLotMoreDone
description: IS the person at the other end of the telephone listening raptly, concentrating on your conversation? Most people want to think so, but it's probably not true. Chances are that this person is opening mail, writing checks, filing a nail or making a bed. But why not? Chances are, you're doing some of those very same things.

title: Hurley Will Have His Day on Court
description: Duke is expected to retire the No. 11 jersey of senior point guard BOBBY HURLEY before Sunday's home game against U.C.L.A. The honor is expected to come before the No. 9 Blue Devils play the Bruins on national television.

title: A New Worry: Going to Work Can Be Murder
description: In New York City, the leading cause of death on the job is not construction accidents, car crashes or machinery malfunctions. It's homicide.

title: George M. How, 35, An Architect, Is Dead
description: George M. How, an architect who helped to design the new NASA headquarters in Washington, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 35.

title: Ralston Unit Names BBDO Europe
description: Ralston Energy Systems in Geneva, the Ralston Purina Company's European battery unit, named BBDO Europe in Paris to handle its consolidated account, with billings estimated to exceed $25 million. BBDO already handles Ralston's Mazda and UCAR European battery brands, with combined billings estimated at $8 million to $10 million.

title: There's A History Behind the Slopes
description: People have been skiing in North America since the mid-1800's and for centuries in the Alps and Scandinavia, so it is not surprising that there are numerous ski museums around the world as well as a new association for ski history buffs.

title: 15-Year-Old Dies in Attack In School Hall
description: A 15-year-old student fatally stabbed a classroom rival at a Manhattan junior high school yesterday after a long feud between them flared into a deadly quarrel over a pair of sunglasses, authorities said.

title: Guaranty National reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 131,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 1,546,000, or 12 cents a share, in the year.c-After an extraordinary charge of $ 647,000 in the quarter and $ 439,000 in the year.

title: Eric Clapton Wins 6 Grammys With His 'Unplugged' Album
description: A self-effacing Eric Clapton won six Grammy Awards, sweeping the pop and rock categories, at last night's 35th annual awards ceremony in Los Angeles.

title: Indecent Disclosure
description: There's a big problem with proposed new Federal legislation to curb the influence of lobbyists. The lobbyists aren't rallying against it. That means Congress, aided and abetted by President Clinton, is getting ready to commit a giant hoax.

title: Mr. Mulroney Steps Down
description: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada may be unpopular at home, but he has been a good friend to the U.S., a close ally on global issues and a strong partner in demolishing trade barriers.

title: Suspect, 18, Is Arrested In Murders of 6 in Bronx
description: An 18-year-old man arriving at the Bronx County Building to appear in a drug case yesterday morning was arrested and charged with the murders of six people in a Mott Haven apartment on Feb. 14, the police said.

title: New Predictor Found for Giant Waves
description: Scientists say they have found a better way to predict when earthquakes will produce the deadly ocean waves known as tsunamis. The technique, they add, could save lives by providing timely warnings to the inhabitants of low-lying coastal areas.

title: Donaldson & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Foreign Affairs; Balkan Strategy, Part I
description: This column will explain U.S. interests and policy options in Bosnia and what I think should be done. The next will show how to get other nations to join in stronger, though limited, action.

title: Chainsaw Logic
description: The timber industry is using rising lumber prices to lure us subtly and otherwise into an unsettling equation. We are told that expensive lumber makes houses unaffordable. And we are told to blame environmental protection for these higher prices: How much are we willing to pay, the industry asks, to save a lesser species, the northern spotted owl?

title: ANUHCO SHARES SOAR ON NEWS OF $70 MILLION JURY AWARD
description: Anuhco Inc. shares surged 28 percent yesterday after the company and its American Freight System Inc. unit were awarded $70 million in damages from the Westinghouse Credit Corporation. A Kansas City, Mo., jury found that Westinghouse Credit, a subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, reneged on a 1988 commitment to provide $65 million of financing to Anuhco. Shares of the Overland, Kan., trucking company's rose $1.0625 to close at $4.875 in Nasdaq trading. Westinghouse Electric's shares fell 12.5 cents, to $13.25. Westinghouse Credit said it planned to appeal the verdict.

title: Architecture Exhibition Of Vernacular Design
description: Centerbrook Architects in Essex, Conn., has designed a house in Maryland with columns made of oak tree trunks that are two and a half feet in diameter, and another house in the Berkshire Hills in Massachusetts, where the main rooms are in what appears to be a barn, the office and meditation room in a silo, and the garage in a shed.

title: Mohawk Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $ 95,000, which was related to the company's initial public offering, in the quarter, and the year included a one-time charge of $ 3,568,000 related to the company's initial public offering.Mohawk said that results from Horizon Inc., acquired in October 1992, ''contributed positively'' to the company's earnings.As a result of the merger, Mohawk said, the number of Mohawk common shares on a fully diluted basis was increased from 10.5 million shares to 12.3 million shares outstanding.The share earnings and shares outstanding were fully diluted.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge for write-off of deferred financing costs from early retirement of debt and a debt refinancing of $ 1,583,000 in the quarter and $ 106,930,000 in the year.c-Net loss and included substantial interest expense that was reduced significantly by the recpitalization completed April 1, 1992. Giving pro forma effect to the recapitalization as if it had occurred on Jan. 1, 1991, the company would have had earnings before extraordinary item of $ 10.5 million, or 15 cents a share.d-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $ 591,000, or 2 cents a share.Latest results are restated to include its Central Moloney Transformer division as a continuing operation within the industrial segment as a result of the termination of the agreement to sell the division to Kuhlman Corp.

title: Mastercard tries to change its image in a campaign by Ammirati.
description: SHHHHH. Quiet, please. Dr. Ammirati and Dr. Puris, with a consultation from Dr. Fleischman of "Northern Exposure," are about to attempt a most risky surgical procedure, an advertiser imagectomy.

title: Biscayne Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included gains from refinancing and equity in net losses of investees of $ 714,000 in the quarter and $ 641,000 in the year.

title: Greece Investigates Arms Smuggling Case
description: The Greek Government said today that it had ordered its embassy in Nairobi to begin an immediate investigation into assertions that a Greek-flag ship has violated United Nations embargoes on Serbia and Somalia.

title:
DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
Houses That Have Their Roots in Books
description: THE American fascination with genealogy has moved beyond the family to the family home. Houses that for years were simply tagged Victorian or Greek Revival are taking on new identities. Many of their shapes can be located in pattern books, 19th-century volumes from which families that could not afford an architect chose a house pattern. In these books, one finds the gene maps of suburban and small-town American homes.

title: Wyle Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Wyle Laboratories said that the most recent fiscal year included a $ 947,000 pretax charge for an enhanced early retirement program at the company's Scientific Services & Systems Group.

title: Burglar Is Charged With 3 Rapes and Robberies
description: A convicted burglar who escaped from a halfway house in Connecticut last October was charged today in three rapes and robberies here over a six-day period. The authorities also said he was the only suspect in the murder of a young woman who was attacked in her apartment on Monday night.

title: AT WORK WITH: Matt Groening; The Fun of Being Bart's Real Dad
description: MATT GROENING would like to tell you a few things about his family:

title: High Court Limits U.S. Power to Take Property in Drug Cases
description: The Supreme Court today rebuffed the Justice Department's assertion of sweeping power to confiscate property tainted in any way by an illegal drug transaction.

title: Marshall Sparks UConn
description: Connecticut's Donyell Marshall blocked two shots and scored 5 points in the last 18 seconds of play tonight as the Huskies defeated Boston College, 69-64, for their sixth straight victory.

title: Horn & Hardart reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from early retirement of debt of $ 1,491,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9,201,000, or 24 cents a share, in the year, and the year also included a gain of $ 10,000,000, or 26 cents a share, which reflects cummulative effect of accounting change for income taxes.c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 17,619,000 in the quarter and $ 21,119,000 in the year, and an extraordinary gain from early retirement of debt of $ 6,915,000, or 29 cents a share, in both the quarter and year.

title: Piano Schools for Adults
description: To The Home Section:

title: Morgan Smith, 83; Photographer who Chronicles Harlem
description: Morgan S. Smith, who photographed American black leaders and celebrities and the life and culture of Harlem, died on Feb. 17 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 83 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: The Message Village Vanguard 178 Seventh Avenue South (at 11th Street) Greenwich Village Through Sunday

title: Coca-Cola Will Expand Into the Interior of China
description: The Coca-Cola Company expanded its status as the world's leading producer of soft drinks this morning by signing an agreement in Beijing with the Chinese Government to build or upgrade 10 bottling plants in the interior of the country.

title: The Clinton Track: New Turn In Story of Quarter-Mile Loop
description: Bill Clinton may not be particularly fast, sleek or graceful when he goes jogging along the streets of his adopted hometown, but a number of private citizens think enough of his athletic abilities to help finance a running track at the White House.

title: Review/Theater; The Afro-Cuban Gift To American Pop Music
description: Too often when American pop history is being discussed, the Afro-Cuban contribution is either ignored or given short shrift. But as "Nostalgia Tropical," an exuberant new revue at Playhouse 91 pointedly demonstrates, it is almost impossible to overstate the influence of the culture that produced the rumba, the cha-cha, the mambo and the conga. These dance rhythms and their echoes and offshoots have been so thoroughly absorbed into contemporary music that they are often taken for granted or referred to by vague catch-all terms like "Latin flavored."

title: Harland (John H.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 8.7 million in both the quarter and year.

title: Protectionism Doesn't Help Balance of Trade; Semiconductors
description: To the Editor:

title: Bond Set in B.C.C.I. Case
description: Robert A. Altman, law partner of Clark M. Clifford, the former Defense Secretary, was ordered yesterday to post a $500,000 unsecured bond while awaiting trial in the Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal.

title: SEOUL GIVES POWER TO CIVILIAN LEADER
description: Kim Young Sam took the oath today as this land's first nonmilitary President in more than three decades.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Nationsbank Retirement Is Reported
description: The vice chairman of Nationsbank, who was the architect of what some consider "the "greatest bank acquisition ever," will apparently adhere to his desire to take early retirement.

title: Malcolm Allen, 57, A Manager of Shows
description: Malcolm Allen, a general manager and company manager for dozens of Broadway and Off Broadway productions including "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" and "My Fair Lady," died on Monday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57.

title: Jaclyn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VF's Ex-President Replaces Founder as Gitano's Chief
description: The Gitano Group Inc., the financially troubled jeans manufacturer, announced yesterday that it had hired Robert E. Gregory Jr., the former president and chief operating officer of the VF Corporation, as its chairman and chief executive.

title: Assembly Revenue Figure Is at Odds With Cuomo's
description: Releasing its forecast for New York State's economy, the State Assembly said today that the state's revenues in the fiscal year beginning April 1 would be $550 million higher than Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has predicted.

title: Arnold E. Beermann, Newspaper Executive, 68
description: Arnold E. Beermann, a retired advertising executive for The New York Times, died on Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 68 and lived in Queens.

title: Let's Not Turn Korea Into a Trouble Spot
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stone Age Supernova May Have Breathed Fire
description: Two teams of astronomers have turned up evidence that a star as bright as the full moon exploded into view 340,000 years ago and that its dazzling radiation could have disrupted earth's protective ozone layer and sunburned our Stone Age ancestors.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Up 2.6% on Nasdaq
description: Reflecting the rising volatility among over-the-counter issues recently, the number of companies whose stock was sold short rose to 3,815, from 3,708 during the previous period.

title: Nets Take A Meeting, Then Take A Break
description: The All-Star break is over, but the Nets are still playing like they're on spring break. The atrocity in Charlotte on Tuesday served as an elbow to the gut, bringing them from the beach and back to the court. They played better against Boston tonight but lost, 103-88. This is not the same Nets team that went into the break on a roll.

title: Hancock Fabrics Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a charge of $ 5,657,000 from an adjustment in accounting.Hancock Fabrics said that its LIFO (last in, first out) charge for the fourth quarter and for the full year of 1992 was considerably higher than a year ago and negatively affected earnings per share comparisons by 5 cents and 8 cents for the quarter and the year, respectively.The LIFO charge included in cost of goods sold was $ 2,698,000 in the latest quarter, compared with $ 1,080,000 in the year-ago period. The LIFO charge in the latest year was $ 6,998,000, compared with $ 4,280,000 in the prior year.

title: Telephone & Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 769,000 in the quarter and year, and the year also included a charge of $ 6,866,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting change.c-Included charge of $ 5,035,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Review/Music; Pitching a Large Voice to a Small Space
description: In a relatively few years, Susanne Mentzer has established herself as a consistently satisfying presence in the international opera network. This reviewer knows her from performances at the Metropolitan Opera and in Santa Fe, but the American mezzo-soprano also takes her major roles from Covent Garden to La Scala and beyond.

title: Mr. Coffee (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary loss of $ 472,000 from the early repayment of debt in the quarter and year.

title: HCA-Hospital Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Results for the quarter and year included a pre-tax gain of $ 93 million, or $ 58 million after tax, or 32 cents per common and common equivalent share, for the quarter and 33 cents for the year, from the sale of the company's investment in the common stock of HealthTrust. In addition, results for all of 1992 included pre-tax charges during HCA's fiscal third quarter of $ 394 million, or $ 330 million after tax, in connection with the company's restructuring of its psychiatric division and sales of hospitals.c-Net loss and results for the quarter and year included a pre-tax gain of $ 221 million, or $ 162 million after tax, from HCA's sales of its investment in preferred stock and warrants of HealthTrust and pre-tax charges of $ 108 million for the year and $ 92 million for the quarter in connection with the writedown to net realizable value of five psychiatric hospitals and certain other properties and investments sold or planned for sale.The periods also included a pre-tax noncash stock option compensation charge of $ 413 million, or $ 256 million after tax, for the year and $ 359 million, or $ 223 million after tax, for the quarter, resulting from vesting of certain stock options and increase in the fair market value of the stock issuable upon the exercise of options.The company said share earnings results for 1991, as well as the average number of shares outstanding, are not reported as the company's initial public offering of common stock was not completed until March 1992.

title: No Headline
description: "Deterrence may not work in the old Soviet-American terms, but I'm convinced that having nuclear weapons still matters. It's not a mistake that Saddam Hussein never used chemical or biological weapons in the Persian Gulf war." -- GEN. LEE BUTLER, United States Strategic Command. [ B7:5. ]

title: INSIDE
description: Setback for Microsoft

title: U.S. Study of Drug Makers Criticizes 'Excess Profits'
description: A Congressional study of the costs of pharmaceutical development in the United States said today that even using the industry's own numbers and allowing for a substantial profit, drug companies still make "excess profits" totaling more than $2 billion a year.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A Mediterranean Corner

title: New Boston Garden Plan Finally Gets Green Light
description: After being deluged by calls, letters and petitions from sports-minded Bostonians, the Massachusetts Legislature passed a bill tonight allowing construction of a new sports arena to replace the 65-year-old Boston Garden, home of the basketball Celtics and the hockey Bruins.

title: Fernandez Doesn't Dwell On Health
description: Baseball is a noncontact sport that has broken Tony Fernandez up pretty well. His medical chart, in fact, reads like a Blue Cross-Blue Shield nightmare:

title: At the Bar; A judge's comments to co-workers conjure up memories of a disagreeable past.
description: Judge B. Joseph Fitzsimmons Jr. gave plenty of ammunition to his critics, including the Massachusetts Commission on Judicial Conduct. He sloughed off work and abused lawyers and litigants. He arrived in court late and left early, often for a nearby country club. Yet he chastised the unemployed, particularly women, when they came before him.

title: No Way to Pick a Comptroller
description: There's no sense in pretending otherwise: The process to select a successor to New York State's Comptroller, Edward Regan, is highly undemocratic. No election, no public participation, just a predetermined vote by a heavily politicked Legislature. The procedure, dictated by the State Constitution, is not about to change. Fortunately, Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin has persuaded his colleagues to open the process to some scrutiny by questioning the candidates at a public hearing.

title: Restaurants
description: Given the numbing sameness of so many new restaurants in New York City -- cookie-cutter Italian trattorias, predictable French bistros and how-much-can-you-eat homey American dining rooms -- it is exhilarating to see a venture as original as Vong, the new Thai-inspired restaurant on Third Avenue at 54th Street. Before going there, however, it's best to put aside your notions of New York Thai food.

title: State Budgets Mending After Years of Surgery
description: Finally emerging from the recession, nearly all the states are planning their first budgets in years without big tax increases or deep cuts in programs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about City Councilwoman Una T. Clarke's appeal to New York State to overhaul its inspection and monitoring of day-care centers referred incorrectly to a State Senator. He is Franz S. Leichter.

title: Arthur Markewich, 86, a Justice On Panel That Disbarred Nixon
description: Arthur Markewich, a retired Justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court, died on Wednesday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged on West 106th Street. He was 86 and a longtime resident of the Upper West Side.

title: Computer Uncovered 2 Suspects In Killings
description: At first, investigators met only silence. Looking for any thread that could lead them to the killers of six people, slain execution style in a Bronx apartment on Valentine's Day, they fanned out over the streets of Mott Haven only to find people were too terrified to speak.

title: 2d Trial Begins In Beating Case In Los Angeles
description: A second trial of four police officers accused in the beating of Rodney G. King began today with new showings of the now-famous videotape and a forceful prosecution statement that focused on the same evidence that failed to persuade a jury in a state trial last year.

title: June Bout for Foreman
description: The former heavyweight champion GEORGE FOREMAN will meet TOMMY MORRISON on June 5 in Las Vegas, Nev., promoters said yesterday. The fight, which was to have taken place April 16, will be televised on pay-per-view.

title: The Art Market
description: A Deal in Spain

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about the chamber group Continuum misstated the age of the composer Gyorgy Ligeti. Mr. Ligeti, who is to be honored in a birthday tribute next month, will be 70, not 80.

title: Article 648693 -- No Title
description: Every neighborhood seems to have an abundance of a particular kind of restaurant. On the Upper West Side, there are so many Chinese restaurants around Broadway and 96th Street that the intersection is called Sichuan Gulch. On the Upper East Side, the profusion of designer pizzas from wood-burning ovens may draw the attention of environmental regulators. And on this stretch of Avenue A in the East Village, every other block seems to have its Japanese restaurant.

title: Budapest Quartet Knew Glory After Schneider
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DIXONS GROUP P.L.C., London, has acquired Vision Technology Group Ltd., which owns the PC World chain of computer stores in England, for $12 million. GENERAL MOTORS CORP., Detroit, will suspend production at its car assembly plants in Ypsilanti, Mich., and Wilmington, Del., for one week starting Monday because of slow automobile sales.

title: Abroad at Home; Lessons of Yugoslavia
description: President Clinton's planned airdrops of food and medicine to besieged villages in eastern Bosnia have been called little more than symbolic. That is true. Planes flying at 10,000 feet to avoid ground fire will not be able to get many relief packages near their intended recipients.

title: Oilers Trade Murphy
description: JOE MURPHY, Edmonton's free-agent holdout, was traded to the Chicago Blackhawks yesterday. In return, the Oilers received defenseman IGOR KRAVCHUK and the junior forward DEAN McAMMOND, Chicago's top draft choice in 1991, currently playing with the Swift Current Broncos of the Western Hockey League.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY BRONX KILLINGS LINKED TO LOVE RIVALRY

title: Disasters With Nuclear Subs In Moscow's Fleet Detailed
description: Detailing new evidence of cold-war dangers, a report said yesterday that Moscow's nuclear-powered submarines had collided with foreign subs at least eight times over the decades and, separately, suffered at least four partial meltdowns of nuclear reactors.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Surprise Leaders Jay Don Blake, who has made a handsome living on the PGA Tour in recent years despite winning just once, birdied the final two holes yesterday to grab a share of the first-round lead in the $1 million Los Angeles Open. Blake finished with a four-under-par 67, tying him with Jim McGovern and Russ Beiersdorf, each looking for his first tour victory. Jeff Sluman, who finished second by one shot to Ted Schulz in the 1991 Los Angeles Open, and Ronnie Black each had 68. The defending champion, Fred Couples, opened with a 71. Blake, in his seventh year as a pro, earned $299,000 last year despite not winning a tournament. In the last three years, his earnings have totaled more than $1 million. (AP) NORDIC SKIING Ogiwara Leads Japanese Kenji Ogiwara became a double winner at the world Nordic ski championships yesterday in Falun, Sweden, leading Japan to the Nordic combined team title. Ogiwara, who won the individual gold medal last Friday, anchored the Japanese trio to a 3.46-minute victory over Norway. Germany was third, 8.30 minutes behind. Earlier, Russia took the lead for good on the second lap and cruised to a 19.4-second victory over Italy in the women's 20-kilometer cross-country relay. The gold medal was Russia's third in the championships. Norway leads with five gold medals. (AP) TRACK AND FIELD Powell Wins Down Under The world-record holder, Mike Powell of the United States, won the long jump yesterday in the NEC International meet at Olympic Park in Melbourne, with a mark of 27 feet, the longest ever in Australia. Powell set the world record of 29-4 1/2 in the 1991 world championships in Tokyo. Dave Culbert of Australia finished second in 25-7 1/2 and Gordon Laine was third at 25-3 1/4. (AP) TENNIS 7 Double Faults, 1 Victory Third-seeded MaliVai Washington overcame seven double faults and a strong effort from Marcelo Filippini for a 6-2, 3-6, 6-3 victory yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the Purex Tennis Championships in Scottsdale, Ariz. No. 7 Emilio Sanchez of Spain and an Australian, Mark Woodforde, had straight-set victories in the $275,000 ATP Tour stop. Sanchez needed tie breakers to eliminate Gabriel Marcos, 7-6 (7-1), 7-6 (14-12). Woodforde, who won the United States Indoor tournament in Philadelphia last week, continued his streak with a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Luiz Mattar of Brazil. (AP) Ivanisevic Gains: Second-seeded Goran Ivanisevic of Croatia advanced to the quarterfinals of the World Tennis Tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, yesterday with a 6-4, 5-7, 7-6 (7-5) victory over unseeded Amos Mansdorf of Israel. The hard-serving Ivanisevic is the tournament favorite following the withdrawal of an ailing Boris Becker. Among other matches, Anders Jarryd of Sweden easily moved into the quarterfinals, beating Paul Haarhuis of the Netherlands, 6-3, 6-4. Goran Prpic of Croatia, who on Wednesday upset fourth-seeded Richard Krajicek, lost, 6-2, 6-3, to Andrei Olchovsky of Russia. (AP) Wiesner Gains in Austria: Third-seeded Judith Wiesner of Austria advanced to the quarterfinals with a 6-3, 6-3 victory over Laura Golarsa of Italy in the EA Generali tournament yesterday in Linz, Austria. (AP)

title: Palestinians Are Expressing Hope On Both the Deportees and Talks
description: Although withholding an official response to an American and Russian call for a new round of Israeli-Arab peace talks in April, Palestinian negotiators said tonight that they hoped for a quick resolution of the deportees crisis so they would be able to attend.

title: AIG Earnings Up 7%; Equitable Cuts Loss
description: The American International Group, the nation's largest commercial and international insurer, reported 7 percent growth in 1992 earnings yesterday, which was surprisingly strong considering that it was a particularly bad year for industry-wide property casualty losses.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIAM E. SIMON, the former Treasury Secretary, and his wife, CAROL, have pledged $2.5 million to help Drew University build a gymnasium, the university announced yesterday at ceremonies on its campus in Madison, N.J.

title: In Test of Serbia Embargo, U.S. Presses to Seize a Ship
description: In a test of the West's ability to enforce the embargo on trade with Serbia, the Clinton Administration has urged its allies to seize a Greek-owned ship that recently delivered goods to Yugoslavia.

title: New York Police to Get Training in How to Testify
description: To help improve police credibility on the witness stand, the New York Police Department will revise its officers training program to put a special emphasis on courtroom demeanor and appearance.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRANK ZAPPA has often cited Edgard Varese as an inspiration. Eight years ago, when JONATHAN HAAS, a co-director of the Music Today Ensemble and a percussionist, noticed close similarities between a recording of a Zappa composition and a work by Varese, the proponent of atonal and electronic music, he wrote to Mr. Zappa and suggested putting on a concert featuring both works.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Arnold E. Beermann, a retired advertising executive for The New York Times, omitted his nickname. He was known as Barney, as was his son Arnold E. Jr.

title: Computer Shares Lead Most Stocks Higher
description: Computer stocks animated both the Big Board and Nasdaq trading yesterday, easily overpowering an opposite tug by a few medical and biotechnology issues.

description: Acoustic and Electric

title: Clinton and Yeltsin to Hold Summit Meeting April 4
description: President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia will hold their first summit meeting on April 4, in a third country still undisclosed, the United States and Russia announced today.

title: Court Restricts Phone Device As Police Tool
description: In a ruling that could affect hundreds of organized-crime and narcotics investigations across New York State, the state's highest court ruled today that judges have been too lenient in allowing the police to use devices that can identify telephone numbers and even listen in on calls.

title: Central Co-Operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Awards Presented In Direct Marketing
description: For the second consecutive year, Ogilvy & Mather Direct took top honors from judges of the John Caples International Awards for excellence in direct marketing. The 15th annual awards were presented yesterday in New York.

title: Diary Said to Reveal Bank's Tactics in Iraq Case
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee said today that a diary kept by a senior official of an Italian bank under investigation for its role in arming Iraq showed how bank executives had been determined to use political influence to avoid prosecution.

title: Communications Systems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Accounts
description: * Circus Circus Enterprises, Las Vegas, Nev., to Stranger & Associates, Los Angeles, to handle advertising for its Luxor hotel and casino scheduled to open in October. Stranger was awarded the account, with billings estimated to exceed $3 million, in a review that also included Pallas Advertising, San Francisco, as the other finalist.

title: Review/Art; How Beautiful Is Small and Vice Versa
description: For lazy art lovers, which means some of us all of the time and probably everyone in February, the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan is the place to be this weekend. The fifth annual "Art Show," organized by the Art Dealers Association of America, is in progress, and through Monday evening, 64 dealers from uptown, downtown and around the country are cozily and conveniently ensconced under one roof.

title: The Art of Interrogation
description: On Nov. 20, 1990, in Rostov on Don, Chief Inspector Issa Kostoev of the Russian Attorney General's office arrested Andrei Romanovich Chikatilo. Inspector Kostoev was convinced that Mr. Chikatilo, a 54-year-old industrial engineer, grandfather and zealous Communist, was the serial killer who had murdered and cannibalized women and children for 12 years throughout the Soviet Union.

title: New Issues Of Bonds Set Record
description: The corporate bond market was flooded with a record amount of new issues yesterday as borrowers continued to scramble to take advantage of low interest rates.

title: Arizona Braces to Meet Once-in-200-Years Flood
description: Audrey Sanchez and Patricia Fajardo stood in the yard with their five young children today and listened to the deputy sheriff urging them to leave the area as soon as possible.

title: Mutual Funds Draw a Rush Of Investors
description: Mutual funds that invest in municipal bonds are taking in cash from Americans at the fastest pace in history. And so are funds that invest in common stocks.

title: A G.M. Jobless Fund Runs Out; the 2d Is Solvent
description: A $1.7 billion fund paying benefits to about 14,000 laid-off auto workers at the General Motors Corporation will run out of money on March 1, almost seven months before the automobile union's three-year contract with G.M. expires, the company said today.

title: Charles Callison, Conservationist And Audubon Leader, Dies at 79
description: Charles H. Callison, former executive vice president of the National Audubon Society and a major figure in the conservation movement, died on Tuesday at University Hospital in Columbia, Mo. He was 79 and lived in Jefferson City, Mo.

title: A creative talent at a big agency jumps ship for 'entrepreneurial' shop
description: A PROMINENT creative executive is returning to her roots.

title: EXTENSION GRANTED FOR MACY'S REORGANIZATION PLAN
description: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland yesterday approved a request by R. H. Macy & Company for an extension of the filing deadline for its reoprganization plan, rescheduling the deadline from today to Sept. 30. During that period, Macy can submit its plan without competition from other proposals. Myron Ullman, the company's co-chairman, said Macy's needed the extension because, except for last month, it had failed to meet financial projections since filing for Chapter 11 protection in January 1992.

title: Troops Suppress Hindus' Protests In India Capital
description: Firing tear gas and wielding bamboo staves, the riot police prevented a rally here today by Hindu nationalists demanding the resignation of the Government of Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao.

title: Benjamin B. Rosenberg; Accountant, 79
description: Benjamin B. Rosenberg, an accountant who worked for District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan and later for the New York State Harness Racing Commission, died on Friday at his home in Deerfield Beach, Fla. He was 79.

title: Review/Film; Urban Horrors, All Too Familiar
description: In the eerie opening sequence of "Falling Down," a man identified by his license plate as D-Fens (Michael Douglas) sits in his car, brought to a halt in a gigantic Los Angeles freeway tie-up. The stalled lanes of glass, chrome and paint jobs sparkle in the midmorning sun, which is very hot. Nothing moves except the tiny beads of sweat on the man's face. They slip down his brow from his military-style brush haircut to his jaw, which is clenched against life. The man grips the steering wheel and stares straight ahead through gold-rimmed glasses.

title: Amato's 'Don Giovanni'
description: The Amato Opera, under the direction of Anthony Amato, is to begin a 10-performance run of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. and Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Each of the performances, which are to take place on weekends through March 28, will feature a different cast. At the Amato Opera Theater, 319 Bowery at Second Street, East Village. Tickets are $16; $13 for seniors. Information: (212) 228-8200.

title: Surprise: Elliot Is the Giants' Franchise Player
description: In a surprising move yesterday that placed free-agency restrictions on three of their top players, the Giants designated offensive tackle Jumbo Elliott as the team's franchise player and outside linebacker Carl Banks and inside linebacker Pepper Johnson as transition players.

title: American Air Agrees to Limit Fare Data
description: American Airlines said yesterday that it would "reluctantly" comply with a Justice Department consent decree that prohibits carriers from giving advance notice to travel agencies of fare changes through their computerized reservation systems. But American vowed to continue to fight the decree, which, if approved by the court, would be in effect 10 years.

title: S.E.C. Cites Japanese
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said American branches of some of Japan's biggest brokerage firms had violated securities laws by reimbursing losses of favored customers, hiding millions of dollars in foreign-exchange losses and fraudulently buying Treasury securities.

title: Nunn Is Arrested
description: The World Boxing Association supermiddleweight champion, MICHAEL NUNN, was arrested on an alcohol and weapons charge early yesterday after being pulled over in Orion, Ill., police deputies said. Nunn, 29, of Davenport, Iowa, was freed after posting $100 bond. Deputies said two containers of beer and a 9-millimeter handgun were found in the car. Both charges are misdemeanors. (AP)

title: Not Everybody's Running to the Garden's Big Party
description: It is the height of the indoor track and field season, but not everybody is attending the house party.

title: A Little Ignorance Helps Dutch Player Rout Austin
description: Tracy Austin finally played someone who had hardly heard of her today, and the result was disastrous. Stephanie Rottier, a Dutch teen-ager, treated Austin like just another 30-year-old, drilled a barrage of untouchable backhands and put Austin back into the bridal shower business with a 6-1, 6-0 thrashing.

title: Shift on Congressman's Trial Stirs Fury at Justice
description: While awaiting the confirmation of a new Attorney General, the Clinton Administration has run the Justice Department through a hybrid management team led by a conservative Republican holdover from the Bush Administration and a former Arkansas law partner of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

Maiden Voyage, Smooth Sailing
description: Warren Christopher isn't known for dramatic gestures, but he does have a reputation for competently managing complex and dangerous crises. He used his first overseas voyage as Secretary of State to tackle two big challenges on the foreign policy agenda -- reviving the stalled Middle East peace talks and reaching out to Russia and its embattled President, Boris Yeltsin.

title: Dull Devils Get Sharp Treatment
description: The goaltending sharpness of Craig Billington and the steadiness of the Devils defense, displayed two nights ago in Pittsburgh, were nowhere to be found here tonight.

title: Editorial Notebook; An Emergency That Need Not Be
description: Congress thought it had solved the problem of expiring unemployment benefits when it passed an "emergency" law last July. The law was designed to prevent future emergencies by giving states the power to enact extra benefits when they were needed. But the states did nothing and now Congress finds itself forced to do it all over again. It's an example of how Washington politicians can get caught up in problem-solving that solves nothing.

title: Audi Might Cut Jobs
description: The German car maker Audi A.G., a subsidiary of Volkswagen, might cut as many as 9,000 jobs, or 24 percent of its work force, within the next five years, a company spokesman said today. Audi employs 37,500 people at plants in Ingolstadt and Neckarsulm. It said last year that it planned to cut 4,000 jobs by the end of 1993. The spokesman said an internally circulated memorandum quoted the figure 9,000 for possible job cuts within five years.

title: New York Classrooms Looking Bad but Better
description: New York City school officials said yesterday that physical conditions in the city's public school classrooms were improving overall but that deterioration in many classrooms "remains a serious problem."

title: Review/Music; New Ways Of Honoring Tibetans' Old Ways
description: There were a number of times during "The Great Miracle Prayer Festival" at Town Hall on Wednesday night when a listener might have wondered whether the events on stage had much to do with the annual Tibetan Buddhist celebration of the same name. For 2,000 years, as part of the festival, monks have performed prayers and religious ceremonies and celebrated with the people; this benefit for Tibet House was meant to be a contemporary continuation.

description: Here on a stony meadow in West Texas, at the end of 10 miles of unpaved road through mesquite-covered, coyote-infested scrub land, several hundred bearers of a strategic commodity of the United States of America are gathered.

title: HIGH SCHOOL SPORTS: At Elizabeth High School; Manchild in a Land Of Gift and Promise

title: PFIZER TO REPURCHASE AS MANY AS 20 MILLION SHARES
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back as many as 20 million shares of its stock during the next 24 months. Pfizer has about 323 million shares outstanding. The health-care products company said it had completed its repurchase program for 10 million shares that was authorized in August. Shares of Pfizer's stock closed yesterday at $57.125, down 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Questions Follow a Slaying in a School
description: John Rodriguez and Angel Jimenez were headed to their fifth-period pro-skills class, the session devoted to lectures on dealing with frustration without punching people and on containing anger without blowing a fuse. Instead, the police charge, John stabbed Angel to death on their way to the class.

title: Parents Wary of Change As Integration Looms
description: TO visit Duffy School and talk with its parents is to be reminded how good public education can be, and how thoughtful and generous parents can be. It is also to step right up to the chasm that separates suburbs and cities, a chasm of race and class, hope and fear, that few parents will lightly ask their children to cross.

title: Woman and Son, 2, Are Found Slain In Staten Island Apartment
description: A 27-year-old mother and her 2-year-old son were found shot and bludgeoned to death yesterday in their apartment in New Brighton, Staten Island

description: The Bavarian National Ballet, an excellently schooled classical company that opened its two-week debut engagement in the United States on Wednesday night, can trace its roots, as do many other German troupes, to organized ballet activities in the 18th century.

description: Italy's rapidly widening corruption scandal gnawed further into the country's business and political elite today with the resignation of a leading politician, the arrest of one of the country's richest industrial barons and the apparent suicide of a Government official implicated in the affair.
