title: Raid Poses Risks at Angkor
description: The magnificent ruins of Angkor, which few foreign travelers dared to visit during Cambodia's long civil war, are once again a risky travel destination.

title:
On Long Island With Rising Tide;
A New Wave of Food, a Dash of the 60's
description: THERE'S a Grateful Dead song that goes, "Got some things to talk about, here beside the rising tide."

title: Miss Muldowney, Nils Dahl 3d
description: Christine Muldowney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Muldowney of Alpharetta, Ga., was married yesterday to Nils S. Dahl 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nils J. Dahl of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Timothy Brown performed the ceremony at St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church in Middletown, R.I.

title: Have Suburban Prices Hit the Bottom?
description: THE market for one-family homes in the suburban New York metropolitan region, much of which has been in decline for the last five years, appears to have bottomed out in most areas, and, in some places, such as Northern New Jersey, a modest recovery seems to be under way.

title: An Offbeat Play Is Nicely Repulsed
description: THE piggyback tournament has been getting some tryouts in the last five years. The format consists of two overlapping competitions, one a string of elimination minimatches, the other a Swiss-system tournament comprising the players who were knocked out of the first. Each has its own prizes.

title: LONE STAR
description: Your article on Ann Richards will reinforce the conviction many Americans have that our present-day political system doesn't attract people of solid accomplishment to run for office.

title: LONE STAR
description: I gloried in your coverage of our Governor. We are all very proud of Ann Richards.

title: Chanel Goes to the Front
description: There's a new boot camp in town along Fifth and Park avenues, where the first rank of a new fashion army is strutting in lace-up black Chanel boots. With spit-and-polish gold metal plaques riveted to the back and double-C logos embellishing the toes, the boots help to secure the wearer's fashion status, both coming and going. And why not -- at $1,190 a pair? With thick crepe soles, they are the Chanel challenge to Doc Martens. The boots come with 7 or 16 eyes, and the taller versions are topped with three buckles. Whoever said high fashion was effortless? While a few women wear them with slim below-the-knee suit skirts, most pair them with leggings, stirrup trousers or narrow-legged jumpsuits, all topped with a variety of sporty parkas, Chanel jackets and even a blond sable. The look includes an abundance of Chanel gold-chain accessories -- necklaces, hatbands, belts and straps for black quilted shoulder bags -- not to mention gold buttons, zippers and earrings. There's even a leather Chanel biker's cap. In redesigning the Chanel look, Karl Lagerfeld has given the boot to the signature sling-back shoe.

title: Beleaguered Bosnian President Meets With Gore
description: The President of Bosnia and Herzegovina, Alija Izetbegovic, conferred with Vice President Al Gore today on the Bosnian conflict, and after a 90-minute meeting Mr. Gore issued a statement saying he had "expressed the profound hope that an equitable and durable solution would be found to the problems of former Yugoslavia."

title: Connecticut Q&A: George E. Chartier; When Audience and Actors Are Neighbors
description: GEORGE E. CHARTIER of Vernon has been involved with community theater for more than a dozen years, mainly behind the scenes, and has now put his experience into a book, "Full House: The Definitive Guide for Successfully Promoting School and Community Theater."

title: FEB. 21-27: In in Seoul; Kim Vows to Ride Tiger To Reform in South Korea
description: Asia has been transformed over the past decade by a single force: feverish economic development. The inauguration of Kim Young Sam in South Korea just may herald the emergence of a new regional force: political reform.

title: Profile/Michael Viner and Deborah Raffin; Selling Books to a Generation That Won't Sit Still
description: ONE evening six years ago, Michael Viner, a producer, sat down to play backgammon with a longtime friend, the novelist Sidney Sheldon. The stakes were high. Mr. Sheldon promptly lost $8,000 to Mr. Viner.

title: Tika Pinther, William Brewer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Miklos Pinther of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tika Liang Pinther, to William Logan Brewer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Brewer Jr. of Stamford, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Caught Between Homes
description: WITH tax time at hand, people who have had their home on the market for a long time are pondering the tax consequences of whether and when to sell. If they have already vacated their home and bought another, the decision may be filled with stress as they approach a key time threshold -- two years years after they have purchased a new home without having sold the old one.

title: CRYING WOLF OVER ELEPHANTS
description: Ray Bonner correctly characterized World Wildlife Fund's 1989 decision to support a worldwide ban on ivory trade as difficult. But the debate was among conservationists, not between conservationists and fund-raisers.

title: Forget The Fight: Islanders Win Game
description: Twelve minutes into today's contest between the Islanders and the Flyers, not a single player stood on the ice. All that remained of a free-for-all -- sticks, gloves, helmets and a puck -- was strewn from blue line to blue line as most of the 17,380 fans at the sold-out Spectrum, understanding the urgency of the overall situation, stood on their feet and cheered wildly.

title: New Rochelle
description: To the Editor:

title: Caught in Tale of Revenge and Death
description: To those who knew him, Elliot Lopez did not seem to be the sort of teen-ager likely to be seduced by the street code of easy money, short tempers and rapid retribution. A star athlete with a ready smile, his goal was college and a way out of a South Bronx neighborhood whose streetcorners were dotted with dozens of other young men who had long ago traded the promise of the future for the grim pickings of the present.

title: Corps of Engineers Looking Warily for New Role
description: The Army Corps of Engineers, once the well-oiled machine that could be counted on to move earth and perhaps even a piece of heaven with the right Congressional appropriation, is agonizing in the opening days of the Clinton Administration over reorganization, lean budgets and belt-tightening.

title: A Remembrance of Whitney Biennials Past
description: It may be the exhibition that New York loves to hate, but the world would be a duller place without the Whitney Biennial to kick around every two years. This informative, if hardly infallible, barometer of contemporary art has been part of the scene since 1932; its latest incarnation, which will include 80 artists, will arrive on Thursday.

title: Alternative Magazine Changes With the Times
description: WHAT goes around, comes around. It happens in fashion and politics, and it has happened to The Aquarian Weekly.

title: Apology Not Accepted
description: After Oriole scout FRED UHLMAN opined that Mexicans lack speed because of genetics, but were good infielders and dancers because they have good rhythm, he apologized and was reprimanded by club president LARRY LUCCHINO . That's not good enough for the national council of La Raza, a national Hispanic organization. The Washington-based lobbying group told Lucchino on Friday that it wants both Uhlman's resignation and an investigation. (AP)

title: Perspectives: Park Slope Condominiums; Finding the Iron Hot, Young Buyers Strike
description: A PROFESSIONAL bass player named Yasutomo Takeda has yet to meet a professional sax player named Jeff Lederer. But once they meet they will find they have more in common than their careers.

title: Mediums With Messages
description: Nino Fidencio was a Mexican folk healer who lived in the northeastern state of Nuevo Leon in the early part of the 20th century. When he died at the age of 40 in 1938 (at the hands of jealous doctors, his followers believed), he was the country's most prominent healer -- it was even said that he had cured the Mexican President of a serious illness. Since his death his cult has spread, particularly among Mexican-Americans in south Texas; tens of thousands make a pilgrimage to his tomb every year. NINO FIDENCIO: A Heart Thrown Open (Museum of New Mexico Press, $34.95) presents a reverential look at the experiences of his contemporary followers through Dore Gardner's documentary photographs of the pilgrims, and through testimonials from the women who are his mediums. Frequently these women go to Nino Fidencio's shrine (often over the objections of their husbands) seeking to cure themselves or their children of debilitating illnesses after traditional medicine has failed. If they or their children are healed, the women often pay their debt by allowing Nino Fidencio's spirit to take over their bodies so that they may cure others, and by making the arduous pilgrimage to the remote village where he lived. Few who knew Nino Fidencio are still alive, and details about his life are vague and subject to constant revision by his devotees. An essay by the folklorist Kay F. Turner offers some historical and psychological insight into the cult, but more information would have been welcome, not only about Nino Fidencio but about his followers as well. For example, biographical sketches of the people giving testimonials might have made clear that many references to Nino Fidencio are actually about a medium who has taken on his spirit in a trance. However, this book offers a fascinating glimpse into a little-known phenomenon as well as a testament to the power of belief.

title: Emily Bakemeier, Alain Moureaux
description: Emily Paviour Bakemeier, a candidate for a Ph.D. in art history at Princeton University, is engaged to be married to Alain Gislain Moureaux, the president of Moureaux Associes, an international investigative company in Paris and in Princeton, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: World Atomic Agency Needs Beefing Up
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Ways to Install Sinks: Freestanding or Vanity
description: THERE are two types of bathroom sinks. One is freestanding, which is mounted directly on a wall and sometimes supported by legs or a pedestal, and the other is the vanity sink, which is attached to or part of a vanity top. Installing a vanity sink is fairly easy, but installing a freestanding one can be more challenging.

title: Sally MacCowatt And Josh Black
description: Mr. and Mrs. Haskell P. MacCowatt of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sally Pawling MacCowatt to Josiah Milton Black, the son of Timothy N. Black and Martha W. Black, both of Washington. A July wedding is planned.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Bristol, R.I.; State's First Law School
description: CONTINUING an expansion that began in 1969 when it moved from Providence to this seaside community, the 3,600-student Roger Williams University is just a few months away from completing Rhode Island's first law school.

title: Estate of the Art
description: All it the paradox of contemporary house design: Everybody wants a new house that looks old but acts new. Window seats and gables, moldings and fireplaces -- these are the elements that make a home livable, not a machine for living. And yet, along with modernism and its stripped-down esthetic came bigger rooms, more light and circulation patterns that flow the way people actually live. So what's an architect to do?

title: CURRENCY
Getting a Custom House From a Factory
description: THE weather outside is frightful, but inside the factory of Westchester Modular Homes in Wingdale, N.Y., workers are building houses as if it were summer.

title: In Tireless Pursuit of Key West
description: The budgets for the $500 weekends covered accommodations, sightseeing and food and drink, but not the cost of transportation to and from the cities.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 14 about feminism and rock music misstated Sue Cummings's position at L.A. Weekly. She is a senior editor.

title: Correction
description: A report on Feb. 14 about the wedding of Chase Reynolds and Charles Ewald omitted the education of the bridegroom's mother, Dr. Mary T. Ewald. She holds a Ph.D. in English philology.

title: Great Riffs. Big Bucks. New Hopes?
description: Alternative rock doesn't seem so alternative anymore. Every major label has a handful of guitar-driven bands in shapeless shirts and threadbare jeans, bands with bad posture and good riffs who cultivate the oblique and the evasive, who conceal catchy tunes with noise and hide craftsmanship behind nonchalance. Meanwhile, the independent labels that first exposed the style -- some people still call it Amerindie rock, despite the new corporate presence -- have kept up production, as bands proliferate and commercial hopes expand.

title: Taxes and Subsidies For and From Olympus
description: The one argument against Olympus that I find totally incomprehensible is the assumption that it would endanger drinking-water supplies [ "The Olympus Dispute's Broad Reach," Feb. 7 ] . How could 600 people in an office building accomplish this catastrophe when the same area housed 1,000 people and a working staff of 2,000 without contaminating the water supply?

title:
Viewpoints: Choices for the Clinton Era;
Time for Fairness on Health Premiums
description: AS Hillary Rodham Clinton is surely aware as she tackles the issue, health care is expensive, no matter how you slice it. But in America, we are now slicing it in the most unfair way imaginable.

title: INSIDE
description: Bosnian Plight Said to Ease

title: Don't Cut Jobs, Cut Working Hours . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Music for Antiquity
description: Annual benefit recital, Pierpont Morgan Library, Feb. 22.

title: Kevorkian's Backers Outnumber His Foes At Michigan Protest
description: Separated by police officers, the two sides in the growing debate over doctor-assisted suicide demonstrated today in front of Dr. Jack Kevorkian's apartment here in this Detroit suburb.

title: Technology; From the Rugged Outback, A Quick-Fix Modular Tire
description: ALAN R. BURNS has reinvented the wheel, or at least the tire around it, and now finds demand outstripping supply for his modular tires. During years of traveling through Australia's outback as a mining surveyor, Mr. Burns learned that in off-road conditions, conventional air-filled tires are subject to multiple hazards that cause tire loss and costly down time on the job.

title:
YOUR TAXES;
Making the Many Weather Disasters of '92 Deductible
description: THE unprecedented number of storms, hurricanes and other disasters that battered wide areas of the country last year is expected to result in a sharp rise in claims for tax deductions for casualty losses on personal property. A total of 45 areas were declared Federal disaster areas, surpassing a previous historical high of 43 set in 1991.

title: Library Buys Piece Of Altman's
description: Dormant three years, the mammoth limestone building at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street that was once B. Altman's flagship is showing signs of life.

title: At Work; Straddling the Law on Layoffs
description: WHEN Congress passed legislation in 1988 requiring companies to give 60 days' notice to workers who were about to lose their jobs, it was trying to put a tourniquet on the wounds of America's industrial heartland. Business howled, as it tends to do over measures it views as fettering its options. President Ronald Reagan, who vetoed the measure once and only reluctantly let it slip through on a second pass, used to refer to the law -- known formally as the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Act, or WARN -- as "a ticking time bomb in the back seat of any medium-sized or larger company."

title: Small College Builds a Team Dynasty
description: GOOD as she is, Allegra Schell is used to being overshadowed by male basketball players. Though she was the star of a Providence high school team that won back-to-back state championships, Ms. Schell and the other members of her Central High School team played second fiddle to Abdul Abdullah, currently a star at Providence College, and the rest of the school's boys team, even though she gave Mr. Abdullah a run for his money in their occasional one-on-one games.

title: Moose-Hunting in Japan?
description: Just a few years ago, it seemed as if nothing could pry fashionable young Tokyoites away from such symbols of youthful self-expression as Louis Vuitton handbags and Valentino suits.

title: Nowadays, Nets Can't Shoot And Can't Beat Anybody
description: Three. It's supposed to be a charm. But just try telling that to the New Jersey Nets, who are in the midst of a three-game slide since the All-Star Game break and are staring at another possible loss when they face the Knicks (36-17) on Sunday afternoon at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about efforts to appeal the conviction of Bonnie Foreshaw, who is serving a 45-year sentence for murder, referred incorrectly to Mary Werblin, a lawyer involved in the case. She lives in Woodbury, not Stonington.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: KEEPERS OF THE FLAME The Role of Fire in American Culture, 1775-1925. By Margaret Hindle Hazen and Robert M. Hazen. Princeton University, $29.95.

title: Hartford Benefit for People With AIDS
description: A PAIR of benefit concerts can be heard today at 4 P.M.: the double bassist Gary Karr and the pianist Harmon Lewis will play in Hartford at Immanuel Congregational Church, while choral and instrumental ensembles of South Church in Hartford will perform at the Second Congregational Church in Middle Haddam in a program directed by Richard Donohue.

title: Talking: Appraisals; Getting Around the Evaluation
description: SINCE the residential real estate market took a turn for the worse in the late 80's, buyers, sellers and owners struggling to refinance have seen their plans repeatedly undermined by the low values appraisers have pinned on their homes.

title: Hair Gone, Heart to Follow?
description: Loss of hair has symbolized a loss of strength since Samson's fall in Biblical times. Now new evidence lends support to the mythical equation -- at least regarding the most important human muscle, the heart.

title: In a Wheelchair
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade's column provided excellent tips for travelers with mobility impairments. As Ms. Wade mentioned, the Air Carrier Access Act of 1986 has improved passenger services for people who use wheelchairs, as well as overall airport and aircraft accessibility.

title: A Dancer Dances, Against All Odds
description: DAWN STORRS could hardly have been happier. Classes at Torrington High School had just been dismissed for the Christmas break, and she and five friends -- two other cheerleaders and three male athletes -- got in a car and headed for Waterbury to do some last-minute shopping. It was early afternoon on Dec. 23, 1988, and a mixture of snow and sleet was falling as their car traveled along Route 8.

title: EXPLOSION AT THE TWIN TOWERS: The Dead; Casual Choices of Workday Prove Fatal to 5 at Disaster
description: Had it happened on almost any other day, it might not have mattered to them, for their habit was to be elsewhere at lunch time.

title: Elizabeth Jakes, David Wykoff
description: Dr. and Mrs. William C. Jakes of Andover, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Knight Jakes, to David Hayes Wykoff, a son of Faith A. Wykoff of Manchester, Mass., and James H. Wykoff of Prides Crossing, Mass. An April wedding is planned.

title: With the 1993 Athletics, Introductions Are the Order of the Day
description: The subject is not restricted to fans and reporters. It has infiltrated the Oakland Athletics' clubhouse, too.

title: Ex-Officer Guilty in Sale of Information to Gotti
description: A retired New York City police detective pleaded guilty on Friday to selling secret police information about the mob to John Gotti and other crime figures.

title: On Per-Bag Garbage Systems
description: I read with interest the Jan. 17 article on per-container trash systems ("Per-Bag Garbage System Creeps Along"):

title: A Fabled City From China's Past
description: "BUS to Quanzhou!" the bucktoothed conductor was urgently shouting. "Immediate departure!"

title: Home Offices: Tough, Not Impossible
description: STEPHEN SAVITT, a New York City lawyer, opened two offices last year: one in Manhattan, where he spends about 80 percent of his working hours, and one in his home in Forest Hills, Queens, where he spends the other 20 percent. At the time, he intended to take a Federal income tax deduction on his 1992 tax return for his office in the home.

title: Taking a Chance on Cairo
description: THE night before we flew to Cairo early in January a friend called to remind us to pack our flak jackets. Our daughter, Hester, said, "You're crazy," and asked where we kept our wills. The idea was that anyone who had been reading the newspapers should know that Egypt was infested with Islamic fundamentalists bent on terrorizing the $4 billion-a-year tourist trade, as vital an economic lifeline as the Nile itself. Our response to these alarms was a mix of set purpose (to see tombs, temples and monuments we'd known about since the third grade), skepticism (there had only been a scattering of incidents and no evidence that tourists from other countries were staying away) and a rough actuarial calculation that told us that Egypt was a safer bet than Mexico (famous for bus plunges), Milan or Route 6, the murderous highway that runs the length of Cape Cod. As it turned out, the only anxiety-provoking moment in the entire trip came when a camel tried to crush one of us against a wall.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HOW I LEARNEDShort Stories.By Gloria Frym.Coffee House Press, paper, $11.95.

title: Betrayed by Their Protectors
description: LEAD US NOT INTO TEMPTATION

title: Mementos of Stress In the 1860's Economy
description: WHILE President Clinton is going around the country trying to sell his economic recovery program, it's nice to think that things have changed a lot in 130 years. President Lincoln had trouble selling not only his policies but also money itself.

title: Wall Street; Some Dissatisfaction in Disneyland
description: MINNIE and Mickey Mouse were strolling around, characters from the hit movie "Aladdin" were on display, and the Anaheim, Calif., Convention Center was packed with kids who probably do not consider financial reports required reading.

title: On Turning 13: Reports from the Front Lines
description: Yesterday, Chelsea Clinton became a teen-ager. The Week in Review asked an eighth-grade social studies class at the New York City Lab School for Gifted Education, a public junior high that selects students with diverse backgrounds from all over the city: "What did it feel like when you turned 13?" Here are excerpts from their written responses.

title: Fletcher Knebel, Writer, 81, Dies; Co-Author of 'Seven Days in May'
description: Fletcher Knebel, co-author of the best-selling cold war novel "Seven Days in May" and a retired syndicated newspaper columnist, died on Friday at his home in Honolulu at the age of 81.

title: Civil Rights Roster
description: To the Editor: Thank you for the article on the new Civil Rights Institute in Birmingham (Travel Advisory, Jan. 17).

title: The Rope
description: WHAT: The ultimate icon of New York night life. A tube of burgundy velour or velour blend -- but seldom real velvet -- three to six feet long, held up by aluminum or steel stanchions. It's used to guard the doors of all night spots that aspire to hotness. WHERE IT RULES: Everywhere that's anywhere: China Club, Grand, Club USA, a Susanne Bartsch party. Up to 800 people wait behind it on Saturday night at Webster Hall. Getting past it requires prospective patrons to be (a) on the list or (b) beautiful or famous enough not to have to be on the list. Those who are neither may wait humiliating hours only to be told, "Sorry, private party." Erich Conrad says the only people his rope excludes at the Friday party he promotes at the Supper Club are the "glamourphobic" ones. "Unfortunately," he said, "on weekends New York is littered with glamourphobic people."

title: EXPLOSION AT THE TWIN TOWERS: The Precautions; With Talk of a Bomb, Security Tightens
description: Police and public safety experts throughout the New York region yesterday drew a tight security net around the city's airports, hotels, major tourist spots and other vulnerable public spaces, moving the city to an alert level not seen since the Persian Gulf war.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CONVERSATIONSStraight Talk WithAmerica's Sister President.By Johnnetta B. Cole.Doubleday, $17.50.

title: Colleges Luring Black Students With Incentives
description: George Watson is a high school senior in great demand. More than 100 colleges have sent him unsolicited application material, filling two crates in his house in South Orange, N.J. Some have offered to waive their normal $35 application fee. One invited him for an all-expenses-paid visit. Another promised him a $20,000 scholarship, although his parents own a successful business.

title: Programs That Teach Students the Basics
description: WANT to start young people off with a solid grasp of photography? Take a look at two programs, one sponsored by Fuji and the other by Eastman Kodak.

title: 2 Dead and 1 Hurt in Brooklyn Apartment
description: Three people were shot, two of them fatally, in an apartment in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

description: BOOK SIGNING

title: Madrid Museum For Blind People
description: A museum designed primarily for people who are blind or visually impaired, where visitors are encouraged to touch the exhibits, has opened in Madrid. The Tiflological Museum, one of the few of its kind in the world (another is the Musee Valentin-Hauy in Paris), emphasizes tactile appreciation of the arts while maintaining a visual presentation for sighted visitors. Exhibits are accompanied by audio tapes that guide the visitor's hands over the exhibits. Pamphlets printed in both large-type characters and in Braille are provided.

title: Small Change
description: To the Editor: Beware of currency exchange in Greece. The bank authorities welcome exchanges from dollars into Greek currency, but discourage exchanges back into dollars by imposing exorbitant bank charges.

title:
ART;
Private Visions Dare The Public Eye to See
description: NORWALK Community-Technical College is mainly housed in a rather handsome but sprawling modern structure here; the ground floor is reminiscent of a bazaar with all sorts of distracting activity.

title: Who Paid the Bills at Mansfield Park?
description: CULTURE AND IMPERIALISM

title: Neil Simon Faces Humor's Hurtful Side
description: ALL through an astounding career that has flourished for more than 30 years, Neil Simon has teetered on the brink of an artistic breakthrough. He has adapted Chekov ("The Good Doctor"), retold the tale of Job ("God's Favorite") and dabbled in ancient Russian folklore and mysticism ("Fools"). In its filmed version, his chronicle of an alcoholic actress ("The Gingerbread Lady") had a title change that intimated the Simon credo of comedy: "Only When I Laugh." None of these departures from the playwright's customarily glib comedies were successful.

title: POSTINGS: Lecture at the Y; Assessing Big Projects
description: What is the real impact of such megaprojects as Riverside South on their immediate neighborhood and on the city at large?

title: BABY SITTERS' BOSS TELLS ALL
description: Baby sitters' boss is going to have a hard time keeping all those people on her domestic payroll once she starts reporting their earnings (Hers: "Baby Sitters' Boss Tells All," Feb. 7).

title: Courtney Bauer, C. B. Burnham
description: Mrs. Henry P. Warren of Delray Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter Courtney Anne Bauer to Christopher Bancroft Burnham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Burnham of Stamford, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 7 about the appointment of an environmental specialist from Greenlawn as a trustee for a bankrupt manufacturer in Brooklyn misidentified the company. The company in bankruptcy is Plated Plastics Industries, Inc., not SC Plated Plastics Industries, Inc. Because of an editing error, the article also referred incorrectly to the trustee, James Schirripa. He is chief executive of Life Support Sciences Inc. of Greenlawn, and is not a lawyer.

title: FEB. 21-27: The Middle East; Christopher May Do More Than Just Listen Well
description: Warren Christopher set out on his first trip to the Middle East as Secretary of State with a modest agenda: listen well, get acquainted and try to bring Israel and the Arabs back to the negotiating table.

title: Finally, Someplace Fed Up Enough To Stop Fighting
description: IT is not easy imposing peace on people when they are bent on killing each other. That much is clear from the Balkans, Angola, Cambodia and other fresh holes in the graveyard of good intentions.

title: 2 Counties Press Their Cases Against Mandates
description: TALK of radical change echoed last week in the office of Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a politician not noted for straying farther from the middle of the road than conditions compel.

title: U.S. URGES NATIONS TO SPEED GROWTH
description: Its standing boosted by tentative signs of economic recovery at home and enthusiasm abroad for its new deficit-reduction plan, the United States encouraged the other major industrial nations today to do more to stimulate world growth.

title: Pedophiles and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's That Masked Man? It's Richter
description: Mike Richter hasn't had many moments like this one this season. His Rangers teammates were wandering by to congratulate him. His coach was singing his praises. He was smiling, looking confident and -- get this -- enjoying himself.

title: Maupin's 'Dream of the Future, Set in the Past'
description: Armistead Maupin still remembers Hollywood's first pass at developing a screen version of "Tales of the City," his funny and affectionate novel of San Francisco circa 1974. "Tales" follows the interconnected lives of a melange of characters, gay and straight, and their emotional, social and sexual meandering, which all seem to lead to a mystical place called 28 Barbary Lane. As Mr. Maupin recalls it, in 1979 Warner Brothers was set to produce "Tales," which originally appeared as a series of daily columns in The San Francisco Chronicle.

title: Celebrating Sassoon
description: The father of cutting-edge hair styles. F.I.T., Feb. 22.

title: Semak and the Devils Slam Door on Senators
description: Aleksandr Semak has been the most productive member of the Devils the last month, but he was kept scoreless in two games before the Devils met the Ottawa Senators this afternoon.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Roots of Bosnia's Anguish
description: When Yugoslavia was still a country, foreigners complained that political arguments seemed never to get beyond the year 1945. After Yugoslavia crumbled, startled outsiders discovered that Serbs spoke of the Battle of Kosovo in 1389 as if it had happened yesterday. Now that horizon needs another shove: the sources of blood hate are even remoter in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: Sarah Bleasdale, John Coleman Jr.
description: Sarah Marvel Bleasdale, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. T. Bleasdale of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married yesterday to John A. Coleman Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Coleman of White Plains. The Rev. Michael McClan performed the ceremony at the Good Shepherd of the Hills Episcopal Church in Cave Creek, Ariz.

title: 3 Killed and 10 Injured in a Brooklyn Fire
description: Two children and an adult were killed and 10 people were injured when fire swept through a two-story house in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn yesterday morning.

title: Does She Or Doesn't He?
description: IN rock, hair style proves tribal allegiance, but it's also a crucial form of personal expression, especially for men. Over the last decade, ambiguity has dominated the hair scene, as a wide array of male rockers explored their masculine/feminine selves with mousse in hand. The following brief history of rock hair over the decade tries to reveal those developments. Jon Bon Jovi serves as a guide, because he is not a tortured artist, but a rock-and-roll Everyman. As goes Mr. Bon Jovi's hairdo, so goes the rock nation.

title: An Effective Weapon Against Premature Births
description: To the Editor:

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
For a Boy Wonder, Composing Has Become a Painful Chore
description: Wearing an ancient wool sweater, smoking cigarettes and swigging diet soda, Oliver Knussen radiates an easy informality. An ungainly bear of a man, Mr. Knussen, with his rumpled exterior and self-deprecating humor, suggests anything but an anguished composer wrestling with his art.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;
New State Rules for Affordable Housing
description: AFTER nearly two years of review the New Jersey Council on Affordable Housing has released revised rules for municipalities to meet their share of the 83,000 low- and moderate-income Mount Laurel housing units it estimates the state will need through 1999.

title: SURFACING
description: HOLLYWOOD -- Instant remakes: If you thought you'd seen it before, you may have. At least three new movies ("Sommersby," "Point of No Return" and "The Vanishing") are American versions of recent foreign films ("The Return of Martin Guerre," "La Femme Nikita" and "The Vanishing"). POLITICS -- President Clinton on CD-ROM: A high-tech President if there ever was one. A new CD-ROM release, "Portrait of Victory," traces his last months on the campaign trail. APOLOGIES -- Who's sorry now?: February must have been National Apology Month. Mea culpas were issued by Ann Landers (for misrepresenting a letter writer), Marky Mark (for misunderstandings with Asians and gay people) and NBC (for rigging a test of G.M. trucks).

title: A Terrible Thing to Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Harcsar, Stephen Purdum
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Harcsar of Rumson, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Curry Harcsar to Stephen Edward Purdum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Purdum of Mendham, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: Congress Hears the Public And Moves Behind Clinton
description: President Clinton's economic plan gained support in Congress this week as lawmakers sensed that their constituents favored it and were willing to pay a price for lowering the budget deficit.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Still Photos Trace The Moving Image Of Blacks
description: Motion pictures, needing shortcuts and symbols to speed communication, are a most ingenious device for the production and dissemination of stereotypes. When it comes to black Americans, the stereotypes have been particularly potent and lasting (although other groups are not lacking for reasons to complain). As late as 1970, John O. Killens, a black film writer, said that the movie industry was "the most anti-Negro influence in this nation." It has filled many minds with pictures of happy blacks having fish fries in a "Green Pastures" heaven and Butterfly McQueen as a flustery pickaninny with a weak-tea voice in "Gone With the Wind."

title:
Viewpoints: Choices for the Clinton Era;
I Get Social Security. I'll Sacrifice, Too.
description: I'M glad to hear that President Clinton is looking at Social Security as a place to cut spending. This is one Social Security recipient who for years has been tired of hearing that others must tighten their belts but that I and my fellow 60-, 70- and 80-year-olds must not be asked to sacrifice any of our benefits -- even those who could afford to.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OFFICIAL AND CONFIDENTIALThe Secret Life of J. Edgar Hoover.By Anthony Summers.Putnam, $25.95.

title: Royal at Last; 3-2-1 Smile
description: KRISTEN McMENAMY was flattened out like a basset hound on a vintage green sofa in a dressing room at Webster Hall on Tuesday night. Totally relaxed, the 28-year-old model with the plain Jane eyebrowless face was having six red ribbons painted down her back by two women dressed in black. The audience at the Mardi Gras benefit for the American Foundation for AIDS Research would get to see those ribbons later on, when Ms. McMenamy dropped her dress after being crowned queen of the jubilee by Leanza Cornett, the reigning Miss America.

title: Where the Trail Began: 3 River Towns
description: IN the spring of 1843, in what came to be known as the Great Migration, 200 families and 120 wagons heaped with their belongings left Independence, Mo. Leaving "the States," these emigrants went in search of land and a better life in the lush green wilderness of what Francis Parkman, the 19th-century historian, called "barbarous Oregon," a foreign land then claimed by both the United States and Britain.

title: How Clinton's Stimulus Plan Cuts Into Deficit; Social Security Siege
description: To the Editor:

title: The Voice of the New York School
description: THE COLLECTED WRITINGS OF ROBERT MOTHERWELL

title: Don't Confess to Anything You Didn't Do
description: TESTING TESTING Social Consequences of the Examined Life. By F. Allan Hanson. Illustrated. 378 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $28.

title: Dread Days in American History
description: "WHO do you think you are?" Alexander asked Young Mickey in 1968, when they were both 13 years old. A young black in the South Bronx who wrote poetry, took piano lessons, played baseball, practiced karate and aspired to be somebody -- that's who Mickey thought he was.

title: Pedophiles and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Diary/February 21-26
description: THE ECONOMY The Numbers Are Up, but Belts Are Tight and Consumers Edgy

title: A School's Role in Getting Students to the Stage
description: THEIR names pop up regularly now in theater reviews, news of the film world and celebrity profiles. Graduates of the State University of New York's division of theater arts and film at Purchase have reached a kind of critical mass and their success is drawing attention to the program that helped start their careers.

title: Subaru Introduces a New Subcompact
description: REMEMBER the good old days, when cars were named after things we knew ? Animals, birds, even fish.

title: On the Trail of the Pioneers in Oregon
description: THEY call themselves rut nuts. These are the people who love the Oregon Trail, what's left of it, and probably wish they had been among the 300,000 pioneers who rode (actually, most walked) almost 2,000 miles to find the promised land in Oregon. Now that the 150th anniversary of the first wave of emigration over the Oregon Trail is approaching, rut nuts are popping up everywhere.

title: Cheer Up, It Could Be Worse
description: THE tax season may be bleaker than usual this year, what with taxpayers getting smaller refunds or writing bigger checks as a result of George Bush's decision to withhold less tax -- but not reduce the liability -- during the 1992 campaign. And with the new President, Bill Clinton, likely to raise taxes not once, but twice, in coming months.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Jan. 24 with an article about traveling by bus from Newark, Del., to Old Saybrook, Conn., gave incorrect times for two of the legs. The No. 5 bus of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transit Authority leaves Third and Market Streets in Philadelphia at 10:15 A.M. and arrives at the Bridge-Pratt Terminal at 10:57. The Milford Transit No. 1 bus leaves Stratford, Conn., at 11:30 A.M. A reader's letter dated Feb. 3 led to further research.

title: New Look In Car Tags To Aid Wildlife
description: HAVING approved license plates celebrating everything from hot rods to ham radios, the Legislature is on the verge of passing bills that would create specially decorated auto-tags dedicated to protecting the shoreline and the state's wildlife. If the measures become law, they would for the first time earmark license plate fees for a cause other than the State Treasury.

title: CUNY Reorganization Unites Students and Faculty in Anger
description: In the two months since a panel appointed by Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds announced a sweeping plan to reorganize the City University of New York, an intense and emotional battle has spread across many of the system's 20 campuses, testing the ability of Dr. Reynolds to sell such a far-reaching proposal.

title: Florio Gains In Popularity, New Poll Says
description: Eight months before New Jersey voters elect a new governor, there is more evidence that the incumbent, Jim Florio, is slowly but steadfastly making a political recovery.

title: Making a Difference; An Executive Laugh-In
description: WEARING pajamas in public. Gluing toilet paper rolls to his feet. Standing backward in elevators.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OFFICIAL AND CONFIDENTIALThe Secret Life of J. Edgar Hoover.By Anthony Summers.Putnam, $25.95.

title: Joe Henderson Pushes the Limits
description: In June 1963, the tenor saxophonist Joe Henderson embarked on a series of recordings for Blue Note Records that count as some of the best jazz albums ever made. Henderson used the projects to advance jazz harmony with gorgeously intelligent, occasionally dissonant tunes that quickly became standards. In an era of polarization, the music preached balance, mixing experimentation with hard-driving swing.

title:
DANCE;
Troupe With a Smooth and Breezy Style
description: THERE are no swans on the programs of the American Repertory Ballet Company. Rather, there are "dust devils," "swamp demons," an occasional quartet of goddesses and, coming up Friday at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, references to a "rabbit-chasing, water-drinking wiener dog" that figures prominently in Septime Webre's newest work, "Shoogie."

title: These Fire Engines Spark The Imagination
description: Toy fire engines are among the trappings of childhood that often evoke two kinds of nostalgia in adults -- for the toys and for their real-life counterparts. These miniatures spark memories of sirens in the night, not to mention the hook-and-ladder toy owned decades ago or the pumper that remained in a shop window.

title: Capitalist Diasporas
description: TRIBES

title: RECORD BRIEF
description: June Tabor: 'Angel Tiger'

title: CRYING WOLF OVER ELEPHANTS
description: I will never be prouder of any action taken by the African Wildlife Foundation than its leadership in protecting the African elephant by calling for an end to its destruction ("Crying Wolf Over Elephants," by Raymond Bonner, Feb. 7). A total ban on commercial trade in ivory made sense, and will continue to make sense until the elephant numbers rebound and the healthy principle of sustainable use of natural resources takes root. PAUL T. SCHINDLER President, African Wildlife Foundation Washington

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Life in the Rural North Fork Alternative
description: THE North Fork, stretching from Riverhead to Orient Point, has never been developed as a vacation mecca, probably because it lacks oceanfront beaches like those in the Hamptons on the South Fork.

title:
MUSIC;
A Series Seeks to Woo Audience of the Future
description: "OUR goal is to say, 'Here we are!' to a new and future audience," said the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's resident conductor, Peter Rubardt, speaking of the orchestra's "Panorama Concerts for Families," a three-concert series now in its first season.

title: Tantalizing Appetizers, Served Up by City Ballet
description: As things turned out, there was more new choreography than originally scheduled for the New York City Ballet's recent season. Peter Martins, the troupe's artistic director, offered three premieres, and William Forsythe appended a completely new duet to a slightly revised version of "Herman Schmerman," a piece he had created last year for the company's choreographic showcase, the Diamond Project.

title: In the Region: Connecticut; A New Train Station for South Norwalk
description: LIGHT is finally appearing at the end of the South Norwalk railroad station tunnel. Nearly five years after the idea of upgrading the station was put forth, and after a major setback, planning is now under way. They are considered a key to the city's continued revitalization.

title: Battered Women: How Pictures Speak
description: THEY are not pretty pictures: women with bruised and blackened eyes, tear-streaked, swollen faces, a leg torn open by a knife, a tire track across an abdomen. They could be photographs of prisoners of war.

title: What Do You Expect Living Along the L.I.E.?
description: It's most timely to read "Expressway Noise Walls Disputed" [ Feb. 14 ] . The whole project should enrage overburdened taxpayers. Why is the public so acquiescent and silent about this blatant waste of taxpayers' dollars?

title: Campaign Reform: An Idea Whose Time Drags On
description: THOUGH President Clinton has vowed to change how candidates get elected by pushing through a campaign finance reform package, the passage of a serious bill anytime soon is far from assured. Congress has its reasons for stonewalling. And so, after all, may the President.

title: At Your Front Door, a Remnant of 50's-Era Medicine
description: BOUNDING out of his car, Dr. Luigi M. Capobianco looked like robo-doc. A cellular phone stuck to his ear. A beeping beeper clung to his waist. And a hi-tech plastic stethoscope hugged his neck.

title: Lucile B. Olson, Richard Huber Jr.
description: Lucile Bello Olson, the public relations officer for the division of arts at the Organization of American States, was married yesterday to Richard Miller Huber Jr., an environmental specialist at the World Bank. Both work in Washington, where the wedding took place at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. James T. Maier performed the ceremony.

title:
TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Air Security Little Changed In Frankfurt
description: Despite persistent criticism, security procedures at the Frankfurt Airport, the Continent's largest and busiest air hub, have not substantively changed since a Lufthansa jetliner en route to Addis Ababa was hijacked to New York City on Feb. 11, according to officials from Germany's Interior Ministry. The Ethiopian hijacker was armed with a harmless starter's pistol that he smuggled aboard under a wide-brimmed fedora hat.

title: New Issues: Sellers Win, Buyers Lose
description: Initial public offerings, as any broker will be happy to tell you, are often great investments. They are your chance to get in on the ground floor, to share in the growth of business.

title: Weather Disruption to Last a While, Data Show
description: Precise measurements of ocean currents made by a new satellite show that El Nino, the warm current that flows along the Pacific coast of South America and, among other things, has given California its rainy and snowy winter, will persist into the spring and maybe the summer, scientists said Friday.

title: On Turning 13: Reports from the Front Lines
description: Yesterday, Chelsea Clinton became a teen-ager. The Week in Review asked an eighth-grade social studies class at the New York City Lab School for Gifted Education, a public junior high that selects students with diverse backgrounds from all over the city: "What did it feel like when you turned 13?" Here are excerpts from their written responses.

title: All the Publisher's Presidents
description: POWER, PRIVILEGE, AND THE POST

title: To Make His Own Marc
description: Marc Jacobs is a very talented fashion designer, but he's a pretty strange salesman.

title: Pedophiles and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: S. Gregg Renfrew, William D. Orr
description: Susan G. Renfrew and Robert M. Bender of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Renfrew's daughter, Susan Gregg Renfrew, to William Dennison Orr, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Orr of Darien, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: State's Case Links Poverty to Students' Performance
description: THE Sheff v. O'Neill desegregation trial is nearly over, and soon a single Superior Court judge, Harry Hammer, will take on the task of sorting out Connecticut's responsibility for how poorly children do in the public schools of Hartford.

title: Budget London
description: To the Editor: Readers of the "Pound-Wise Guide to Off-Season London" (Jan. 10) might be interested in knowing about a couple of our new British Tourist Authority brochures that are available free of charge. They are "London Accommodation for Budget Travelers" and the newly revised "London Guide." Both can be requested from B.T.A. offices in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Atlanta. BEDFORD PACE Director, public relations, U.S.A. New York

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 14 about "Significant Others," an exhibition at the Kraushaar Galleries, omitted the name of the curator. She is Amy J. Wolf. The article also misstated the number of artists in the show who are living. There are eight.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: February 28, 1993
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 THE PELICAN BRIEF, by John Grisham. (Island/Dell, $6.99.) A woman law student probes the murder of two Supreme Court justices. 2 6 ALL AROUND THE TOWN, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket, $6.50.) The plight of a college student accused of killing her professor. 3 4 BYGONES, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Jove, $5.99.) A dinner party reveals family strains and love. 4 10 RISING SUN, by Michael Crichton. (Ballantine, $5.99.) A woman's death leads to an investigation involving the American-Japanese rivalry. 5 57 THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Island/Dell, $5.99.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. LP indicates that a book is available in large print.

title: Do-It-Yourself Autobiography, Ready for Prime Time
description: Frankie C. always strapped on a gun when he ventured into his bullet-pocked North Philadelphia neighborhood. Now the stocky young gang member packs something else: a video camera. "The camera is my weapon," he says. "For people living here, eyes are a punishment. But I'm going to take this camera and film the pain straight up."

title: Capitalist Diasporas
description: TRIBES

title: The Biggest Place There Is
description: DESERT TIME

title: EXPLOSION AT THE TWIN TOWERS: The Background; A Long List of Possible Suspects, as Inquiry Into the Bombing Begins
description: Trying to determine who might bear responsibility for Friday's huge explosion at the World Trade Center, Federal officials are examining chronologies of terrorist groups in search of clues showing similarities in methods.

title: On Turning 13: Reports from the Front Lines
description: Yesterday, Chelsea Clinton became a teen-ager. The Week in Review asked an eighth-grade social studies class at the New York City Lab School for Gifted Education, a public junior high that selects students with diverse backgrounds from all over the city: "What did it feel like when you turned 13?" Here are excerpts from their written responses.

title: Loves of a Young Hustler
description: MARTIN AND JOHN By Dale Peck. 228 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $21.

title: Jana N. Fromer, Scott H. Cook
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Fromer of New York have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Jana Nicole Fromer and Scott Henry Cook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Cook of Salt Lake City.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 14 about a new library building in Paris misstated the administrative affiliation of the Jussieu campus. It is a branch of the University of Paris.

title: EXPLOSION AT THE TWIN TOWERS: The Investigation; Bomb Is Definite Answer, But All Else Is Mystery
description: Working with puzzle-pieces of seared wreckage, chemical traces and disjointed telephone messages, investigators from New York City to the White House struggled yesterday to decipher the mystery of the blast that ripped through the World Trade Center on Friday, killing at least five people and injuring more than 1,000.

title: Martha Fein, Todd Miller
description: Dr. Richard Fein and Dr. Helen Fein of Cambridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Martha Susan Fein to Todd David Miller, a son of Harley Miller of Canton, Ohio, and the late Elaine Miller. A June wedding is planned.

title: Leigh Weatherly, Anthony E. Flint
description: Michael M. Weatherly of Southport, Conn., and Eloise J. Weatherly of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter Leigh Manning Weatherly to Anthony Evans Flint, the son of George S. Flint of New York and Mary Alice Flint of Princeton, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Beth T. Vesel, Frazier Moore Jr.
description: Beth Terace Vesel, a literary agent for the Sanford J. Greenburger Associates agency, and Frazier Moore Jr., a television critic and reporter for The Associated Press, both in New York, were married yesterday. Jean Somerville Kotkin, an Ethical Culture Society leader, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: This Week's Numbers
22 Years as a Class Enemy
description: A SINGLE TEAR A Family's Persecution, Love, and Endurance in Communist China. By Wu Ningkun, in collaboration with Li Yikai. 367 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $21.

title: EXPLOSION AT THE TWIN TOWERS: The Scene; An Underground Crater Filled by Twisted Debris
description: From above there was little indication yesterday of the enormity of the damage, only the lingering stench of smoke, the bent heap of the metal doors to the parking garage and the litter of rescue and repair on West Street, in the lobby of 1 World Trade Center and along the arcade that connects the center's buildings.

title: How Clinton's Stimulus Plan Cuts Into Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: The Tricky Details of Refinancing
description: THE wave of mortgage refinancing last year prompted victorious smiles among the legions of homeowners who cut billions of dollars from their monthly payments. But the advent of tax season brings a fresh challenge: winning maximum deductions for last year's paper shuffling.

title: Dancers Stepping Out, Mexican and Modern
description: MANY events are scheduled today in the Westchester area, including ballet performances, piano recitals and vocal and chamber concerts.

title: Where Nearly 10,000 Exotica Contend
description: IN this city of a thousand cities, the area around Broadway and Canal Street is looking a lot like Hong Kong. Teeming with shoppers, its stalls brimming with cheap watches and sidewalk fashions, Chinatown has edged its way into SoHo.

title: Works That Take Humanity as It Comes
description: BENNY ANDREWS arrives at the State Museum here with quite a record. Since his first solo show, in Manhattan in 1962, there have been maybe three or four years when the artist has not been visible, alone or in group, somewhere in the United States or abroad. Images by him are hanging at two galleries in Detroit and Atlanta and at the Butler Museum of American Art in Youngstown, Ohio. Many more are to be found in public collections, notably those at the Metropolitan Museum, the Museum of Modern Art and, in New Jersey, the Newark and State Museums. As he himself put it in a recent conversation, "I keep working at my work," adding that he takes pride in "still being around, like Richard Nixon."

title: Chinese Suffer From Rising Pollution As Byproduct of the Industrial Boom
description: Each winter the air here takes on the fragrance of sulfur, the acid fog becomes so dense that planes are often delayed, and the wilted leaves drop from the Chinese evergreen trees like portents of the early deaths that some here will suffer.

title: Besieged President of Zaire Goes Home to New Turmoil
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire ended a weeklong visit to France today for dental treatment and returned home to a political situation that was further complicated by army threats against an interim Parliament.

title: NOTES
description: In March, Stagebill, the program for performances at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center, will have a red AIDS ribbon on its cover. The cover was planned to coincide with "Music for Life," a benefit for the Gay Men's Health Crisis at Carnegie Hall on March 14.

title: Sydney L. Whitman, Caterer, 84
description: Sydney L. Whitman, the owner of a large kosher catering house in Brooklyn, died on Monday at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. He was 84 and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Voracious Venison

title: Data Update
Yugoslav Borders
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Is Taking 'the Return' in Stride
description: Gene Michael welcomed a reporter into his office this morning by smiling and then quickly posing a question. "So are you here to do a story on me getting fired?" he asked.

title: Tech Notes; Video Games in a Big Way
description: VIDEO game fanatics with more than a few quarters to burn are the target of a new control device for Nintendo and Sega game systems that is as big as some children.

title: Steps Remain in School Case
description: Testimony in the Sheff v. O'Neill desegregation case has ended, but months will pass before a decision is handed down and more than a year before a final legal judgment is likely. These are the steps that remain in the lawsuit's progress:

title: Roadside Attractions To Reckon With
description: Architects who hope that infrastructure holds the magic key to rebuilding American cities need to reckon with a sobering truth: throughout this century, infrastructure -- highways, communications, even mass transit -- has been the major force responsible for dismantling American cities. And they will also have to reckon with Frank Lloyd Wright -- the greatest "infra structural" architect America has produced.

title: Foreign Affairs; Balkan Strategy, Part II
description: The main problem with my idea of limited Western intervention to create a fair fight in Bosnia is that I can't sell it to anyone in power. Even if President Clinton bought it, he would have a very tough time getting Western Europe, Russia or the U.N. to go along.

title: Steinbrenner Is Back With His Old Pitches
description: What the advertising executive Jerry Della Femina saw in the lobby of the Regency Hotel in Manhattan on Tuesday morning was unexpected and peculiar: George M. Steinbrenner, momentarily all alone, with no one to talk to. "But he had this look that said, 'I dare you not to recognize me,' " said Della Femina.

title: You Can't Take the Hackensack Out of This Guy
description: Not only does pro golfer Jim McGovern share his hotel room with his caddie, he also lets the caddie heap T-shirts, socks and putters all over the carpet.

title: Seeing Is Believing
description: BLACK LOOKS

title: FEB. 21-27: Penny-Wise at the Pentagon; Defense Chief a Casualty In Retreat From Profligacy
description: It makes sense to a lot of Americans that the Pentagon is slashing billions from its budget in recognition of post-cold war realities. But it didn't make sense last week when penny-pinching claimed Defense Secretary Les Aspin as victim.

title: FEB. 21-27: Anti-American Riots; From Hunger Pangs To Withdrawal Pains In Still-Violent Somalia
description: In Somalia, the American military is learning a new lesson in the difficulty of graceful exits.

title: On Turning 13: Reports from the Front Lines
description: Yesterday, Chelsea Clinton became a teen-ager. The Week in Review asked an eighth-grade social studies class at the New York City Lab School for Gifted Education, a public junior high that selects students with diverse backgrounds from all over the city: "What did it feel like when you turned 13?" Here are excerpts from their written responses.

title: Alison G. Finn, J. M. Bogert Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Finn 3d of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Alison Gallagher Finn to Jeremiah Milbank Bogert Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bogert of Bedford Hills, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: Michael Reisman, Elizabeth Comte
description: Elizabeth Anne Comte, a reporter in New York for Forbes magazine, and Michael Jonathan Reisman, a sports-marketing executive, plan to marry in June.

title: Wall Street; Cisco's Stunning Rise Puts It in the Big Leagues
description: FOR those who bought in at the February 1990 offering price of $4.50, adjusted for splits, Cisco Systems, now at $87.75, has been one of Wall Street's greatest recent successes. For the many who sold it short, hoping to profit from a decline, it has been a graveyard.

title: Wall Street's Rivalries Yield in Drive to Help Neediest Cases
description: Wall Street analysts usually regard their competitors with suspicion. They know that if they do not haggle and finagle and strategize and painstakingly search for the slightest edge, they will fall victim to firms that do. But once in a while, the soldiers of the financial world call a truce.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FROM THE CHAMBERS

title: On Turning 13: Reports from the Front Lines
description: Yesterday, Chelsea Clinton became a teen-ager. The Week in Review asked an eighth-grade social studies class at the New York City Lab School for Gifted Education, a public junior high that selects students with diverse backgrounds from all over the city: "What did it feel like when you turned 13?" Here are excerpts from their written responses.

title: On Turning 13: Reports from the Front Lines
description: Yesterday, Chelsea Clinton became a teen-ager. The Week in Review asked an eighth-grade social studies class at the New York City Lab School for Gifted Education, a public junior high that selects students with diverse backgrounds from all over the city: "What did it feel like when you turned 13?" Here are excerpts from their written responses.

title: Fitness Gets a New Face
description: The wave of exercise videos by models has spawned a television fitness show with a model as host. "Body by VH-1," with Rachel Hunter, begins tomorrow and will be shown at 7 A.M. and noon on weekdays on VH-1, the music-video channel.

title: N.R.A. Makes Beating Florio Its Prime Issue
description: The National Rifle Association is preparing to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars and recruiting new members in New Jersey as potential footsoldiers in what may be the most expensive political fight in the N.R.A.'s 122-year history: trying to unseat a governor.

title: Hillary Clinton's Potent Brain Trust On Health Reform
description: THE CLOCK is running on the Clinton Administration's task force on health care, which now has only two months to produce a comprehensive restructuring of a system that has resisted comprehensive restructuring for years. But Ira C. Magaziner, who is running the mammoth policy-making enterprise with First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton, still found time last week to make the long trip to the Tetons.

title: What's Possibly Left? Winfield Wants to Pitch
description: He pitched his collegiate team to the College World Series, and now, after proving his major league mettle, he wants a chance to pitch just one inning before he retires. Is that too much to ask? Not for DAVE WINFIELD .

title: By Any Name, They Still Set Off Those Bells and Whistles
description: THE Internal Revenue Service doesn't like the term "red flag" to describe those deductions on income tax returns that set the alarm bells clanging. "But a rose by any other name is still a rose," said Jeff Saccacio, a certified public accountant with Coopers & Lybrand in Los Angeles, "and whether they're called red flags or triggers, what we're talking about are claims the I.R.S. is sure to look at closely and probably challenge."

title: Don't Cut Jobs, Cut Working Hours. . . And Count In the Computer Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Fernandez in Final Top-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez had three service breaks in the first set en route to a 6-3, 6-1 semifinal victory over No. 5 Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia in the Evert Cup in Indian Wells, Calif. No. 4 Amanda Coetzer of South Africa defeated Stephanie Rottier of the Netherlands, 6-4, 6-3, in the other semifinal. Fernandez, a 21-year-old from Miami ranked seventh in the world, faces Coetzer in today's final for the $75,000 prize. (AP) Novacek Defeats Nargiso: Czech Karel Novacek beat Diego Nargiso of Italy, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday to reach the final of the ABN-Amro indoor touranment in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Novacek, ranked 16th in the world, will be aiming for his fourth singles title in today's final against Anders Jarryd of Sweden. Jarryd, a wild-card entry ranked 156th, beat fifth-seeded Aleksandr Volkov, 6-3, 6-7 (6-8), 6-3, in the other semifinal. (AP) Ondruska Wins Again: An unseeded South African, Marcos Ondruska, continued his streak of upsets yesterday, beating eighth-seeded Andrei Chesnokov, 6-4, 7-5, to advance to the finals of the Purex Championships in Scottsdale, Ariz. The 20-year-old Ondruska, who has yet to lose a serve while knocking out three seeded players -- Francisco Clavet, David Wheaton and Brad Gilbert -- during the week, will face Mark Woodforde of Australia, who defeated second-seeded Andre Agassi, 6-2, 6-3. (AP) ROAD RUNNING Winners Go 100K In a raced slowed by the cold, 28-year-old Valmir Nunes of Brazil and 30-year-old Marta Vass of Hungary lived up to their international credentials yesterday, finishing the U.S.A. national 100 kilometer championship in Central Park well ahead of their closest rivals. Nunes, the 1991 world champion, completed the 62.14-mile course in 6 hours 45 minutes 38 seconds, more than 6 minutes ahead of Stefan Fekner, 40, of Canada (6:51:52). Bryan Hacker, 29, of Bloomington, Ind., was third (7:11:49) and as the first American finisher became the national champion.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SAM'S CROSSINGBy Tommy Hays.Atheneum, $20.

title: Shriver: Women Pros Felt Special Kinship to Ashe
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Poverty Becomes Oh So Chic
description: Two years ago, Matty Rich's "Straight Out of Brooklyn" sailed out of the Sundance Film Festival and into theaters, propelled by the behind-the-scenes story of the teen-ager who rehearsed actors in his mom's apartment and made a movie for $77,000.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SAM'S CROSSINGBy Tommy Hays.Atheneum, $20.

title: On Sunday; 'Cost-Effective' Can't Measure Babies' Lives
description: STORY No. 1: Aug. 29, 1992, Catherine Grotto was born at 3 A.M. in Point Pleasant, N.J. She was full term, weighed 8 pounds, but as soon as her umbilical court was cut, she turned blue. Doctors diagnosed hypoplastic left-heart syndrome, one of the most common and serious heart defects in infants. Catherine's aorta was one-tenth the normal size, meaning oxygenated blood could not get to her body. Her heart had no left ventricle.

title: Maori Art Comes to Chicago
description: At dawn on March 9, more than 30 Maori people who have traveled from New Zealand for the occasion will hold a private ceremony to dedicate the newly restored Maori meeting house at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago. The public opening on March 13 will be marked by a Maori art exhibit through early May and dance performances in late March.

title: Tardiness Pays Off for a Jazz Quartet
description: WHEN four musicians formally got together in January 1990 and called themselves the Jazz Mentality, they planned to have a record made by 1991.

title: Corrections
description: CORRECTION: Because of an editing error, a letter on Feb. 14 misidentified a character on the television show "Gilligan's Island." He was Thurston Howell 3d. The letter writer had identified him correctly.

title: Audrey L. Ruggiero, John A. Kallassy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Ruggiero of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Audrey Loren Ruggiero to John Anthony Kallassy, a son of Nita Kallassy of Whitesboro, N.Y., and the late Peter Kallassy. An October wedding is planned.

title: Making Healthful Meals That Taste Good
description: YELLOW tomato gazpacho, trio of seafood boulangere, lattice Napoleon with stir-fried fruit -- it sounds like a gourmet meal, and it is. Yet this three-course menu, conceived by Christopher Smith, executive chef at the Westchester Marriott in Tarrytown, is also designed to be heart healthy -- that is, to contain no more than 1,000 calories, 20 grams of fat, 1,000 milligrams of sodium and 100 milligrams of cholesterol.

title: Take That! A 19-0 Run Propels Hall
description: Seton Hall gained further command of the Big East today by sweeping aside a challenging Connecticut team in a game that suddenly became easy near the end.

title: New Rule Is Aiding Deals
description: The buying and selling of formerly state-owned apartments became possible in Moscow only a year ago, when the city adopted a procedure through which occupants could privatize such dwellings for a fee of 1,400 rubles ($2.40).

title: The Women Who Volunteer for a Cancer-Prevention Study
description: FOR seven years, Renee Rauch of Howell Township watched her mother die. After a diagnosis of breast cancer, her mother underwent two radical mastectomies and aggressive treatment through which she suffered greatly, her daughter said.

title: How Clinton's Stimulus Plan Cuts Into Deficit; Cut Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Ivanisevic's Chilling Quote
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Rethinking The Statistics Of 'Epidemic' Breast Cancer
description: THROUGHOUT the 1980's the incidence of breast cancer appeared to rise dramatically, increasing by nearly a third from 1980 until 1987. Doctors, advocates for women with breast cancer and frightened women talked about an epidemic. But recently the American Cancer Society and the National Cancer Institute have cast a cold eye on those upward curves and have come to what should be a reassuring conclusion. Both assert there is not now nor was there ever an epidemic of breast cancer in this country. The increase was more of a statistical illusion, they say, resulting from an increased use of X-ray screening that caught cancers early.

title: Fleshing Out The Credits
description: To the Editor:

title: Courting a Monster Star In Hopes of a Monster Film
description: Robert De Niro, who proved in "Cape Fear," two years ago, how frightening he could be, is being wooed to play a genuine horror character.

title: EXPLOSION AT THE TWIN TOWERS: The Mayor; Dinkins Arrives From Japan and Views Damage
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, who was nearing the end of his nine-day trade mission in Japan at the time of the World Trade Center explosion, arrived in New York City yesterday afternoon and immediately met with First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Deadly Nuclear Waste Seems to Have Leaked in Washington State
description: About 7,500 gallons of deadly radioactive waste have apparently leaked from a tank at the Government's Hanford reservation in Washington State, raising serious questions about the success of efforts to improve safety of the storage of waste from the production of nuclear weapons.

title: On Turning 13: Reports from the Front Lines
description: Yesterday, Chelsea Clinton became a teen-ager. The Week in Review asked an eighth-grade social studies class at the New York City Lab School for Gifted Education, a public junior high that selects students with diverse backgrounds from all over the city: "What did it feel like when you turned 13?" Here are excerpts from their written responses.

title: Data Bank/February 28, 1993
You Can Escape to the Outdoors While Staying Inside
description: If in recent weeks you have been titillated by a vague yearning to set forth on stream, lake or ocean with rod in hand, you can intensify that anticipation by visiting the World Fishing & Outdoor Exposition, which opens Wednesday at the Rockland Community College Field House in Suffern, N.Y., and continues through Sunday.

title: New Jersey's Trappers Are an Endangered Species
description: A HANDFUL of muskrat skins and the pelts of a few raccoons and foxes were hanging from the rafters of the packing house on Calvin Hill's truck farm in Lower Alloways Creek. On this cold and blustery February morning, Mr. Hill was warming himself at the wood stove and recalling another day.
